Name: Global Conference 2001
Description:
This year's conference opened March 19 with a private dinner hosted by Mike Milken to tackle the issue of Philanthropy in the 21st Century.

A record 1,500 people attended this year's event, which focused on new markets, biological breakthroughs and the impact of world economic fluctuations on social conditions around the globe.

To view the 2001 Global Conference Briefing Book click here.

To view summaries of the conference, please click on the links below.

Portions of the 2001 Global Conference are available for viewing on the web site of Direct Capital Markets, a conference sponsor. To view, click here. Audiotapes of conference sessions are available for purchase ($15 per session) through the Milken Institute. To order, please contact us by e-mail at publications@milkeninstitute.org.

Name: Global Conference 2002
Venue:
The Beverly Hilton Hotel
Los Angeles, CA

Name: Lessons from Lexecon: Battling Back Against Frivolous Securities Lawsuits
Description:
Securities litigation against corporate America could impact the economy as the fear of lawsuits by investors and the costs of defending them by companies divert capital away from productive uses, presenters at this roundtable discussion said.

"I've talked to investors from all over the world, and their deep concern is securities litigation," said Mickey Kantor, former U.S. Secretary of Commerce and now a partner in the law firm of Mayer, Brown & Platt. "It strikes fear in their hearts."

With investment driving the economic boom of the '90s in the U.S., the economy could suffer if investors are scared away from American companies because of the increase in class-action lawsuits alleging securities fraud.

"Without that investment, which can be inhibited by the fear of these kinds of lawsuits, we're going to shoot ourselves in the foot," said Kantor, who also served three years as U.S. Trade Representative.

To prevent this from happening, several things are needed — from tort legislation and tougher judges to a legal strategy that fights these lawsuits based on sound economic research and theory, said members of the panel, who were also attorneys from Mayer, Brown & Platt, co-sponsor of the event.

The firm recently won a $50-million settlement in a lawsuit against Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes and Lerach, a New York law firm that has sued hundreds of companies on behalf of shareholders. Mayer, Brown & Platt sued the firm, accusing it of abusing the legal process by trying to destroy the reputation of Lexecon Inc., a consulting firm that has testified on behalf of companies sued by Milberg Weiss.

In April, a jury in Chicago awarded Lexecon $45 million in compensatory damages in the case. The two sides agreed to a $50 million settlement before the jury could decide on punitive damages.

The volume of securities class-action lawsuits in federal court has been climbing. Recent research described in a Policy Short published by the Milken Institute, "The Economic Costs of Frivolous Securities Litigation," shows that in 1998, the number of such suits filed was close to one suit a day for every trading day that the stock market was open, breaking the record set in 1994. The research also shows that smaller companies — those that are the fastest-growing in the country, such as high-tech firms — are being sued more frequently than larger companies.

Alan N. Salpeter, the lead attorney in the Milberg Weiss case for Mayer, Brown & Platt, said the Lexecon victory should send a signal to corporate America that it needs to fight securities lawsuits, not just settle them.

"If everybody settles these cases, then we'll never make law in this area," said Salpeter. "We'll never be able to fight back as a defense bar and establish some principals that are helpful. There's only so much that can be done in passing legislation. But there's a lot that can be done through the appellate process."

One of the lessons of the Lexecon case, he added, is that it "was clearly about someone who fought back."

Other solutions offered by the panelists included:

When building a defense, lawyers must think of the economics of the case. Many factors cause stock prices to fall, he said. Build a strong economics case as to why the price fell.

Tort litigation. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 helped reduce the number of frivolous lawsuits, but the numbers are climbing back. New legislation is needed to curb these suits. Passing new laws is a long and difficult process, however, said two other speakers — Philip R. Recht, former deputy administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration who joined Mayer, Brown & Platt this year, and Mark H. Gitenstein, former chief counsel to the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee who has been a partner with the firm since 1990.

They, along with Kantor, stressed the need for defense lawyers to be as aggressive as plaintiffs' attorneys have been in taking their case to politicians in Washington and Sacramento.

Gitenstein said he has learned four important lessons from his years in Washington:

"There has to be a good public policy reason for reform." It's not just who you know, he said, but "what you know" that counts.

"You cannot do tort reform in Washington unless it is bipartisan."

Be prepared for incremental reform. "You can't go for the whole enchilada," he said. "You're not going to get the whole enchilada."

Broad reform is possible, but only when the issue is positioned in a way that "the average American can understand it."
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: 2002 California State of the State Conference
Venue:
Century Plaza Hotel
Los Angeles, California
blurb: In an event best described as a “tough love” view of California, speakers at the 4th annual State of the State Conference lauded the state’s many strengths, but warned that problems - if unfixed - threaten its future.

Name: Milken Institute-Israel private/public partnership conferences
Description:
What do the Yarkon River and a parking garage in Tel Aviv have in common?

Both are the subject of initiatives by Milken Institute researchers who are working with officials in Israel on ways to finance urban development projects using new and innovative financial tools.

The Institute co-sponsored two conferences at Tel Aviv University in June 2002 that focused on two projects — the cleanup of the Yarkon River and economic development in Tel Aviv.

At the heart of both efforts are two of the Institute's top research priorities — using private/public partnerships and innovative financial tools, not just government funds, to save the earth's ecosystems, and to increase economic development in the Middle East.

The first conference, held June 10, examined a variety of financial tools that could help pay for the cleanup of the Yarkon River, Israel's second-largest river, which runs through seven different municipalities in the most densely populated area of Israel. Damage to the river includes water diversion, sewage outfall and habitat destruction.

The conference, "New Methods for Financing Environmental Projects in Israel / Case Study: Yarkon River Cleanup," brought together finance and environmental officials, academic experts and business leaders to look at ways to pay for rehabilitating the river, such as a mix of private and public funding.

The day-long event was co-sponsored by the Tel Aviv-Los Angeles Partnership and the Recanti Graduate School of Business and the Porter School of Environmental Studies at Tel Aviv University.

The second conference, "Community Economic Development in Tel Aviv-Yafo," held June 13, focused on how to use private and public financing to fund urban development in Tel Aviv.

It looked at the "Genesis" model in Los Angeles, which combines private and public financial tools for economic development, and how its successes could be transferred to initiatives in Tel Aviv.

Among those speaking was Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Studies at the Milken Institute and a host of private and public officials from Israel. The event was co-sponsored by the Tel Aviv—Los Angeles Partnership and the Tel Aviv Municipality.

The Tel Aviv-Los Angeles Partnership is active in joint projects between the two cities in the areas of economic development, education, culture and others. Most recently, the Milken Institute and the Partnership worked together on creating a municipal bond to raise money for the construction of a parking lot in Tel Aviv — the first of its kind of financing in Israel.

Both of the Israeli efforts are tied to the wider work of the Institute's Capital Studies group on finding innovative financial solutions to help solve long-standing social, economic and environmental problems.

Name: What's Next for Technology Stocks?
Description:
Early last year, the Nasdaq was over 5,000. Many dot.coms with little revenue sported market caps that far exceeded those of profitable retail companies hundreds of times their size. What a difference a year makes! The Nasdaq dropped nearly 70% before its recent partial recovery, and many dot.coms have fallen by the wayside.

So where do investors turn today? Has the technology sector bottomed out? Is it time to get back in? In this talk, Matthew Fitzmaurice will discuss volatility in the market for technology stocks and provide his unique insights on how to take advantage of it.

Amerindo pioneered the management of institutional portfolios comprised of emerging technology stocks. It is a leader in the management of institutional portfolios having a focus on Internet and Internet-related issuers. Since its inception in 1980, Amerindo has worked exclusively in the specialized area of investing in emerging-growth companies in technology, health sciences, and biotechnology. Today, Amerindo, has more than $4 billion under management and is exploiting the ongoing explosion in Internet technology, which is changing the landscape of business, consumer and government markets, both domestically and internationally.

Fitzmaurice is Chief Investment Officer for Amerindo with 13 years of investment and industry experience. He is also the Managing Member of Vertex Capital Management, LLC. Prior to his joining Amerindo, he was a Partner at Wessels Arnold & Henderson, and an attorney at Oppenheimer, Wolff & Donnelly, and at Crowell & Moring. He earned his BA from Georgetown University and his JD from Georgetown Law Center.

Amerindo Investment Advisors a leading investment firm specializing in emerging technology companies. Michael Milken, Chairman of the Institute, will introduce Fitzmaurice and engage him in a dialogue.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Matthew Fitzmaurice, Chief Investment Officer of Amerindo Investment Advisors.

Name: Why Do Emerging Markets Have So Little Firm-Specific Risk?
Description:
One of the most important roles of markets is to process information. But without secure property rights, judicial efficiency, honest government, and meaningful accounting information, markets cannot allocate capital efficiently and economic growth stands to suffer.

Bernard Yeung examines how emerging markets are subjected to economy-wide fluctuations to a greater extent than advanced economies because of political conditions that discourage informed trading, and instead foster "noise" trading. Yeung is a professor of international business at the University of Michigan Business School. His current research includes trade policies and firm behavior, foreign direct investment, and international trade.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Financial Instruments and Portfolio Risk
Description:
Do investors really know the risk of their high-yield bonds? Most methods currently used to value these bonds operate on the assumption that interest rates and equity returns are independent. But are they? Professor Theodore Barnhill argues that investors need to take both interest rate and credit risk into account, or else they will seriously underestimate the risk of holding such securities.

Barnhill is a professor of finance at George Washington University and the director of its Financial Markets Research Institute, created in 1995 to fund and conduct research in a variety of financial studies. Barnhill also co-founded FinSoft, a financial software development company focusing on security valuation and risk management. His book High Yield Bonds, co-edited with William Maxwell and Mark Shenkman, is forthcoming.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: The Frontiers of Global Economic Development
Description:
How to govern for prosperity will be one of the most important policy puzzles of the next century. Although the study of political economy has provided many answers as to how political arrangements can create incentives for growth, not all leaders govern for prosperity.

Hilton Root, a Senior Fellow at the Milken Institute and a former senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution and professor in public policy and international policy at Stanford University, discusses these issues as they relate to how paths to economic success or failure begin with the political institutions of sovereign states.

Root organized and directed the Hoover Initiative on Economic Growth and Democracy, an advisory group that explores the relationship between economic performance and political choice in order to implement effective policies for developing countries.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: The Government as Venture Capitalist
Description:
The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program, the largest U.S. public venture capital initiative, provided more than $7 billion to small high-technology firms between 1983 and 1997. Harvard Business School Professor Joshua Lerner relates his findings about the long-run impact of the SBIR program, including the growth rate of SBIR awardees compared to other firms, the characteristics of the SBIR awardees that performed the best, and distortions inherent in the award process.

Lerner worked for several years on issues in technological innovation and public policy at the Brookings Institution, for a public-private task force in Chicago, and on Capitol Hill. His research focuses on the structure of venture capital organizations and their role in transforming scientific discoveries into commercial products.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Technological Change, Education, and the Labor Market
Description:
Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz, both professors of economics at Harvard University and research associates at the National Bureau of Economic Research, present a historical view of the impact of educational and technological developments on the U.S. economy, focusing on the interplay among technology, education, and human capital in the 20th century.

Professor Goldin's research covers a wide range of topics in American economic history, including industrial laws and legislation, women and employment, and the labor market and economic conditions in the past century. In the words of The Wall Street Journal, she is "a sort of historical detective." Goldin is a former editor of The Journal of Economic History and has authored and edited several books, the most recent of which is The Defining Moment: The Great Depression and the American Economy in the Twentieth Century, with Michael Bordo and Eugene White.

Katz's work has spanned the issues of income inequality, unemployment, changes in wage structure, and theories of wage determination. Katz has been editor of the Quarterly Journal of Economics since 1991, and is the co-editor of the recent NBER book Differences and Changes in Wage Structures.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: What's Different About Family Businesses?
Description:
Ralph Chami, assistant professor of business economics at the University of Notre Dame, presents his research on family businesses, which make up 40 percent of Fortune 500 companies and account for half of the U.S. GDP. His theory of family business encompasses both market forces and the non-market institution of family. He explores the tradeoffs a parent makes as owner and manager in deciding employee compensation packages and examine how trust, altruism, and family succession affect family members' behavior and the survival of their firms.

Chami also specializes in the economics of information and of risk and uncertainty. He recently published "Altruism, Matching, and Nonmarket Insurance" in Economic Inquiry, "King Lear's Dilemma: Precommitment versus the Last Word" in Economics Letters, and "Development Policies in the Presence of Unemployment and Non-Traded Intermediate Goods" in the Journal of Economics.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: The Asian Crisis Updated
Description:
The continuing financial crisis in Asia will not ease for at least another year, but if Japan undertakes needed reforms, we could see the economies of that region begin to turn around by the year 2000, Marcus Noland said in a speech at the Milken Institute.

Japan's economic health is critical to Asia's future. If it doesn't solve its financial problems, the rest of Asia probably won't solve theirs either, he warned.

"The real issue for the rest of Asia is Japan," said Noland, Senior Fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, D.C. "Japan is key to a speedy and constructive resolution of the crisis."

During his talk to about 150 guests at the Institute, Noland highlighted Japan's problems:

- An estimated growth rate this year of between minus-2 percent and minus-3 percent.

- Rising unemployment among the core male population.

- An increase in precautionary savings.

- The flight of deposits from commercial banks to government-run institutions.

Noland offered several solutions:

1. To stimulate demand for goods, Japan should establish a finite inflationary target and then "simply print money until it is reached" - an idea, he concedes, that does not have many supporters in Japan.

2. Japan must follow through on its promises to spend public money to stimulate the economy - and spend that money wisely. "There have been so many special packages, so many stimulus plans and so many supplementary budgets in the last 15 years that haven't amounted to much that no one actually believes them," Noland said. So when the government announces, as it recently did, a 10-trillion yen stimulus package, he expects it to actually spend about 3 trillion yen.

3. Japan must act aggressively to shut down insolvent banks and pay off bad loans, which some estimate as high as $1.5 trillion. The government recently earmarked 60 trillion yen (about $500 billion) to fix the problem, a decision praised by Noland. But, historically, the government has been reluctant to implement such plans. "The government doesn't want to act aggressively, because it fears that if it aggressively tries to shut insolvent banks that it will exacerbate a credit crunch. And it also wants to protect its friends," Noland said.

Because of this reluctance, Japan runs a risk of making things worse.

"Given the set of institutions, incentives and corporate governance practices that their economy operates under, one runs the risk of simply recapitalizing a flawed system and setting yourself up to exacerbate the crisis somewhere further down the road with a public that would, understandably, be even less willing to pay the bill," Noland said.

Fortunately for Japan, it is stable and has many resources at its disposal. The rest of Asia isn't so fortunate. South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines have all suffered tremendous economic losses due to fiscal, regulatory and political problems. Unfortunately, righting Japan's economy may cause further damage to some of these countries - especially South Korea. A devaluation of the yen, for example, would cost Korea exports not only to Japan, but also to other countries like the United States as Japanese goods became more competitive.

Noland also touched on these problems:

- The U.S. trade deficit could reach $300 billion this year. While that is not a problem at the moment, it could become a big problem later. "If the U.S. economy weakens, the trade deficit could rise in terms of political salience in the U.S. And if Japan has not pulled out of its recession by the time the United States economy weakens, then the world economy could truly be a mess," Noland said.

- China, while not as bad off as the rest of Asia, still faces many problems, including its own poor banking system and the transition of state-owned enterprises to the private sector. A devaluation of some type can be expected from China next year.

Without a healthy Japan, however, the rest of Asia cannot recover, Noland said. Even the $30-billion stimulus package recently announced by Japan to revive the economies of other Asian countries will go only so far. "Restoring robust growth in Japan would be more desirable," Noland said. And that will take time.

"This is going to be a slog," Noland said. "This is unlikely to turn around quickly. I don't think one can have any real confidence in positive growth until 2000."

Noland is one of the nation's most preeminent scholars of East Asian economies. He formerly served as a senior economist on the Council of Economic Advisers and has authored numerous books and articles on subjects ranging from the impact of the Asian currency devaluations to the U.S.-Japan economic conflict. He has testified before Congress in his areas of expertise and has consulted the World Bank, the New York Stock Exchange, and the U.N. Conference on Trade and Development.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: What's Happening on the Regulatory Front?
Description:
The current push in Washington for more federal regulations - on everything from trade to high technology - poses a threat to the American economy, Fred Smith said at the Milken Institute.

As a result of these regulations, some industries have been stymied, such as in biotechnology, where regulations make it difficult for entrepreneurs to get their products to market. In other industries, such as small drug manufacturers, regulations threaten their ability to compete with larger companies.

"Right now, the whole mood toward regulatory reform is at an ebb," said Smith, president and founder of the Competitive Enterprise Institute. "The forces favoring greater regulation are having a bit of a renaissance."

It is time for Congress to control this regulatory fever. The U.S. should treat regulations the way it treats the federal budget - Congress must authorize it and the president must sign it into law. Lawmakers cannot continue to allow each agency to impose whatever controls it wants, with little oversight, he said.

"It's becoming recognized that it's something that has to happen," said Smith. "Over the next 20 years, we will have some form of regulatory accountability, which will essentially mean that regulations will be included in a more precise way in the U.S. budget. I think that will lead to a view that regulations can be promulgated by agencies, but they don't become law until Congress and the president sign them into law. That's a kind of tool that would attract bipartisan support over time."

Lack of accountability is just one problem with current regulations, he said. The other is a feeling by many agencies that anything new is risky, such as medicines or the Internet. The problem with that way of thinking, he said, is that it inhibits progress.

"There are risks of going too quickly into the future, but there are also risks of staying too long in the past," he said.

Smith pointed out two areas in particular that are hurt by too much regulation. One is in biotechnology. In many ways it is similar to the computer industry, where bright entrepreneurs push the boundaries of technology. The difference, however, is that the computer industry has few regulations while biotechnology has many.

"One of them produces a Bill Gates, the other hasn't produced much wealth at all," Smith said. "One of the reasons is a Steve Jobs or Steve Wozniak can start off with a brilliant idea, develop it in their garage and then, if it really works, attract capital and go out and become incredibly wealthy. A biotech firm can start with its product in a small lab, but when it wants to take the next step and become a marketable product, it has a real impediment, because it has to go through the regulatory process."

The other area where regulations hurt is trade, where the end of the Cold War has resulted in the United States demanding more from its partners. With the Soviet Union in power, we dealt with the world "on its own terms," which sometimes meant dealing with countries with poor human rights records or repressive leaders. "With the Cold War over, in America in particular, a lot of utopian fantasies have been freed," he said.

Groups as diverse as Greenpeace and the Christian Coalition are trying to impose their moral beliefs on the rest of the world through federal trade policies, which jeopardizes our commerce with the world, Smith said.

"The risk with this new world is that protectionism will become a moral thing to do - 'Yes, we'll trade with Burma as soon as they have wonderful human rights.' These are areas that are not going to be easy to achieve and they create incredible backlash potential among the rest of the world."

Smith is the president and founder of the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a public interest group that promotes market-based solutions to economic and environmental public policy issues. CEI publishes Ten Thousand Commandments, an annual survey of federal regulations. Smith co-authored the book Environmental Politics: Public Costs, Private Rewards, and has contributed to numerous other books as well as to leading national newspapers and public policy journals.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: China in Transition: Social & Economic Challenges
Description:
China has made tremendous progress in moving toward a market-based economy in just a few short decades, but still faces monumental challenges in the years ahead - from having enough food to feed its people to finding enough jobs for its millions of workers, a group of experts said Thursday night.

But while the problems are vast and difficult, its leadership appears to be working hard to prevent them from becoming major catastrophes - and in many cases is succeeding, the speakers said.

"What we're seeing in China today is a leadership that is struggling with enormous problems," said Barry Naughton, a professor in International Relations and Pacific Studies at the University of California, San Diego. "It might still be swamped by these problems, but so far, from everything we can see, it is maneuvering to keep a very dramatic forward momentum going on."

One of the most recent signs is China's concessions on negotiations for entry into the World Trade Organization, he said.

"It is a very large and very important package of concessions by the Chinese that has the effect of opening Chinese markets in very important ways to outside business," Naughton said. "I would say this WTO agreement represents a recognition that government-sponsored attempts to restructure industry in a planned way aren't working, and the only thing that works in China, and that the only thing that's going to work in the future, is to ratchet up the degree of competition, ratchet up the degree of economic change."

Naughton was one of three speakers who addressed an audience at the Milken Institute Conference Center on, "China in Transition: Social & Economic Challenges." The event was co-sponsored by the Asia Society, the Milken Institute and the USC-UCLA Center for East Asian Studies. The event was moderated by James Tong, co-director of the center and a professor of political science at UCLA.

All three speakers pointed to large-scale problems facing China's leadership, from vast environmental pollution to rural poverty.

Vaclav Smil, professor of geography at the University of Manitoba, said China faces terrible problems of air pollution, soil degradation and water shortages - all of which spell trouble for China's ability to feed itself.

With so many mouths to feed, and with only a limited amount of food available on the world market, China has no choice but to grow its own crops to feed its people.

But, he said, "You have to have a reasonably healthy environment to do that."

Anthony Saich, resident representative of the Ford Foundation in Beijing and Daewoo Professor of International Affairs at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, said that rural poverty remains one of China's biggest problems.

"The long-term future of China resides in resolving very deep-seated rural problems," Saich said. "It's still where 80 percent of the population lives, and it's where domestic demand will eventually have to be stimulated to keep the Chinese economy moving along."

As the Chinese leadership struggles with these problems, it is faced with many dilemmas, the speakers said. One of the most difficult is being able to reduce the country's massive state-run enterprises while maintaining its strong growth rate, Naughton said.

"In order to continue this process, (Prime Minister) Zhu Rongji needs to be able to hold out to the workers who are being laid off the possibility, the promise that they'll find some other kind of work, some new occupation, that they're not just going to be cast aside on the ash heap of history," he said. "Zhu Rongji needs to keep the growth rate up."

To do this, the prime minister has injected government money into various infrastructure projects.

"The reason this is a dilemma is that in doing so, Zhu Rongji is inevitably working at cross-purposes," he said. "The money that gets pumped from the state into infrastructure projects inevitably goes primarily back into the state sector. So on the one hand, Zhu is shrinking down the state sector by intensifying market competition. On the other hand, he is propping it up by pouring government funds into a large-scale investment program."

"That's a set of choices that is easy to criticize," Naughton added, "but it's hard to figure out what he should do that's a whole lot better."
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Korea Update '99
Description:
Diplomatic efforts currently under way may be North Korea's last chance to create permanent peace and stability on the Korean peninsula, South Korea's ambassador to the United Nations said today.

"We sincerely hope that the North Korean leadership seizes the opportunity to establish a more permanent basis for peace and security," See-Young Lee said in a luncheon talk co-sponsored by the Asia Society, Milken Institute, and UCLA Center for Korean Studies. "It is incumbent on them to respond positively to our overtures so that we can together create a new paradigm for peaceful coexistence and respect."

Lee's talk came one day before U.S. special envoy William Perry arrived in North Korea for talks meant to persuade its leaders to abandon their nuclear weapons and missile programs in exchange for a package of economic and diplomatic benefits.

Perry brought with him a joint message from the U.S., South Korea and Japan, which have worked on a package of incentives to encourage the North to end its weapons programs.

Lee said the package is part of a strategy of engagement with North Korea that his country hopes will finally persuade the communist regime to turn from confrontation to peace with its neighbors.

"We believe the package deal presents the North Korean regime with its best chance for survival," said Lee, pointing to the North's numerous economic problems. "It may be their last chance as well."

Also speaking at the event were Hilton Root, a senior fellow at the Milken Institute, and Ci-Wook Shin, a professor of sociology at UCLA.

Hilton Root
Root discussed his recent report, "The New Korea: Crisis Brings Opportunity," which proposes that compromises be made by the three major sectors in South Korea - the giant chaebols, labor and finance - so that needed economic reforms can go forward.

"Labor markets, enterprise markets and financial markets are part of an integrated social bargain in Korea," Root said. "People there understand these as related, not as separate."

Unfortunately, the International Monetary Fund only looked at financial reforms when it helped out the South Korean government in 1997.

"The IMF failed to understand that reforms must include all three sectors at once if changes are to occur, and as a result, the necessary reforms have not taken place," Root said.

Despite these failures, Root said there is room for optimism.

"There still needs to be an integrated settlement. There still needs to be a meeting of labor with management and with the capital markets, the banks, the IMF and the president in which there are tradeoffs, in which different groups make concessions, because all of these three groups hold part of the power," he said. "Nothing will happen if one works exclusively with one of these groups and not with all three at the same time."

Ci-Wook Shin
Shin spoke on social crises affecting South Korea that, despite some recent good news about that country's economy, remain serious problems.

"If you read Korean newspapers these days, you may get the impression that the crisis may be over," he said. "Stock prices went up. Some people are expecting growth of 4 to 5 percent this year. But if you talk to people in Korea, you get a more conflicting picture. You get the impression that the crisis is far from over."

Among the most serious problems is unemployment, now at between 8 and 9 percent - very high by Korean standards.

"Jobs are more than just about simply making money. The workplace is a place for social occasions," he said. "Losing a job is more than simply losing a means to make money, but also losing your social worth."

As a result of this high unemployment, labor unions are in trouble. They have lost public support.

"The labor movement is at a crossroads. It is facing a very tough challenge," he said. It must shore up its support, while being careful not to take actions that hurt its interests.

"Any miscalculation may facilitate the demise of labor activism in South Korea," he said. "The next couple of months will be crucial for labor activism in South Korea."
Venue:
Regal Biltmore Hotel
Los Angeles, CA

Name: Global Conference 2003
Venue: Beverly Hilton Hotel, Los Angeles, CA
blurb: The 2003 Global Conference brought together 180 panelists and 1,600 leaders in business, finance, government, academia, media and other fields for an invigorating three-day learning and networking experience.

Name: The Economics of Consolidation in the U.S. Defense Industry
Description:
In the early 1990s, the aerospace industry remained both the most technology-intensive U.S. manufacturing industry (measured by R&D as a fraction of sales) and the single largest high-technology industry (in terms of total R&D performed). From 1993 to 1997, as the result of changing Defense Department policies, U.S. aerospace and defense producers underwent an unprecedented wave of large-scale consolidation. With the recent decision to oppose the merger of defense giant Lockheed-Martin with Northrop-Grumman, U.S. government policymakers have signaled that further reduction in the numbers of potential prime contractors for key defense products will be subject to much more stringent scrutiny, closing a chapter in the recent history of these industries.

What forces have been driving these policy changes, and what impact have they had on the structure of U.S. aerospace and defense industries? What was the public policy rationale for encouraging consolidation, and how has it changed in light of current and probable future trends in defense spending? Has government policy gone too far, or not far enough?

As an economist, Kenneth Flamm has written extensively on trade, technology, and competition in global high-tech industries. His most recent book is Mismanaged Trade? Strategic Policy and the Semiconductor Industry. From 1993 to 1995 he served as Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary (Economic Security) and Special Assistant to the Deputy Secretary of Defense and was responsible for dual use technology policy and international programs.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: The Role of Japan in the Asia-Pacific Balance of Power: Economics, Technology, Politics and Psychology
Description:
This talk will cover the strategic relationships in the Asia-Pacific region during the Cold War and the rise of Japan from the ashes of defeat in the Pacific war, with special emphasis on the first post-Cold War decade.

Peter Berton, Distinguished Professor Emeritus of International Relations at the University of Southern California, will address the impact of nuclear proliferation in South Asia, the escalation of tension in the Taiwan straits, and the potential development of nuclear weapons and delivery systems by North Korea, on Japan. He will also explain the characteristics of Japan's foreign policy as forged by politics, economics, technology, and psychology. Other issues posed are whether we expect a revision of Japan's peace constitution and a new assertive Japanese nationalism; should Japan become a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council (with or without veto power); and what role Japan might play in the evolving security architecture in the Asia-Pacific region in the 21st century?

Berton is Distinguished Professor Emeritus of International Relations at the University of Southern California. He was Coordinator for the Asia/Pacific Regional Studies Program for 30 years. He also taught at Stanford and UCLA, as well as in Japan, England, and Germany. He held research positions at Harvard, Columbia and Tokyo universities, and the Kyoto Research Center. He is the author of over 100 publications on Asian and Soviet/Russian affairs, including International Negotiation; The Japanese-Russian Territorial Dilemma, "The Psychology of Japan's Foreign Relations," and "New Stability and Security in the Asia-Pacific Region."
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Peter Berton, Distinguished Professor Emeritus of International Relations, University of Southern California

Name: The Impact of Movie and Television Industry Strikes on the Los Angeles Economy
Description:
With strikes by the writers' and screen actors' guilds looming, Los Angeles is girding up for its greatest quake in a decade. The entertainment industry here is among the strongest urban industry clusters in the nation, rivaling Wall Street's concentration and influence on New York's economy by many measures. If a strike occurs, what will the consequences on the city's economy be — both short-term and long-term?

The entertainment industry accounts for a substantial sector of the Los Angeles economy. The motion picture and television production industries directly produce roughly $24 billion in output each year. The indirect economic effects of the industry are significantly higher, since film and TV production rely on a vast array of local industries peripheral to the entertainment world. Services from dry cleaning to caterers, artisans to accountants, will feel the tremors. How then, will this strike impact the suppliers that serve the entertainment world and the entire economy of Los Angeles in turn?

Ross DeVol is an expert on the California economy and technology, with particular expertise on regional industry clusters — the product of businesses and workers seeking geographic proximity to others engaged in related activities. DeVol will discuss the far-reaching effects of a strike within the entertainment world on the external industries that support it and the Los Angeles and California economies.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Ross DeVol, Director of Regional & Demographic Studies, Milken Institute

Name: The Economics and Politics of Post-Communist Transition
Description:
The demise of communism left behind a vast geopolitical region extending from Central Europe to Eastern Asia with 400 million people and substantial resources. How is that region's transition from communism to a free market economy to be managed? And how will that impact our global economy?

According to professor and author Grzegorz Kolodko, if that transition is properly managed, it could be the fastest growing part of the global economy during the next decades. And that process of ongoing political, social, cultural and economic changes is of great importance not only to the countries directly engaged in these complex transformations, but their partners worldwide, too. Transition, he says, is gradual and costly, both in financial and social terms. But it must proceed slowly for that transformation to be successful.

So far, only a few countries have been able to surpass their pre-transition level of output, while most have been involved in a great transitional depression for several years. Kolodko sees this problem as part of an important international endeavor and serious challenge as well as a great chance for the foreign partners: the governments, international organizations and international business community. He will talk to us about the process: liberalization and stabilization, institution building and microeconomic restructuring as well as his formulas for properly designed transition strategies.

Kolodko is the Director of TIGER, Transformation, Integration and Globalization Economic Research, at Leon Kozminski Academy of Entrepreneurship and Management and professor of economics and finance at the Warsaw School of Economics and the University of Rochester, New York. He is a key architect of Polish economic reforms who led his country to the OECD. He served as Poland's First Deputy Premier and Minister of Finance from 1994-1997. He is a consultant to international organizations, lecturer, author of 25 books and a columnist who has contributed to The New York Times, Financial Times, International Herald Tribune, Journal of Commerce, The European and The Economist.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Grzegorz W. Kolodko, Professor, Director of TIGER, Warsaw, Poland and author of Shock to Therapy.

Name: eBusiness Challenge: Preparing for the Next Wave
Description:
Wireless technology is poised to become the next wave in the Digital Revolution. The rate of adopting this technology for e-businesses in the U.S. is just beginning to accelerate along with new applications and devices. Where is this cutting edge technology going, how will it affect existing technologies and what role does it have both here and in Europe?

In his talk, Alex Soschin will discuss his strategy for taking full advantage of the new opportunities wireless technology brings, and how and when to apply it successfully to e-businesses. He will explain the pitfalls of adopting new technologies and what other e-businesses are doing to remain competitive in the new economy.

As Strategic Business Consultant, Soschin brings many years of strategic consulting and business analysis experience to his role at Digital Boardwalk. He is a veteran of a wide variety technology companies including Bain & Bain and GeoCities. As a management consultant with Bain & Company, he developed strategic plans and initiatives for Fortune 500 enterprises in over 10 industry fields. Working in business development for GeoCities, Soschin was part of the successful team that was instrumental in providing the strategic framework and analysis behind Yahoo's multi-billion-dollar acquisition of the premier community-building site on the Internet.

He graduated cum laude from Harvard University with a concentration in Political Science.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Alex Soschin, Strategic Business Consultant, Digital Boardwalk

Name: The Sand Dollar Report: An Analysis of Venture Investing on the Digital Coast, 2001
Description:
The Southern California Digital Coast has been in the throes of an economic transition since The Los Angeles Region Technology Alliance (LARTA) began studying venture investing here seven years ago. Then, the dearth of venture capital and the small number of venture firms were indicators of regional immaturity, a promise being built but not yet realized. Four years later, venture capital was up and an increasing number of players were starting firms in the region. Dramatic increases in venture investing in Southern California continued well into 2000, buoyed by the exuberance of the stock market.

While it is clear that irrational exuberance has ended, both here and across the country, the findings of LARTA's The Sand Dollar Report 2001 reveal that, quantifiably, the Digital Coast has the most diverse venture capital investment of any comparable region in America and that the maturity of the industry continues to deepen and expand. Many challenges, however, still remain. This panel will discuss the findings of The Sand Dollar Report 2001 and assess the strengths and the weaknesses of the venture capital industry on the Digital Coast.

LARTA is an independent nonprofit corporation that serves as a trusted advisor to the technology industry in Southern California. Created by California legislation in 1993 as the Los Angeles Regional Technology Alliance, LARTA has become an influential catalyst for the industry through its technology think tank, boot camps for technology entrepreneurs, venture capital showcases, and administration of a California seed grant program. LARTA has mentored thousands of entrepreneurs, jump-started over $400 million in financing, published over 30 research reports, and administered $10 million through 76 California seed grants.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Tom Clancy, Enterprise Partners; Todd Springer, Trident Capital; John Morris, Tech Coast Angels

Name: eLeadership
Description:
What if the very elements that made your company successful were now liabilities? What if your employees did their best work without ever seeing one another? What if you had to make critical decisions with no business model to follow?

Welcome to the eWorld - the electronic business world where the old rules no longer apply, staffers work 24/7 in a virtual workplace, and business conditions change by the minute, literally.

eLeadership, by Susan Annunzio, presents new management practices to executives guiding their companies into the ultra-competitive high-tech New Economy. Her leadership methods instruct and inspire corporate managers to become eLeaders, aligning generational and corporate cultures to create a successful company.

Annunzio is a leading authority in the field of change management. She is a strategic business consultant to corporate executives worldwide who seek her expertise in creating programs that maximize the success and profitability of their change efforts. Annunzio holds master's and bachelor's degrees in psychology from Loyola University, Chicago where she was on staff. She teaches change management and organizational behavior at the Kellstadt Graduate School of Business, DePaul University in Chicago.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401

Name: Will George W. Bush Be the Urban Technology President?
Description:
After a fractious election process that lasted five weeks beyond the general election, George W. Bush, Jr. has emerged as the President-elect. Throughout the campaign, he focused on the need to reform education and stimulate greater participation in the "New Economy" by those who have not fully participated up to now.

What policy initiatives will the new president be likely advance to stimulate technology development in the nation's urban centers? Does his record as Governor of Texas provide any clues as to where his focus will be? Where will he need leadership encouragement with respect to expanding participation in the "New Economy?"

The issue of urban technology transfer, which entails education and training, infrastructure development, capital formation, entrepreneurial development, values and leadership is comprehensive and among our most important strategic priorities, according to Sidney Morse, President and CEO of the Institute for Strategic Thinking and Technology Development. Morse will present the President-elect's likely technology agenda and also highlight areas that will be critical for him to address if the "New Economy" is to expand to the nation's cities and increase the universe of opportunity.

Morse is President and CEO of The Institute For Strategic Thinking And Technology Development (ISTTD) and Adjunct Professor at National University where he teaches Leadership in a Global Environment and Strategic Technology Management in the Graduate MBA Program at its Los Angeles Campus.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Sidney Morse, President and CEO of the Institute for Strategic Thinking and Technology Development; Adjunct Professor, National University

Name: The American University: Why It Works, Where It Fails, How to Change It
Description:
The future of higher education is at a turning point. Even as research universities are losing their monopoly over higher learning, they are still the most powerful centers of human capital in existence. Whether the American university can reinvent itself in the information age remains an open question. Universities are the antithesis of change, contends author Susanne Lohmann in The American University: Why It Works, Where It Fails, How To Change It. Managing a university in a competitive environment that demands fast and furious change -and a political one dead set against it - is a formidable challenge. Is the American university up to it?

Susanne Lohmann is Professor of Political Science and Policy Studies and Director of the Center for Governance at UCLA. She has published about two dozen articles and a dozen book chapters and is the recipient of numerous fellowships, honors and awards. As a doctoral student, she was awarded a John M. Olin Fellowship and an Alfred P. Sloan Fellowship. As a faculty member, she was James and Doris McNamara Fellow at Stanford University, Olin Fellow at the University of Southern California, and Fellow of the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in 1998-99. She is now a Fellow of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. Her current research focuses on ethics and governance. Lohmann received her Ph.D. in Economics and Political Economy from Carnegie Mellon University in 1991.

The Milken Institute Forum provides a Town Hall-like setting that allows leaders mostly from the greater Los Angeles area to meet together and discuss critical public policy issues facing the region, country, and world.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Susanne Lohmann, Professor of Political Science and Director of the Center for Governance, University of California, Los Angeles

Name: The New Geography: How the Digital Revolution is Reshaping the American Landscape
Description:
Many have suggested that place is less important in the digital age than in the past, but it is actually becoming more important as we progress, author and expert Joel Kotkin tells us in his soon-to-be-released book, The New Geography: How the Digital Revolution Is Reshaping the American Landscape. The digital age has made choice in location more elastic, so the ability of a place to attract knowledge workers and information companies has become more critical. Success in the new economy will depend upon the success of a given locale to attract new economy businesses. This is true for all kinds of communities, from big cities and suburbs to towns. What will our cities look like in the decades to come?

Kotkin is a recognized authority on global, economic, political and social trends. He is a Senior Fellow with the Milken Institute and Pepperdine University's Davenport Institute for Public Policy as well as a Research Fellow in urban policy at the Reason Public Policy Institute. He serves as director of content for Prime Ventures LLP, a venture capital partnership specializing in new media ventures.

Kotkin was Business Trends Analyst for KTTV/Fox Television in Los Angeles where, in 1994, he won the Golden Mike Award for Best Business Reporting, and he writes a monthly column in the Sunday New York Times' Money & Business section titled "Grass-Roots Business." He is a columnist with the Los Angeles Business Journal and ReisReports.com, a frequent contributor to The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, Forbes ASAP and The Los Angeles Times, where he is a contributing editor to the Opinion Section. He served as West Coast editor for Inc. Magazine for five years and contributes regularly. He is the author of four books, and he lectures widely in the United States, Japan and Europe.

The Milken Institute Forum provides a Town Hall-like setting that allows leaders mostly from the greater Los Angeles area to meet together and discuss critical public policy issues facing the region, country, and world.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Joel Kotkin, Senior Fellow, Milken Institute

Name: Cracking the Value Code: How Successful Businesses are Creating Wealth in the New Economy
Description:
How do businesses create value in the New Economy? Companies are increasingly dependent upon intangible assets — brands, relationships, knowledge — as wealth builders, rather than the hard assets of the past. Organizations prosper or fail depending upon how they manage those assets — the basic building blocks of value and the "economic DNA" of businesses. How are intangible assets managed differently? What combination of tangible and intangible assets is best?

In their quest for a formula for creating wealth in the new economy, companies are looking to a new set of principles called Value Dynamics for the answer. Value Dynamics, unveiled in Cracking the Value Code: How Successful Businesses are Creating Wealth in the New Economy by Barry D. Libert, shows companies what steps they can take to create value in our technology-driven economy. It presents four simple steps for designing a business model, allocating risk, managing assets and using information. What to do differently and how to do it are the focus of this book.

Libert and co-authors Richard E.S. Boulton and Steve M. Samek are partners at Arthur Andersen, a premier consulting firm. This book is based upon a three-year study of 10,000 companies conducted by the firm.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Barry D. Libert, Partner, Arthur Andersen

Name: The Network Economy
Description:
Information goods have replaced industrial goods as the key drivers of world markets. Business leaders are tempted to abandon classic lessons of economics, and rely on a new diet of changing trends and industry buzzwords to guide them through the information age. But does doing business in a new economy require "new economics" to guide business decisions?

Managers ignore basic economic principles at their own risk, according to Hal Varian, Dean of the School of Information Management and Systems, University of California, Berkeley. Technology changes but laws of economics remain intact. How managers apply economic principles to the exchange of information goods is at the crux of formulating successful marketplace strategies in the new economy.

In his book, Information Rules: A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy, Varian culls economic principles of information and networks and translates them into practical business strategies. Varian explains the economic concepts needed to navigate the evolving network economy.

Varian is Dean of the School of Information Management and Systems, University of California, Berkeley. He also holds joint appointments with the Haas School of Business and the Department of Economics. His research involves the economics of information technology.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Hal R. Varian, Dean of the School of Information Management and Systems University of California, Berkeley

Name: Engines of Tomorrow: How the World's Best Companies are Using Their Research Labs to Win the Future
Description:
Research scientists have exited their ivory towers and re-entered the world of marketplace innovations. Gone are the days of research sans development. The future belongs to firms with a strong internal commitment to science and technology that is well-integrated with business and the markets.

The "engines," research divisions of major corporations like those at Bell Labs, IBM, HP and elsewhere, are reinventing themselves. They are putting the development back into R&D. Scientists are abandoning "pure" science in favor of good old-fashioned product development. Robert Buderi looks at the best practices of some of the world's preeminent research organizations as they seek to prepare their firms for the 21st century. With clarity and wit, Buderi examines this makeover and illustrates the emerging role of research alongside other corporate functions.

Buderi is former Business Week Technology Editor and author of The Invention that Changed the World. His articles have appeared in numerous national and international publications, including Newsweek, Time, Sports Illustrated, The Economist, Science, Nature, and The Atlantic Monthly. He served as an advisor to the British Broadcasting Corporation's "Science at War" television documentary series, and as a member of the selection committee of the Knight Science Journalism Fellowships at MIT. While at Business Week, Buderi was a member of the team that won the 1992 National Magazine Award for the Quality Imperative. In 1986-87, he was a Vannevar Bush Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He holds a bachelor's degree from the University of California at Davis and a master's degree from the University of Arizona.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401

Name: Meta-Capitalism: The eBusiness Revolution and the Design of 21st Century Companies and Markets
Description:
Make way for MetaMarkets.

The conversion of businesses from traditional corporate structure to Internet-leveraged, brand-owning, customer-focused companies will be complete by 2002. By then, every major company in every major sector will be an e-business. Outsourcing and external alliances are replacing the broad internal physical capital base of old. Companies that continually reinvent themselves through the use of new technology and alliances with external networks are thriving and the message is clear: corporate leaders must adapt or lose.

MetaMarkets — more efficient, more productive and better-managed markets that optimize the use of business networks, or "value added communities" — improve productivity through optimal use of external networks and greater consumer focus. According to Meta-Capitalism: The E-Business Revolution and the Design of 21st Century Companies and Markets, by Grady Means and David Schneider, super-productive MetaMarkets will create unprecedented wealth and value. Means and Schneider predict that capital market growth could increase from its current $20 trillion to $200 trillion in ten years.

Means and Schneider tell us how market leaders in every industry are accelerating growth and enhancing value through expanded, more efficient use of markets and capital, and by taking advantage of the extraordinary surge in human resources.

Grady E. Means is global leader of the Strategy Consulting group of the Management Consulting Services (MCS) practice of PricewaterhouseCoopers. David M. Schneider is managing partner of the Americas Theater Strategic Change practice of the Management Consulting Services (MCS) group of PricewaterhouseCoopers and is MCS's Global Leader of Strategic Planning.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401

Name: Internet Business Models: What's New and What's Not
Description:
Have you ever wondered how web sites that make money, do it? How is it that Internet businesses give away information and still turn a profit? Does the old axiom — there is no such thing as a free lunch — apply to the new economy? Is there a new way to run a business in the new economy or are the old rules still running the show? What laws of economics were violated or created? Or were they?

Robert F. Foster will share the truth about Internet businesses and the variety of models they are built upon in a captivating, interactive presentation. He will talk about the four drivers behind successful Internet businesses, revealing the "secrets" of Internet success.

Foster gained much of his technology experience as president of four technology companies, two of them start-ups. As president of Thomas Bros. Maps, he managed the conversion from manual to computer based mapping, doubled sales to $26 million and earned the company a Lycos "Top 5%" award. He was president and CEO of Thinque System, software company developing sales force automation and customer relationship management software for mobile hand held computers. He was president of Ellison Robotics, a startup company that designed and built factory automation and robotics manufacturing systems, and CEO of Goldsworthy Engineering, a leading edge engineering research and development company focusing on high technology composite plastics. He joined a Xerox Corporation subsidiary that developed manufacturing software and provided on-line time-sharing services when it was a startup and left when revenues were $90 million per year. There, he was vice president of sales and marketing and vice president of software development.

Foster received his MBA from The Anderson School at UCLA and a BS in mechanical engineering from Oregon State University.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Robert F. Foster, Professor, Anderson Graduate School of Management, UCLA

Name: The Minority Business Challenge: Democratizing Capital for Emerging Domestic Markets
Description:
Minority businesses are one of the driving forces in today's record U.S. economic expansion, growing by 17 percent last year — six times the growth rate of all U.S. companies. And their impact and importance will continue to increase, as minorities become a major segment of the population in the 21st century. Despite their tremendous growth, however, minority-owned businesses still cannot get access to the capital they need to grow and sustain their enterprises. Failure to adequately fund minority-owned firms will inevitably put a brake on the overall economy.

These are the conclusions of an important new study the Milken Institute and the U.S. Department of Commerce's Minority Business Development Agency — and the subject of this talk by Glenn Yago, head of the Institute's Capital Studies group. According to the study, minority-owned companies continue to suffer from a lack of capital on all levels — from equity funding to mezzanine and senior debt — to help them grow and prosper, even though these businesses are the fastest-growing in the country in numbers and revenue.

In his talk, Dr. Yago will discuss his findings and his vision for creating investment vehicles tailored to meet the needs of minority business owners. Creating new ways to get capital to this emerging domestic market sector will be good not only for minority businesses, but the U.S. workforce, institutional investors and the overall U.S. economy, he says.

Dr. Yago specializes in financial innovations, financial institutions and capital markets. His most recent projects involve emerging domestic markets — U.S. markets whose entrepreneurs belong to groups such as minorities, immigrants and women whose access to capital to grow their companies has traditionally been limited. The Minority Business Development Agency, National Women's Business Council, and the California State Treasurer's Office, among others, have actively participated in these projects. Dr. Yago received his Ph.D. in political economy from the University of Wisconsin, Madison.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401

Name: Power Transition and the Asian Challenge
Description:
Power transition theory tells us that the probability of war increases as a country's dissatisfaction with its position in the international power hierarchy rises. As the dominant international power, how should the United States address the threat of rising dissatisfaction among countries such as India and China? Tensions between the Unites States and Russia have eased but how this country organizes the international status quo vis à vis China and India — and their relative positions in an international power coalition — may determine whether the next century is a one of overall peace or devastating war.

What strategies ensure peace and stability among competing global powers? Power transition theory, with its consistently accurate depictions of real political events and policies, offers a realistic vision of the future. It can be used to forecast global and regional occurrences and can tell us a great deal about managing the power hierarchy of the international political system. It has proven to be a useful guide for managing relations between the United States and Russia, and a tool to understanding our complex relationship with China.

Jacek Kugler is the Elisabeth Helm Rosecrans Professor of International Relations and Political Economy in the School of Politics and Economics at Claremont College. His pioneering perspective on international politics has successfully challenged well-established thinking and accurately calculated world events that have since ensued. Kugler maintains that effective intervention by U.S. stakeholders will shape the agenda of the international system for decades to come. His current effort is to examine the changing dynamic of international politics along with other scholars and link their findings with viable policy recommendations.

Kugler received his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan following an M.A. and B.A. in Political Science from UCLA.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Jacek Kugler, Professsor of International Relations and Political Economy, School of Politics and Economics, Claremont College

Name: Women and Capital: Why is it Still an Issue?
Description:
We live in an era in which women sit at the helm of multinational corporations, run almost half of all businesses in the United States, employ 27 million people and stand behind much of the past decade's growing entrepreneurial activity in our country. Women have entered every profession and serve at every level of U.S. government and the military. They contribute $3.8 trillion to the marketplace annually and account for more than 70 percent of consumer spending.

Still, barriers to capital for women to finance new ideas or fuel old ones remain. Often times, financing criteria and the capital needs of women in search of backing do not mesh, leaving the underpinnings of an important emerging market unsupported.

Nell Merlino will address the difficulties and discuss new ways of making women's access to capital for business, education and training more equitable. Merlino heads Count-Me-In for Women's Economic Independence, a nonprofit opportunity organization raising capital from women for women. Count-Me-In is a "living laboratory of community, commerce and compassion" through which donated money is redistributed to qualifying women in the form of small-business loans and scholarships.

Merlino is also founder and President of Strategy Communication Action, Ltd., specializing in public education campaigns motivating people to act. She established "Take Our Daughters to Work Day" and was recognized in the book, Remarkable Women of the Twentieth Century, 100 Portraits of Achievement. Named one of "50 New Yorkers to Watch in 1999" by the New York Daily News, Woman of the Year by New Woman magazine and awarded the 1994 Fulbright Award for Outstanding Achievement, Merlino is renown for her skill in producing highly effective awareness-raising campaigns nationally and internationally. She is a 1977 Fulbright Scholar and graduate of Antioch College.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Nell Merlino, Co-founder and CEO of Count-Me-In for Women's Economic Independence

Name: The Middle East Peace Process
Description:
The Middle East Peace Process is at another critical crossroads. The Israeli-Palestinian negotiations are grappling with difficult final status issues. Israel has unilaterally withdrawn from Southern Lebanon without security arrangements in place on that border. And it is unclear how the death of Syrian President Hafez al-Assad will affect the deadlocked Israeli-Syrian negotiations.

Ambassador Edward P. Djerejian will address these and other significant issues of the Middle East peace process to give a perspective on the situation and prospects for peace and stability in the Middle East. Israeli Prime Minister Barak and Palestinian Chairman Arafat have missed important deadlines as both contend with serious issues of public opinion and support from their respective domestic constituencies. The issues of Palestinian refugees, borders and security, Israeli settlements and Jerusalem are all on the table. Hostilities on the Israeli-Lebanese border are high. Yet the death of Syria's 'Lion' Hafez al-Assad may change the dynamic to Israel's north.

Ambassador Edward P. Djerejian is currently the Director of the James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy at Rice University. Djerejian served as the United States Ambassador to both Syria and Israel and was Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs in both the Bush and Clinton Administrations. He has had key roles in the Arab-Israeli peace process, the U.S.-led coalition against the invasion of Kuwait, ending the civil war in Lebanon, release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon and security arrangements in the Persian Gulf. He is a graduate of the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service and speaks four languages: Arabic, Russian, French and Armenian.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: The Honorable Edward Djerejian, Director, James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy, Rice University

Name: Towards a New Financial Architecture
Description:
Under the old economy, "export is good" was the driving force. But the economies of the world have changed, and while it is widely agreed that complementary financial institution reform is a must, how do we know what changes should be made? Which new policies are right for the 21st century? What strategies are likely to work? And how much of the transition will be made by trial and error?

The shift away from export-led growth to internally or regionally demand-driven development strategies will create a better standard of living for the populations of developing nations. These are the findings of the Working Group on Development, Trade and International Finance, headed by Walter Russell Mead. This internationally recognized group from academia, business, finance, think tanks - including the Milken Institute - labor, media and international financial organizations, has just completed its initial work. Mr. Mead will reveal the Group's findings at this Forum and present the audience with concrete policy recommendations for reforming our international financial architecture to facilitate this shift.

Mr. Mead is a political economist engaged in the study of the evolving global economic system and its implications for American policy and society. He is co-Director of the Task Force on He is co-Director of the Task Force on U.S.-Cuba Relations and leads a research group to increase the effectiveness of international financial interventions by taking into account the specific social, cultural, political and historical factors of each recipient country. He is also project director of the Study Group on the History of U.S. Foreign Policy, senior contributing editor at Worth magazine and contributing editor at the Los Angeles Times. He is widely published, the recipient of several academic prizes, and a regular lecturer and commentator on radio and television. Mead is a graduate of Yale University. He is co-author of six books, several dozen articles and the recipient of numerous honorary degrees and awards.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Walter Russell Mead, Senior Fellow, U.S. Foreign Policy, Council on Foreign Relations Project on Development, Trade and International Finance

Name: California in the New Millennium, the Changing Social and Political Landscape: What Will California Look Like in the Mid-21st Century?
Description:
"California is a work in progress," observes Mark Baldassare, author of California in the New Millenium. "Forces and trends are converging that will transform California into a very different state from the one we know today."

The rapid change and population growth California is experiencing are expected to continue unhindered. The regional balance of power will shift form the urban coastal areas inland to the Central Valley, the Inland Empire and Orange County. The dominant ethnic group will be Latino. Most Californians believe that today's elected officials are ill equipped to develop public policy suited to cope with the volatile growth and change California is facing.

Baldassare examines California's economic, demographic and political underpinnings in light of three factors profoundly affecting the state: political distrust, racial and ethnic change, and regional diversity. These divisions will make it increasingly difficult to reach a consensus on public policy issues facing California as the state prepares for the future.

Marc Baldessare is a Senior Fellow at the Public Policy Institute of California in San Francisco and holds the Johnson Chair in Civic Governance at the University of California, Irvine. He directs the PPIC Statewide Survey, a public opinion project aimed at developing a profile of the social, economic and political forces that affect California's elections and shape the state's public policy. He was a professor at Columbia University, is the author of six books and received his Ph.D. from University of California, Berkeley.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Mark Baldassare, Senior Fellow, Public Policy Institute of California

Name: Challenges Facing Higher Education
Description:
American higher education is based on a centuries-old system of knowledge organization largely influenced by 19th-century academic traditions. How are universities to survive in the information age? Or will they?

UCLA Chancellor Albert Carnesale will offer his perspectives on the unprecedented challenges confronting contemporary research universities and the need to reassess all facets of the enterprise, if universities are to thrive in today's environment of pervasive change. In particular, he will discuss how such factors as the knowledge explosion, advances in information technology, and shifts in funding sources represent opportunities as well as challenges for the nation's institutions of higher learning.

Dr. Carnesale became Chancellor of UCLA in 1997 and holds faculty appointments in the Department of Policy Studies at the School of Public Policy and Social Research and in the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at the School of Engineering and Applied Science. In addition to his administrative duties, Dr. Carnesale is an active teacher and lecturer. Prior to joining UCLA, Dr. Carnesale was at Harvard University for 23 years, and Provost there since 1994. He received his Ph.D. nuclear engineering at North Carolina State University.

Dr. Carnesale consults widely in both the private and public sectors on foreign and defense policy matters, is co-author of six books, several dozen articles and the recipient of numerous honorary degrees and awards.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401

Name: Corporate Debt and the Technology Shock
Description:
Thanks to rapid advancements in technology, the U.S. economy continues pushing to new heights, but while this growth may continue, the risks to investors have also grown, two economists said in a talk at the Milken Institute.

"Technology is driving economic growth, not just in the United States, but by extension, in the world," said David Goldman, Global Credit Strategist for Credit Suisse First Boston. "It will continue to do so because of the unleashed forces that no force on earth can stop."

The "technology shock," as Goldman calls it, has turned the investment world upside down. Price-to-earnings ratios have skyrocketed; companies that used to be secure, low-risk have become more volatile as they enter the high-tech market; and as the stock market continues to go up, volatility has gone up, too - exactly the opposite of what has occurred historically.

All of these rapid changes have made life more unpredictable for investors.

"We're in a world such as has never been seen before," Goldman said. "People are getting better stock returns, but feeling more and more nervous about it. This is an anomalous event."

The American economy is so dependent on stock market gains from the high-tech sector that poor earnings could threaten the overall economy - and that has created uncertainty around the world.

"The American consumer is spending, to some extent, capital gains out of her stock portfolio," Goldman said. "Consumption is very much dependent on the stock market, and the stock market is dependent on these kinds of valuations. This makes the world a riskier place. It means that although growth has been stronger than any of us forecast, it's a narrowly based growth, and one based on sources that are difficult to understand."

One result of this volatility is that high-yield debt may be a safer investment than investment-grade debt, he said. The default rate for high-yield bonds is the lowest it has ever been.
