Although there are certain indicators that economists can use to gauge the market - with the volatility of stock prices and the cost of hedging equity prices being two of the most important - there are still many uncertainties, Goldman said.

"The high-yield debt market is between fear and greed," he said. "We're likely to continue with that kind of very odd, not quite knowing how to look at the market for some time."

Bob Kricheff, Managing Director at CS First Boston, highlighted some of the technology areas that are particularly active today, such as cable television, the Internet, and telecommunications. He said the high-yield market is feeding much of their growth.

"The high-yield market really does not act without the major technology sectors and vice versa," he said. "They're closely linked."

To show how much technology industries have restructured the high-yield market, Kricheff pointed to statistics that showed that in 1992, this area made up 13 percent of the market. Today, it makes up 30 percent.

"It's creating some phenomenal opportunities for wealth, some phenomenal opportunities for productivity, and some phenomenal opportunities for employment," he said.

But he added the same cautious note as Goldman about the risks of such a rapidly changing and popular market.

"What worries me is people blindly investing money in everything that ends with a dot-com."

He said investors should keep in mind four things:

  • The technology area is made up not of just one, but many sectors.
  • Rapid change is the norm, so don't get trapped in "old world views" and get stuck on one theme or one company.
  • Don't focus on a company's assets, but how well they execute their business plan.
  • Focus on customers; they are the key to this industry.

"Everybody gets tied up in the technology," Kricheff said. "That is what's changing the economy. But at the end of the day, it's not necessarily what's driving businesses. It's still a lot of execution and focus and winning customers and revenue."
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: A Future Perfect: The Challenge and Hidden Promise of Globalization
Description:
Everyone is talking about "globalization," but the term has vastly different meanings for different people. Most economists view globalization with optimism, but labor movements consider it disastrous.

Globalization has become an economic, political and cultural phenomenon. In this talk, John Micklethwait and Adrian Wooldridge, who recently completed a book on the subject, present all sides of the trend. The speakers explore the three engines of globalization - technology, the capital markets and management - and its ancillary issues. They make their case in favor of an integrated world economy by demonstrating that globalization is not only reshaping business, but enhancing the lives of ordinary people.

John Micklethwait was appointed U.S. Editor of The Economist this past December. He was the New York Bureau Chief for two years, and Business Section editor for four years before that. He is the author of six Economist surveys and has covered business and politics for the publication from the U.S., Latin America, Asia, Europe and South Africa. He is also a winner of the Wincott Award, Britain's leading journalism prize. He has appeared on television and radio around the world and has contributed op-ed pieces to numerous other publications.

Adrian Wooldridge is the Washington correspondent for The Economist covering politics and social policy. He has been an Economist staff member since 1988, serving as its social policy correspondent, management editor and most recently, its West Coast correspondent in Los Angeles. He is the author of Measuring the Mind: Education and Psychology in England, 1860-1990 and co-author of The Witch Doctors with John Micklethwait. His work has appeared in publications worldwide.

Note: the authors' latest book, A Future Perfect - The Challenge and Hidden Promise of Globalization, will be available for sale at this Forum.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: John Micklethwait, U.S. Editor, The Economist; Adrian Wooldridge Washington Correspondent, The Economist

Name: New Economy, Old Institutions: A System in Crisis
Description:
Our institutions are in crisis. Health systems, educational systems, judicial systems and political systems are in flux - not only in the United States, but in the rest of the world as well. Why? Is there a common thread? How are our institutions, designed to meet the needs of other eras, keeping up in the digital information age? Or are they?

Alvin Toffler will address these issues and others in an interactive discussion with attorney Barry H. Lawrence. They will explore how radical changes in our external environment such as instantaneous and mobile communication, have thrown our long-standing institutions and systems into disarray, and will share their thoughts on what steps we can take to return to synchrony.

Futurist Alvin Toffler is the author of more than one dozen books, including the bestsellers Future Shock and Third Wave. He is highly regarded throughout the world by business and political leaders, many of whom consider him a visionary and master of future blueprints. Toffler and his co-author/spouse, Heidi Toffler, wrote about the proliferation of computers, the advent of cable television, niche markets, the shift to work-at-home, corporate restructuring, the break-up of the Soviet Union, the shift to a global economy and dozens of other scenarios long before they even appeared in our nomenclature.

Barry H. Lawrence, an attorney with the international law firm Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, LLP, is an expert in business and finance. He was a television analyst with Financial News Network and served as a Deputy Attorney General for the State of California. He has lectured widely in Asia and Israel on issues of finance.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Alvin Toffler, Author, Futurist;
Barry Lawrence, Attorney; Kaye Scholer, Fierman Hays and Handler, LLP

Name: Failure Be Damned: The Origin of California's Risk-Taking Culture
Description:
Though California's Gold Rush began 150 years ago, it set the stage for the entrepreneurial daring and inventiveness still prevalent in the Golden State today. In this presentation, J.S. Holliday reveals how California's often-fulfilled dreams of sudden wealth became the American dream and how California's tradition-defying freedoms have continually attracted risk-takers from all over the world.

Holliday has devoted 50 years of study to the California Gold Rush and its consequences, which he has dramatically captured in two scholarly books - the just published Rush for Riches and The World Rushed In: The California Gold Rush Experience.

His ability to communicate the drama and energy of the times have made The World Rushed In a classic that has remained in print since it was first published in 1981. A featured historian in the PBS television documentary series "The West," Holliday's mastery of the materials of the times - diaries, maps, manuscripts and photographs - brings the past into the present.

Holliday graduated from Yale University in 1948 and received his Ph.D. in American History from the University of California, Berkeley in 1958. He was a Research Fellow at the Henry E. Huntington Library in San Marino, California and was appointed assistant director of the Bancroft Library at U.C. Berkeley, where he developed a statewide acquisitions program for manuscripts and documents relating to the American West. He was Associate Professor of History at California State University, San Francisco, and Executive Director of the Oakland Museum of California. In 1970, he became Director of the California Historical Society where he directed fund-raising and gained wide recognition for the creation of major traveling exhibitions. Holliday retired as Director in 1985.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: J.S. Holliday, Historian, Author and Director Emeritus, California Historical Society

Name: Societal Needs, Environmental Concerns and Scientific Solutions
Description:
The world is faced with some daunting environmental challenges. Many of these are difficult to fix because of they derive from our everyday needs such as transportation and electricity.

In this talk, Nobel Laureate George A. Olah of the University of Southern California presents his views on how societal needs as well as major environmental concerns can be solved through the efforts of science and science-based technology. In particular, he will touch on issues related to his area of interest, chemistry, such as our reliance on limited and decreasing fossil fuel reserves and global warming caused by excess carbon dioxide formed through the burning of these fuels. One possible solution that has been suggested is to chemically recycle excess carbon dioxide into useful fuels, making us independent of oil and gas, and at the same time helping to mitigate global warming. Other topics for the talk include the gasoline additive MTBE and the insecticide DDT.

Dr. Olah is a Professor and the Director at the Loker Hydrocarbon Research Institute at USC, the only academic center in the United States devoted exclusively to the study of hydrogen and carbon. He won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1994 for his longtime research on how chemical bonds break and re-form during a reaction. He discovered how to "freeze" the chemical process in time, which enabled chemists to view reactions like a single frame of film. This led to a new branch of chemistry focusing on the study of hydrocarbons.

Dr. Olah holds over 100 patents and has authored more than 900 research papers. He has been at USC since 1977. He received his Ph.D from Technical University in Budapest.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: George A. Olah, Professor and Director, Loker Hydrocarbon Research Institute, and Nobel Laureate in Chemistry, USC

Name: Decision 2000 -- Predicting Elections Using Financial Markets: The Iowa Electronic Market
Description:
Predicting election results is always a dicey concern, especially in light of the lack of incentive to tell pollsters the truth. If people have a financial incentive, however, to evaluate information a little more honestly, the result is likely to more accurately reflect their opinions and thus more successful predictions. This is the premise behind the Iowa Electronic Markets (IEM).

The IEM are on-line futures markets operated by faculty at the University of Iowa College of Business. The idea behind them is that people will efficiently evaluate and act on information that will affect their "trades." Their conclusions are revealed through the market's prices. In a political market, for example, the IEM would issue stock for all the candidates. Share values will fluctuate based on participants' opinions as to the candidates' relative success. These fluctuations, in turn, can be "read" to see the reactions of the electorate to various changes in the political landscape.

In this talk, Robert Forsythe, one of the founders of the predecessor market, the Iowa Political Stock Market, will explain the process and elaborate on the IEM concept, especially vis-à-vis the upcoming 2000 elections.

Forsythe is the Senior Associate Dean and Cedar Rapids Professor of Business at the University of Iowa's Henry B. Tippie College of Business. He came to Iowa in 1981 after having served on the faculty of CalTech. His work primarily focuses on the use of experimental economics to examine issues in asset pricing, bargaining, and coordination problems, and he is the author of over 40 articles in journals of accounting, economics, and finance. Forsythe's Ph.D. is from Carnegie-Mellon University.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Robert Forsythe, , Senior Associate Dean, The Henry B. Tippie College of Business (Iowa City, IA)

Name: Saving the Environment from the Environmentalists
Description:
In this talk, Peter Huber sets out the case for Hard Green - a conservative environmental agenda - that is elaborated in his recent book, Hard Green: Saving the Environment from the Environmentalists - A Conservative Manifesto (Basic Books, 2000).

Huber argues that modern environmentalism destroys, rather than enhances, the environment, as it fails to conserve forests, oceans, lakes, and streams. In fact, the Soft Green movement hastens their destruction. Hard Green offers an alternative to this destruction. It argues for the rediscovery of Theodore Roosevelt and the conservation movement and the reversal the Soft Green agenda in order to save the environment.

Peter Huber is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute's Center for Legal Policy and a regular columnist for Forbes magazine. He is also widely published in scholarly journals, as well as in many other publications, in the fields of science, technology, environment, and the law. Prior to coming to the Manhattan Institute, he was an assistant and an associate professor at MIT, and was law clerk to then-Appeals Court Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg as well as for Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.

Huber earned his law degree from Harvard University and a doctorate in mechanical engineering from MIT.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: J. Peter Huber, Senior Fellow, Manhattan Institute

Name: Pakistan's New Politics
Description:
With no timetable in place for a possible return to civilian rule, Pakistan remains under the control of its army. Among the first actions of leader Gen. Pervez Musharraf was the installation of small provisional governments throughout Pakistan. What does this new political order mean for the citizens of Pakistan, and for the country's relationship to the rest of the world?

General Jehangir Karamat will speak about the political structure of Pakistan following the October 12, 1999, military coup that ousted the government of Nawaz Sharif. A former Chief of Army Staff as well as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee (a position from which he retired in 1998), Karamat will share his perspective of his country's future.

Karamat began his military career after graduation from Pakistan's Military Academy in 1961, eventually rising to command an Army Corps. He was a participant in the India-Pakistan Peace Talks in 1992-92 and has led military delegations to a number of countries in the region. After retirement, General Karamat became a Visiting Scholar at the Center for International Security and Cooperation, and in cooperation with Stanford University, has lectured widely. He also holds faculty positions at Pakistan's National Defense College and the Army's Command and Staff College.

A recipient of the U.S. Legion of Merit, among other honors, he holds a master's degree in International Relations.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: General Jehangir Karamat, Retired Four Star General and Former Chief of Army Staff, Pakistan

Name: Science Cooperation for Survival
Description:
The world is faced with a multitude of dangers that threaten our survival. Among these are man-made dangers, such as those posed by nuclear warfare and the buildup of radioactive waste materials, and natural dangers, such as the possibility of disastrous earthquakes.

Michael Intriligator and Vladimir Keilis-Borok propose that nations must begin to cooperate in a series of scientific "superprojects" to deal with these urgent problems. The hope would be to discover new ways of sustaining our civilization, protecting our environment, and lessening the dangers in our world. This effort would require wide international collaboration in the basic sciences, but a surprisingly small capital investment.

Intriligator is a Senior Fellow at the Milken Institute and has been a member of the UCLA faculty since 1963, where he currently is a Professor of Economics, Political Science, and Policy Studies. From 1982 to 1992, he directed the University's Center for International Strategic Affairs, the predecessor to the Center for International Relations. He is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the International Institute for Strategic Studies and has been appointed a Foreign Member of the Russian Academy of Sciences.

Keilis-Borok was the founding director of the International Institute of Earthquake Prediction Theory and Mathematical Geophysics of the Russian Academy of Sciences. He is a Professor in Residence in the Department of Earth and Space Sciences and a member of the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics at UCLA. Keilis-Borok also is a recipient of the Richardson Medal for studies in non-linear dynamics as well as a member of the Russian, U.S., Austrian, and Pontifical Academies of Science, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the Royal Astronomical Society.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Michael D. Intrilligator Professor of Economics, UCLA, and Senior Fellow, Milken Institute; Vladimir I. Keilis-Borok, Professor in Residence of Earth and Space Science, UCLA

Name: Not Just Another Cold Front: Why Canada is Vital to the United States
Description:
Although Canada and the United States are the closest of friends, very few Americans know much about the country to its immediate north. They are often astonished to learn that Canadian society differs greatly from American society and that Canada is, by far, America's largest trading partner.

In this talk, Kim Campbell discusses the overwhelming importance of the Canadian economy to U.S. trade and employment. She elaborates on the dynamic and close relationship between the two countries, while at the same time setting out some of the differences in the two societies. Additionally, she approaches the myths of Canadian cultural protectionism and runaway production

A. Kim Campbell is Canada's Consul General in Los Angeles and served as Canada's Prime Minister (the first woman to hold this position) from June 25, 1993 to November 4, 1993. Earlier government positions included appointments as Minister of Veterans Affairs, Minister of National Defense, Minister of Justice and Attorney General, and Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development). Her government service began in 1986 when she was elected to the British Columbia legislature. Elected to the House of Commons in 1988, Campbell served until 1993.

An advocate of what she has called "the politics of inclusion," Campbell holds a B.A. in political science and an LL.B. from the University of British Columbia.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Kim Campbell, Consul General of Canada (Los Angeles)

Name: Creating Organizations of Concord
Description:
Religion, race, and ethnicity give deep meaning to people's lives. But extreme and exclusive interpretations of these beliefs and experiences (referred to as "hypercommunialism") are a danger both to democratic life and economic prosperity.

In this talk, Barbara J. Nelson and Linda Kaboolian look at how organizations of concord - organizations that bring together individuals from religious/ethnic groups that have a historical record of enmity - work to bridge the deep divisions among people. When they work, such organizations can contribute to building economies and democracies that allow meaningful group identities but also a sense of common purpose among constituencies.

Barbara J. Nelson was named the first permanent dean of the UCLA School of Public Policy and Social Research in November 1996. Prior to this appointment, she was vice president and distinguished professor of public policy at Radcliffe College, and served on the faculties of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University and the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota, where she also was director of the Center on Women and Public Policy. A specialist in conflict resolution, Nelson has authored four books and more than 50 articles and book chapters. Her Ph.D. is from Ohio State University.

Linda Kaboolian is Associate Professor of Public Policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University, and the faculty chair of the Program on Public Sector Labor-Management Relations. Her research, teaching, and consulting focus is the design and operation of multi-stakeholder problem-solving mechanisms and service delivery in the public sector. Her expertise in evaluating and implementing innovative programs and processes has included work for the Department of Energy as well as the Social Security Administration. Her Ph.D. is from the University of Michigan.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Barbara J. Nelson , Dean, 
UCLA School of Public Policy and 
Linda Kaboolian, Professor, 
Harvard University

Name: Russia's Role in the Global Knowledge Revolution
Description:
The news we in the West have received about the Russian economy these past few years has been grim. Worse, Western scholars have been unable to come to any consensus as to how these economic conditions might be altered.

Contrary to this pessimistic view of recent events, observers in Russia contend that there is more economic opportunity now than ever before. In this talk, Nikita Mikhalkov speaks about the steps that are necessary to lift Russia out of its current position. Once these steps are taken, he believes Russia will become the fastest-growing economy the world has yet seen.

Mikhalkov has had a prodigious career as a film director. His 1987 feature film "Dark Eyes" starred Marcello Mastroianni, who won an Academy Award nomination for his performance. In 1992, his "Close to Eden" was nominated for best foreign language film by the American Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Mikhalkov has also appeared in over 20 films as an actor. He has built a strong reputation in the motion picture community worldwide and especially in his native country. Mikhalkov is also highly regarded for his sociopolitical commentary. He is extremely well-known throughout the former Soviet Union and often spoken of as a contender for the 2000 Russian presidential elections.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Nikita Mikhalkov, Academy Award-winning Filmmaker and Social Commentator

Name: Organized Crime and Corruption – The Impact on the Business Community
Description:
International investors must often consider situations that domestic investors would rarely think about. The influence of organized crime and governmental corruption often yields consequences investors could not have foreseen.

In this talk, Louise Shelley makes a case for considering the impact of crime and corruption when making investment decisions overseas, and highlights the unexpected consequences of organized crime and corruption on business.

Shelley is a professor in the Department of Justice, Law, and Society and the School of International Service at American University in Washington, D.C., as well as founder and director of the Transnational Crime and Corruption Center there. An expert on organized crime and corruption, she has particular expertise on law enforcement, crime and law in countries of the former Soviet Union.

As an adviser to the U.S. government on problems related to post-Soviet organized crime, Shelly has testified before Congress, the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and other bodies. She also has authored numerous articles and the 1997 book Policing Soviet Society. Her Ph.D. is from the University of Pennsylvania.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Louise Shelley, Professor
American University (Washington D.C.)

Name: Housing Demographics for the New Millennium
Description:
Why has the housing market been so strong recently? Why have home-ownership rates moved up to record highs? Has it all been because of the extraordinary economic expansion, or are there other factors involved? This talk looks at the demographic factors that have helped fuel the recent housing and home-ownership boom, as well as look at the strength of the housing market in the next decade.

David W. Berson is Vice President and Chief Economist at Fannie Mae in Washington, D.C. He is responsible for managing the Economics Department; forecasting and analyzing the economy, interest rates and the housing and mortgage finance markets; and advising Fannie Mae's chairman and Operating Committee on finance, economic, tax and housing policy issues.

Berson is past-president of the National Association for Business Economics (NABE), and has been on the Board of Governors of the National Economists Club. He is a member of the advisory board for the School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan and the advisory council for the Business School at Howard University. Prior to joining Fannie Mae, Berson was Senior Economist at the U.S. League of Savings Institutions and Chief Financial Economist at Wharton Econometrics. He has a Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Michigan.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: David W. Berson, Vice President and Chief Economist at Fannie Mae

Name: Thinking About China
Description:
Beginning with the Tiananmen debacle of 1989, and continuing more recently with Chinese missile tests in the Taiwan Straits and allegations of Chinese nuclear espionage, American attitudes toward China have soured noticeably. Over the past 18 months, a majority of the American people have come to view China as a "threat" - a far cry from the "strategic partnership" envisioned by President Clinton less than two years ago. What should America's response be to Asia's "awakening giant"?

Richard Baum is a Professor of Political Science and Director of the Center for Chinese Studies at UCLA. He specializes in the study of contemporary Chinese politics and foreign policy. He has served as a past director of the National Committee on United States-China Relations and as a founding member of the China Council of the Asia Society.

He has been invited personally to brief the President of the United States, and at UCLA he has twice been voted political science "Professor of the Year." He has written, co-authored and edited eight books, and more than 50 of his articles have appeared in scholarly and popular journals. He graduated from UCLA, and received his Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Richard Baum, Professor of Political Science and Director of the Center for Chinese Studies at UCLA

Name: The Goldman Sachs Financial Conditions Index: Still Accommodative After All These Years
Description:
The Goldman Sachs Financial Conditions Index illustrates the importance of the equity market in assessing the outlook for the U.S. economy and interest rates. Currently, the index is very accommodative. William C. Dudley, who will discuss the index in his talk, says this suggests that in the absence of a spontaneous stock market decline, further increases in interest rates will be required to slow the economy down to a sustainable growth pace.

Dudley has served as director of the U.S. Economic Research Group at Goldman, Sachs & Co. since October 1995, and has been a managing director since 1996. His duties at Goldman include economic and interest rate forecasting for the United States and overseeing the entire Canadian research effort. Before attaining his current position, he bore responsibility for the foreign exchange outlook, analyzed U.S. financial market developments, and for eight years was Robert Rubin's senior economic adviser. Prior to joining Goldman Sachs in 1986, Dudley was vice president in charge of regulatory management at J.P. Morgan.

In addition to his duties at Goldman Sachs, Dudley is a member of the technical consultants board to the Congressional Budget Office, a member of the Brookings Council at The Brookings Institution, serves on the corporate advisory board for the Institute for International Economics, and is co-chair of the economic advisory committee of the Bond Market Association. His Ph.D. is from the University of California, Berkeley.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
William C. Dudley, Chief Economist
Goldman Sachs (New York)

Name: How the Internet is Changing Our Social, Political and Economic Lives
Description:
Since the invention of the printing press over 500 years ago, the means of exchanging information have increased dramatically. Is the Internet just one of these means, or is it revolutionizing our lives to the same degree that the printing press did centuries ago?

In this talk, Jeffrey Cole separates hyperbole from reality in assessing the Internet's impact on business, political, and social activity worldwide. To do so, he looks at what we know today and examines the possible future influences of this relatively new medium on commerce, education, democracy, and human communication.

Cole has been a UCLA faculty member for 24 years and is director of the Center for Communication Policy. He is also principal investigator of the Network Television Violence Monitoring Project and, with U.S. News & World Report, is the co-author of several national surveys examining the attitudes and values of entertainment industry decision makers. A widely sought-after lecturer, Cole was named director of the Center for Digital Innovation at UCLA in 1997 and in that capacity will oversee campuswide strategies and policies with regard to telecommunications and new media.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Jeffrey Cole, Director
UCLA's Center for Communication Policy (Los Angeles)

Name: Reinventing Democracy
Description:
Over the past two years, a revolution has been taking place in the United Kingdom - a constitutional revolution. Tony Blair's Labour government has successfully passed 11 constitutional bills as part of the U.K. government's effort to strengthen citizenship through renewing democracy.

Graham Allen has been instrumental in crafting his party's reform effort. In this talk, Allen examines the United Kingdom's constitutional revolution in light of the vast changes that have taken place in society over the last century, as well as the possible effects that this constitutional overhaul may have over the coming years.

Allen has been a Minister in the U.K. Government since 1997. He currently is one of the four Senior Whips who run the government agenda, making sure its business is passed in the House of Commons. Since 1987, Allen has been a Member of Parliament for Nottingham North. His expertise lies in economic and constitutional affairs, and he has presented bills for a bill of rights, a written constitution, and the reform of the Second Chamber.

Prior to coming to his present post, Allen was an education and research officer for Britain's second largest trade union, the national coordinator of the British Trade Unions Political Fund, deputy head of the Programme Office for the Greater London Council, and a policy research officer at the Labour Party National Headquarters. His M.A. in Political Sociology is from Leeds University.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Graham Allen, Minister, U.K. Government
Specializing in Dept. of Environment and Transport (London)

Name: The Social Value of Medical Research
Description:
How much value would be added to the United States if we eliminated heart disease as a cause of death? How many trillions of dollars would be added if we eliminated cancer? Or stroke?

Although most of us have a humanistic understanding of the value of finding cures to some of today's most prevalent diseases, few of us have contemplated the economic value of progress against disease.

In this talk, Robert H. Topel and Kevin M. Murphy provide a short history of recent advances against these diseases and contemplate the value of possible future progress. Mortality from coronary artery disease, for example, has decreased in recent years, leading to an increase in longevity. Topel and Murphy examine the economic costs and benefits of this increase, as well as the issue of private versus public medical research.

Robert H. Topel is the Isidore Brown and Gladys J. Brown Professor in Urban and Labor Economics at the University of Chicago, where he began his career in 1979. He spent a year at UCLA (1985-86), and several years at RAND (1976-79). He has been a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research since 1981, serves on several journal editorial boards, and is the editor of the Journal of Political Economy. Topel received his Ph.D. from UCLA.

Kevin M. Murphy is the George Pratt Shultz Professor of Business Economics and Industrial Relations at the University of Chicago, an appointment he has held since 1993. He began his career at the University of Chicago in 1982 as a teaching associate after working for a short time in Santa Monica at the Unicon Research Corp. A recipient of numerous awards and honors, Murphy is the author of over 50 publications in the field of human capital. His Ph.D. is from the University of Chicago.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Robert H. Topel and Kevin M. Murphy, Graduate School of Business University of Chicago

Name: The Legacy of Communism and its Implications for the New Century
Description:
Communism, though defunct as a political system, has left its mark on Eastern and Central Europe in ways yet to be determined.

In this talk, T. Anthony Jones looks at the ways in which communism has affected the social and psychological makeup of the societies it once dominated, and also the implications of this for their future economic and political development.

Jones is associate director of The Gorbachev Foundation of North America, chair of the Department of Sociology and Anthropology of Northeastern University, and a Russian Research Center fellow at Harvard University. His research interests lie in the study of former socialist societies, with special emphasis on Russia. He currently is looking specifically at entrepreneurship and private enterprise. An accomplished author, Jones has written or edited over 15 books and numerous scholarly articles. He is also a sought-after speaker, having appeared before scores of academic and professional audiences.

Prior to coming to Northeastern, Jones was the associate chair of the Department of Sociology at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill and a lecturer at the University of Leicester. His Ph.D. is from Princeton.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
T. Anthony Jones, Associate Director
Gorbachev Foundation (Boston)

Name: America's High-Tech Economy: Growth Development and Risks for Metropolitan Areas
Description:
Most of us know that technology's impact on the U.S. economy is enormous. But what is less well-known is that high-tech is also having a major impact on the health of metropolitan economies across America - from the leader of all high-tech areas, the Silicon Valley, to many smaller cities like Albuquerque, N.M., that are taking advantage of the economic growth that comes with high-tech industries.

In this talk, Ross C. DeVol examines the importance that high-tech industries have in determining the relative economic performance of U.S. metropolitan areas, and he analyzes what lessons can be applied to the future - with special emphasis on Los Angeles and Orange Counties.

DeVol is Director of Regional and Demographic Studies at the Milken Institute and oversees the Institute's research efforts on the dynamics of comparative regional growth performance, focusing on their implications for economic, business, labor, and political leaders. In addition to the recent report, America's High-Tech Economy, DeVol has authored The Asian Crisis Tsunami: Trade and Other Impacts on California and the United States (September 1998).

Prior to coming to the Milken Institute, DeVol was senior vice president of WEFA, Inc. His M.A. in economics is from Ohio University.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Ross C. DeVol, Director of Regional and Demographic Studies at the Milken Institute

Name: Global Population: Development, Economic and Investment Implications
Description:
Recent decades have seen tremendous demographic turbulence. A major postwar baby boom was followed by a sizeable baby bust, which itself was followed by a muted echo of the original baby boom. Overlaying this massive shift in the age profile of the U.S. population have been incredible social changes.

Probabilities of first marriage are low and divorce rates remain high. Since 1986, the average American man or woman entering adulthood can expect to live the majority of their lifetime as an unmarried person, a major departure from the past.

All of these changes, in particular the maturation of the smaller baby-bust generation taking place in the United States today, imply that the future will be radically different from the past. Investment policies based on the economic relationships of the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s are likely to underperform, if not fail.

Richard Hokenson discusses the changing economic relationships both at home and abroad and their implications for investment worldwide. Hokenson is Chief Economist of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and a member of its Investment Policy Committee. Before coming to DLJ, he served as senior economist at both Merrill Lynch (1976 - 77) and Data Resources, Inc. (1973 - 76). From 1970 to 1973, he was a research associate at the University of Michigan's Research Seminar in Quantitative Economic. At DLJ, Hokenson is responsible for analysis and forecasts of economic and demographic trends and is author of DLJ Demographics: Profiles of a Changing Society as well as Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette's weekly economic publication, Economic Highlights.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Richard Hokenson, Chief Economist of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette

Name: The Future of Russia
Description:
When the Soviet Union was dissolved in 1991, Russia's economic prospects were hopeful. Yet, since that time, Russia's decline as been precipitous, culminating with its August 1998 default, devaluation, and the freezing of bank accounts. Michael Intriligator will examine what went wrong for Russia, where things now stand, and Russia's prospects for the future - as well as their implications for the rest of the world.

Michael Intriligator has been a member of the UCLA faculty since 1963 and joins the Milken Institute this yearyear as a Senior Fellow. He directed the Center for International Strategic Affairs, the predecessor to the Center for International Relations, from 1982 to 1992 and currently is a Professor of Economics, Political Science, and Policy Studies at UCLA.

Intriligator has authored or edited over 200 professional articles, books, and advanced texts in the areas of economic theory, econometrics, health economics, strategy and arms control, and Russia's transition to a market economy. His work on strategic affairs includes analyses of arms races, arms control, nuclear proliferation, and the nature of global security.

Intriligator currently is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the International Institute for Strategic Studies and has recently been appointed a Foreign Member of the Russian Academy of Sciences. His Ph.D. in Economics is from MIT.6408477304
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Michael D. Intriligator, Professor of Economics and Political Science
UCLA

Name: Icons of the Internet Economy
Description:
Most people familiar with the World Wide Web are also familiar with on-line leaders such as Amazon, eBay, and Charles Schwab. But what are the implications of these corporate successes for other businesses?

Kenneth Green examines how these and other less-well-known corporations are using the Internet to change and/or enhance conventional business practices. Their methods are affecting both the definition of markets and the delivery of products and services. They are also providing models for others as they reassess their missions, markets, and traditional organizational practices, policies, and procedures in light of this new technology.

Green is an expert on information technology, higher education, and their intersection with the business community. As director of The Campus Computing Project, Green heads the largest continuing study of the role of IT in U.S. colleges and universities and has published over three dozen books, research reports, and scholarly articles. His 1991 book Who's going to Run General Motors? What College Students Need to Learn Today to Become Business Leaders Tomorrow, co-authored with Daniel T. Seymour, is still described as a "must-read" for students, faculty, and corporate leaders.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers:
Kenneth Green,
Founder and Director of The Campus Computing Project

Name: The Economy, Politics, and the Peace Process in the Middle East
Description:
Former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres, in a visit to the Milken Institute, said diplomacy and military might are giving way to education and the economy as keys to the future of the Middle East.

Thanks to globalization, technological change and a new generation of Israelis and Arabs, the dynamics of the region are changing, he said.

"The nature of peace has changed," said Peres, Minister of Regional Development in the current government. "You cannot have any more diplomatic peace. You must have economic peace."

Peres was at the Institute to learn more about the Institute's research on the economy of Israel and the region. Over the past few years, the Milken Institute has engaged in research and development concerning financial innovations to assist in Israeli economic development.

During a roundtable discussion with a group of prominent local business executives and public officials, Peres told them that his generation - which built the modern Jewish state - is seeing major changes take place in the region.

"The whole landscape of leadership in the area is of an old age, irrelevant to a new epoch coming in our lives," he said. The new generation of Israeli's and Arabs is more worried about jobs and getting a good education than tanks and borders.

"They don't understand why they should be stopped at borders, why they should kill or be killed," Peres said. "What for? You cannot explain it to them."

The impetus behind these changes is globalization and technology, which Peres said has resulted in three separate economies:

*The Global Economy: This economy knows no borders or distance. There is a lot of competition, and only those with the most creative ideas and best technology will win, he said. "It is detached from geography, and connected entirely with science, technology and information."

*The Regional Economy: Israel's economic future is tied to its neighbors, so it's important to help them. "For our own existence, we must understand that we can't be an island of wealth in a sea of poverty, an island of cleanliness in a sea of pollution, or an island of security in a sea of violence and terror. Our interest in our neighbors is essential for our own existence."

*The National Economy: Education is the key to Israel's economic future, and the government is planning to spend much more on schools in the near future. "The country with the best education system will be the winning country," he said.

For the region to succeed, money must be spent wisely - on schools, infrastructure, tourism and other vital areas. It cannot continue to go to the same old sources decided upon by central governments. It needs to go to regional development and businesses, he said.

He cited Europe's planned spending of $6 billion in the Middle East as an example of good intentions gone bad, since the money will go to the same central governments that have received funds before, not to the needs of today's new economy.

"They're collecting money from the poor in the rich countries and giving it to the rich in poor countries," he said. Instead, the money should go to such critical needs as roads, water pipes, tourism and education.

"Give this money on a regional basis to every enterprise that wants to develop tourism, education, water and infrastructure," he said. "And the government will use its money for two purposes - to guarantee the investment and to reduce the cost of capital.

"Use the money for these purposes and you will change the Middle East," he said.

He added that it's important to build all economies in the region, Arab and Israeli alike.

"If they remain poor, we will not have peace," he said of Israel's neighbors. And, he added, "Peace will not be done in the police stations. It will be done at universities."
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Restructuring Regulation and Financial Institutions
Description:
On Monday, March 16, 1998, the Milken Institute hosted "Restructuring Regulation and Financial Institutions." This one-day conference presented the ideas of eight distinguished economists in sessions on banking, capital markets, mutual funds, pension funds, derivatives, insurance, government-sponsored enterprises, and systemic risks. Prominent discussants, including Nobel Laureate Merton Miller from the University of Chicago, discussed the papers presented.

Donald H. Straszheim, president of the Milken Institute, provided introductory remarks, and Institute chairman Michael Milken spoke at lunch.

As financial crises both at home and abroad highlight, the world's financial institutions face dynamic markets governed by a bewildering array of regulatory policies. This conference looked at the U.S. financial arena and placed each of the eight areas examined into an appropriate historical market and regulatory context. Presenters then examined what aspects of contemporary regulation either impede or enhance economic efficiency, and assessed what changes in regulatory policy are desirable. In addition, the conference addressed the influence of information technology on the future of financial markets.

Papers presented at the roundtable were later published in a book, Restructuring Regulation and Financial Institutions.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Health Care Venture Capital in the 21st Century
Description:
Amid the volatility in the markets over the past several months, there is renewed interest in health-care companies. Albert Waxman, who is recognized as one of the innovators in care management and health-care services, will present his unique perspective on this topic. He will discuss where venture capital for the health-care industry is flowing, and what sectors and companies are the ones to watch in the coming years.

Psilos Group is a New York City-based venture capital firm that specializes in investments in early-stage companies in e-health and health-care services, as well as new media and business-to-business e-commerce sectors.

Waxman is the firm's Founder and Senior Managing Member who focuses his investment activities at Psilos principally in health-care services and Internet-based health-care applications. He is also a director of several Psilos companies. Prior to founding Psilos, he was Chairman and CEO of Merit Behavioral Care until it was acquired by Magellan Health Services in 1998. Before that, Waxman served as President, Chairman and CEO of Diasonics, Inc., one of the first medical companies to provide ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging in the United States.

Waxman holds several U.S. and foreign patents for display, imaging and diagnostic technologies and products. He received his Master's and Doctoral degrees in electrical engineering and physics from Princeton University.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Albert Waxman, Founder and Senior Managing Member, Psilos Group Managers

Name: America's Choice on China: the Making of a Fateful Decision
Description:
The U.S. and China have a volatile relationship — an increasingly difficult one. It is deteriorating in the sense that elements of trust and goodwill are overshadowed, all too often and more heavily now, by these periods of alienation and disenchantment.

But we are not actually entering a period of some sort of colossal existential crisis. The Chinese are not the Soviets. They're not subverting half the world, they don't have armies all over Eastern Europe. They don't have any armies outside of their borders. They are not making any claims to ideological dominance of the world, as Marxism-Leninism used to do. The Chinese haven't done that for 30 years.

There is something much more mundane on the table: China's accession to the World Trade Organization.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
1250 Fourth Street (at Arizona)
Santa Monica, California 90401
Speakers: Robert Kapp President, United States-China Business Council

Name: Democratizing Capital in the United States
Description:
The starting point for this two-day symposium, "Democratizing Capital in U.S. History, Business, and Public Policy," was the question, What has happened to the goal of combining a capitalist economy with democracy? To answer this question the symposium explored converging themes in American history related to the democratization of capital. We examined from an historical perspective the notion that popular access to capital in a capitalist economy translates to democratic values in a polity. We also considered how that idea developed as the nation's social and economic structure changed from the 19th century to the present day.

The Issues

Two days of roundtable discussions addressed the question along several lines:

The history of capital access The ideal of a society of independent farmers, proprietors, and craftsmen - economically independent producers of wealth - was propounded from the time of the nation's founding through the mid-19th century. It was thought that the wide distribution of ownership of productive assets would form the basis for democratic participation. Could this goal of "democratic capitalism" survive the industrial revolution?

Populism and labor movements The 20th century arrived on a wave of progressive reforms as the needs of mass production drove capital into the hands of a few. Did the redistribution of wealth through the welfare state supply a new means of sharing capital broadly? What issues raised during the populist/progressive era resonate in today's policy debates?

Democratizing financial institutions Access to capital increased through the growth of finance and saving options. A.P. Giannini was one of the first bankers to lend to average citizens instead of just to corporations; he also invented the modern mortgage system, propelling home ownership. How did this focus on providing small-scale financial services to individual consumers impact American economic and political life?

Financial technologies How did 20th-century financial innovations - such as employee ownership of large corporations, greater access to funding for new businesses, and broader participation in the stock and bond markets - affect the role of Americans in the economy and in politics?

The New Deal and the Reagan era Roosevelt and Reagan entered office confronting dire economic challenges: the former, a credit crunch in tailspin; the latter, a stagnant economy and concentrated corporate power. How did the policies of these administrations compare and contrast in their prescriptions for recovery and growth?

Shared capitalism and ownership Could employee buyouts of corporations start a new trend in capitalism - or even eliminate the problem of struggle between owners and laborers? Will the merging of these roles bring about a peaceful democratization of capital in an industrial, technology-driven world? Will the political influence of workers and owners equalize?

Community capitalism How do institutions like community development banks empower the disenfranchised on a local basis?

Democratizing economic policy What policies can the U.S. government adopt to further develop all Americans' access to capital, and, in turn, meaningful participation in the political process?

The Sessions

The program for this small but important symposium consisted of seven roundtable discussions which addressed both historical developments in capital access and their policy implications in the present day. Also featured was a luncheon presentation on the democratization of capital and financial technologies.

The Audience

Our audience of approximately 100 included historians and practitioners in politics, economics, business, and labor as well as key policymakers and media.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Global Conference 2000
Description:
More than 1,000 leaders in business and finance, academia, public policy and media, joined a prestigious lineup of speakers at the third annual Milken Institute 2000 Global Conference.

The event opened Wednesday evening, March 8, with the Conference's signature event — a panel of Nobel Laureates in Economic Science moderated by Institute Chairman Michael Milken. It continued Thursday and Friday with more than two dozen panels on technology, economics, regional outlooks and much more.

This year's event was the Institute's biggest yet, with 27 panels over three days and more than 120 speakers, including some of the world's leading business and finance executives and scholars. The focus of this year's conference was technology and its impact on the way we do business.

The 2000 conference was our largest yet — with more than 1,400 institutional investors, business and financial leaders, academicians and senior government policy officials from all over the globe were in attendence.

Go to the program page to view panel summaries.
Venue:
The Beverly Hilton Hotel
Beverly Hills, California

Name: Examination of S&Ls Roundtable
Description:
What Can an Examination of S&Ls Reveal About Financial Institutions, Markets and Regulation?

Some 50 specialists in financial services gathered at the UCLA Faculty Center on January 25, 2002, to assess the lessons of the 1980s S&L mess for financial institutions, markets and regulation in the years ahead. The give and take at the invitation-only meeting, co-hosted by the Milken Institute and UCLA's Anderson School of Management, reflected the diverse backgrounds of the participants. Some argued that today's financial markets are in much better shape than they were 20 years ago, while others asserted that not nearly enough has been done to prevent future problems. The glass-is-half-full view was expressed most clearly by James Wilcox of the University of California's Haas School of Business. Among the lessons learned:

The value of diversification

We have seen what happens when institutions are not permitted to diversify their investments. Diversification across sectors, geographic regions and services, all make a difference.

The need for risk management

We now have a much better understanding of how much interest rate and credit risk are in the system, and how these risks can be handled. Financial institutions have more latitude to hedge now than they did 20 years ago.

The imperative for closure

Instead of letting firms try to grow out of problems, we should opt for "reincarnation" — reorganizing struggling institutions, bringing them back with different managers, different owners and perhaps different balance sheets. Other participants, including Susanne Trimbath of the Milken Institute, were less sanguine. In the long term, she noted, the share of U.S. financial assets held by banks and thrifts is falling. "We might well look to pension funds and mutual funds as the next set of institutions to become vulnerable if a conflict arises between asset classes and market conditions," she argued. A forced divestment of company stock from pension plans, for example, could leave those financial institutions vulnerable.

"Exactly the same things happened in Superior," a recently failed Chicago thrift, as happened in the 1980s, seconded George Kaufman of the Center for Financial Studies & Policy at Loyola University. Kaufman appends to Santayana's admonition that those who forget history are bound to repeat it.

"What do those who do remember do? They agonize first and then do it again."

To focus the discussion, the day included sessions on government policy, the public record, and the parallels in international banking. The final session summarized the day's discussion.

Government policy: were there unintended consequences?

Government policy left S&Ls vulnerable to shifting market forces, including interest rate volatility, deteriorating asset quality and increasing industry competition. "Public policy at the time included a rigid institutional design," explained Glenn Yago, director of capital studies at the Milken Institute. "That design inhibited the ability of S&Ls to adapt to technological developments, federal and state deregulation that came after the industry was in serious trouble, and tax law changes that weakened the financial condition of savings and loan institutions by adversely affecting real estate values."

Public record: was there fair and accurate coverage?

News coverage mediates society's understanding of events and often becomes the accepted history. The media frames the coverage, promoting certain issues as problematic, certain outcomes as undesirable, and certain strategies as inappropriate. In representing the S&L industry in the 1980s, it generally failed to go beyond terms like "crisis" and "bailout," which fit into 30-second sound bites. "Catch a crook" attracted more attention than how thrifts could fulfill their historical mission to "build a house."

Martin Regalia of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce reminded the conferees that "for the most part, newspapers are not the guardians or watchdogs of our society, but just another business trying to make a buck. And that is not all bad."

U.S. S&L experience: are there parallels in other countries?

The problems of financial institutions in the 1980s anticipated or paralleled those of other countries. When problems occur here, U.S. analysts prefer to look to unique circumstances or the failings of individuals. When problems occur elsewhere, they find systemic causes with simple solutions.

But what happened to the S&Ls was not so different from financial disruptions that occurred overseas both before and after the 1980s. For example, James Barth of the Milken Institute points out that "S&Ls were essentially directed toward the politically motivated investments in residential real estate." Equivalent policy-directed investments are common in other countries with state-owned or controlled financial systems.

Summing up: do S&Ls provide a useful perspective?

The 1980s witnessed the collision of vulnerable financial institutions with frenetic regulatory policy. An examination of the portfolios of institutions that invested in similar assets shows that the S&Ls were treated differently in a systematic way. Banks were underwater at the same time as thrifts, yet the banks were not closed. The seizure of S&L assets amounted to an extraordinarily large — perhaps the largest ever — nationalization of private assets. The S&L case was more visible than other examples of policy mixing poorly with markets because government deposit insurance put the S&Ls in a very visible position. Government- insured institutions were naturally subject to political competition over who was to blame for their demise. But looking below the surface, the similarities in these conflicts generally exceed the differences.

Future roundtables in the series will focus on different forms of financial institutions and different types of asset classes. The conferences will be represented in a book series from Kluwer Academic Publishers, the Milken Institute Series on Financial Innovation and Economic Growth.

The book from this event, The Savings and Loan Crisis: Lessons From a Regulatory Failure, is available through Kluwer Academic Publishers. Read summary.

Name: The New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD)
Description:
In a bid for international support and investments, representatives of the New Partnership for Africa's Development (NEPAD) outlined their hopes and goals for their continent in a special afternoon forum at the Milken Institute.

Nine prominent speakers, from the ambassador of the Republic of South Africa to Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Los Angeles, offered a litany of well-known challenges that face Africa, such as AIDS. But they also offered a good dose of optimism that NEPAD will finally do what other initiatives have failed to do: turn Africa around and put it on the path to sustainable economic development.

"We want to change things in Africa," said Dr. Cherif Salif Sy of Senegal, CEO of the NEPAD Steering Committee. "The time has arrived."

NEPAD was created in 2001 by African heads of state. It aims to bring African countries together to work toward common goals and objectives, and to unite the continent as an economic and trading bloc. Their goal is to create a stable economic platform benefiting both investors and African countries.

The Milken Institute Forum was one of a series of events held during the week by NEPAD supporters.

Lindiwe Hendricks, South Africa's Deputy Minister of Trade and Industry, told the audience that the key to NEPAD's future is that it was created by and for Africans. But, she added, it will take international support and partnerships to succeed.

Among the issues discussed were Africa's debt, health problems, foreign investment, economic growth and other challenges and opportunities.

Speakers:

•Ambassador Sheila Sisulu, Republic of South Africa Ambassador to the United States
•Rep. Maxine Waters, Member, House Committee on Financial Services
•Lindiwe Hendricks, Deputy Minister of Trade and Industry, Republic of South Africa
•Jeffrey Katz, Senior Economist and Manager, Partnerships and External Affairs Group for the Africa Region of the World Bank
•Richard McCormick, Executive Director, International Operations, SBC Communications
•Glaudine Mtshali, Consul-General of South Africa in Los Angeles and former Health Representative of South Africa to the United States
•Konji Sebati, Medical Director, International Philanthropy, Pfizer Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
•Cherif Salif Sy, CEO of the NEPAD Steering Committee

Read more about NEPAD.

blurb: In a bid for international support and investments, representatives of the New Partnership for Africa’s Development (NEPAD) outlined their hopes and goals for their continent.

Name: Milken Institute-CommerceNet Financial Technology and E-Markets Seminar
Description:
Attendees identified opportunities and issues that need to be addressed through research and development by both technology and financial professionals jointly.

In general, application of financial technology on the Internet is relatively unsophisticated. While we do find the first examples of auctions, exchanges, barter and simple market concepts, these examples have little of the sophistication (or liquidity) found in modern financial markets. Conversely, until the emergence of the Internet, opportunities to apply financial technology more broadly (taking technology from the financial community and applying it to non-financial markets) have been constrained. Recent advances in the evolution of Internet markets indicate that application of financial technologies to a new set of transactions holds significant promise for accelerating the evolution of electronic commerce.

Participants were an invited group of industry, academic, and policy experts whose backgrounds encompass a wide variety of expertise and approaches. Their efforts focused on issues, opportunities and problems in this area, communicating existing results and methods among these communities, and exploring the benefits of further collaboration, research and development.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: Milken Institute-CommerceNet Business Risk Management Roundtable
Description: This event assembled business, finance, manufacturing and policy-making leaders to discuss the impact and current and future use of financial risk management in non-financial markets. They sought to identify areas that need non-market intervention that would, in turn, advance and accelerate the use of sophisticated risk management tools and frameworks in intra-enterprise and inter-enterprise trading networks.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA
blurb: Business, finance, manufacturing and policy-making leaders discussed the impact and current and future use of financial risk management in non-financial markets.

Name: Tel-Aviv Jaffa Redevelopment Seminar
Description:
The Municipality of Tel Aviv, in an effort to move rapidly ahead on its Jaffa redevelopment project, sent Danny Kaiser (City Engineer of Tel Aviv) and Dror Amir (Jaffa "borough president") to Los Angeles the week of May 28-31, for Milken Institute briefings on innovative community development finance models, and visits to several LA sites. In addition to discussion on development models, presentations were made by Michael Frankel, Managing Director, Southern California Community Ventures; Richard Gentilucci, Senior Vice President, Shamrock Holdings; Gwen Pentecost, Sr. Administrative Analyst, City of Santa Monica regarding the Third Street Promenade revitalization project) and others.

Site visits included Pueblo Nuevo Development Court, FAME Rennaissance, Santee Court and and Playa Vista.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA

Name: 2001 California State of the State Conference
Description:
California, buffeted by electricity woes, the downturn in technology and the effects of a national recession, still remains a strong economic force with bright prospects for future growth, a group of business leaders, government officials and economists said at the third annual State of the State Conference.

In a sober but upbeat assessment of the state's future, speakers said the current economic downturn will last for several quarters, but expressed confidence that Cal

"While we do have a bumpy road ahead of us - probably for the next 10 to 12 months - confidence, innovation, immigrant spirit and just the courage and resolve to see our way through this will get us through," said Gov. Gray Davis, who gave a special afternoon presentation. Ifornia will come out of it in the second-half of 2002.

More than 400 business and financial leaders, government officials, economists and media attended the day-long event that focused on some of the state's key assets - its diversity, technological prowess, entertainment industry and entrepreneurial talent - while also pointing out the need to solve some long-standing problems such as housing costs and energy needs.

State Treasurer Philip Angelides, the conference's keynote speaker, summed up the day's outlook by telling the audience about the many challenges facing the state today because of the recession and September 11 terrorist attacks that have turned the state's budget surplus into a deficit of between $8 billion and $14 billion, but emphasizing that they are only temporary roadblocks.

"Despite our current challenges, I believe we are on the verge of a great era in California, which will secure our preeminence in the global marketplace - if we approach these times of stress with confidence and vision," Angelides said. "I believe we can sustain the California dream in the 21st century if we summon the strength at this time of crisis to invest anew in our economy and our people."

The day included sessions on energy, entertainment, demography, Internet and financing, and ended with a special Q & A with the audience and Milken Institute economists.
