Name: Springboard Enterprises Bootcamp
Description:
As part of its ongoing efforts to support programs for entrepreneurs and encourage investment in markets that stimulate the economy, the Milken Institute hosted a workshop by Springboard Enterprises on Dec. 5, designed to prepare and connect women-led businesses to investors in the equity capital markets.

The in-depth, one-day "BootCamp" brought together more than 50 women entrepreneurs and local business people to talk about how to raise needed capital for their growing firms. It included a talk by Katrina Garnett, founder of CrossWorlds Software, case studies, panel discussions with leading industry experts and a fast-pitch session highlighting four local entrepreneurs.

Garnett, Managing Director of Garnett Capital, opened the program. She drew from her own inspiring story to illustrate to the audience how to map out their course, detect opportunity to create a new space in the marketplace, stay afloat financially and be flexible when the need arises. Her key pieces of advice were to file patents early on and find the right niche. She also discussed the importance of educating the market about your company's product and knowing how to use the media. Other key points: raise money before you need it, know everyone — customers, analysts and vendors — and let your customers speak for your brand to bring you credibility. In sum, she said, know your vision, execute in phases and have an exit strategy.

Don Fracchia of Wells Fargo Bank spoke about raising capital in general terms. Wells Fargo has long been a small-business friendly bank, said Fracchia, and he advised the attendees to show discipline, focus and have a plan beyond their entrepreneurial vision and passion.

Three brass-tacks panels filled the next several hours. The first, moderated by Betsy Zeidman, head of the Milken Institute's Emerging Domestic Markets Program, discussed the key elements of a growth business. The panelists represented venture capital, banking, law and accounting, and included a former Springboard participant. They discussed financing models and how to assess the competition so that your product stands out above the rest. Their key points: analyze and evaluate the competition as well as barriers to sale, bring in a team that can execute and be credible.

The next panel took it one step further: doing the deal. The panelists focused on due diligence, good connections and good corporate housekeeping. They touched on the structure of different deals and stressed the importance of knowing which fund is the right one for your business. Most of all, they agreed, be patient.

The lunch session, moderated by the Milken Institute's Director of Capital Studies, Glenn Yago, discussed today's economic realities — investors are now looking for companies with high margins, typically 45 to 65 percent, with experienced management teams. The definition of "early stage" financing has migrated upward and investors expect significant milestones before considering a firm. Again, infrastructure, a solid business base and good corporate governance were at the forefront. But investors are still interested in good ideas and consumer product companies. When it came to where the capital would come from, a common theme emerged: match your company's needs with the right fund.

The day then shifted from panel discussions to a case study of a successful woman-led firm, SatisFusion, presented by its chairman, Fay Wood. She was followed by four fast pitches presented by local entrepreneurs who were treated to feedback by a panel of investors.

For more information about its programs, visit the Springboard Enterprises web site.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA
blurb: Designed to prepare and connect women-led businesses to investors in the equity capital markets, this in-depth, one-day “BootCamp” brought together women entrepreneurs and local businesspeople to talk about how to raise needed capital for their growing firms.

Name: Education's Challenge: The Jobs Skills Mismatch
Description:
The Milken Family Foundation's National Education Conference examined significant issues in education, and provided an opportunity for honorees to share their ideas with one another and with other distinguished representatives from academia, government, business, and local communities. The event culminated with the recognition of K-12 educators from across the United States for their teaching, leadership, and contribution to the healthy development of children.

As its part of the conference, the Milken Institute held a panel discussion Friday, June 26, "Education's Challenge: The Jobs and Skills Mismatch," that examined the disparity between the skills of the labor force and the requirements of today's job market. Institute Chairman Michael Milken moderated.

The Issues

The American economy has undergone extraordinary change over the last decade, driven by technology and global competition. With some industries expanding rapidly while others are contracting, the consequences for labor markets and our educational system are profound. Technology is at the heart of a growing mismatch between the skills possessed by our labor force and the mix of skills demanded by employers. What is to be made of this?

The program consisted of two sessions:

The Professionals' Perspective. This session, which featured experts who study education and labor, looked at how our education system is serving the changing needs of the American economy.

The answer? Not as well as it must if American companies are going to successfully compete in the 21st century global market.

Today's workplace is changing so rapidly, that even in today's strong U.S. economy, companies are going begging for skilled, talented workers. One of the critical problems is that many people don't have the skills necessary to succeed in today's "knowledge economy," which values skills like problem solving and communication much more highly than ever, they said.

"The new economy is knowledge-biased," said James O'Connell, Vice President of government relations and human resources policy for the Ceridian Corp. "It gives tremendous advantage to those who have knowledge and a tremendous disadvantage to those who don't. In this economy, knowledge is power."

Laurie Bassi, Vice President for research at the American Society for Training and Development, agreed. "We are now well into the 'knowledge' era, and in this era, it is human capital that defines privilege and wealth, and the absence of human capital that defines poverty," she said.

Bassi presented a chart showing the work attributes that are "in" and "out" in today's workplace. On the list of "ins" were: brains, mental dexterity, access to memory and integration of skills and tasks. On the "out" list were: brawn, manual dexterity, memorization and compartmentalization. "What we need is an education system that is defined by the attributes on the 'in' list," she said. "What worked well in education for hundreds of years for the majority of people who would become the workforce is now a detriment, not an asset."

She and other panelists told the hundreds of educators gathered for the talk that they must change the way they teach if young people are going to succeed. The panelists stressed that traditional fact-based, test-taking classrooms won't help students when it comes time to get jobs in the new workplace.

"Both current entry-level and future entry-level employees need to be intelligent, skilled, thoughtful, able to problem-solve, able to communicate with each other and be able to work together in teams," said Michael Templeton, a consultant in science learning.

Richard McGahey, Assistant Secretary for Policy for the U.S. Department of Labor, told the gathering that jobs are changing so fast today that even in industries such as auto making, the skills required are dramatically different than in years past. "Fewer than half of the high school graduates in the United States currently have the mathematics skills to get a job in an auto plant," he said.

Milken Institute Economist Alec Levenson said many people in the U.S. today don't have the basic skills necessary for such things as locating an intersection on a street map or using a calculator. These workers must be given a proper foundation of reading, writing and math. Without that, the more critical skills needed in today's economy won't be possible.

Slides were presented showing how rapidly jobs are changing in the world today, with some of today's growth leaders being the computer industry, pharmaceutical companies and financial firms. The point, said Donald Straszheim, president of the Institute, is that, "Not only do the employers change, but the nature of the jobs change as well. That's the constant challenge of the whole education system."

The Practitioners' Perspective. This session looked at the problem from the business sector's point of view.

They had two key messages:

One, companies are desperate for intelligent, professional workers with strong people skills, technological skills and the ability to think independently and creatively in the work environment.

Two, businesses must work with educators to create a plan for teaching students so they will have the skills necessary in the changing workplace.

Roger Brossy, of Sibson & Co. said three areas in particular cause great concern to businesses today: 1. They cannot find enough qualified individuals to handle technological matters, such as writing code or computer programs. 2. The service sector cannot find enough good workers. And 3. They cannot find enough talented executives. "The best performing companies today are paranoid that they have an insufficient level of executive talent," Brossy said. That's one reason the search business, or executive head-hunters, has grown by 550 percent in the past 15 years, he said.

Jerry Jasinowski, President/CEO of the National Association of Manufacturers, said among his members, training employees to handle work in the "knowledge" economy is the number one priority. "If we want to continue on the successful growth path, we have to elevate the quality of knowledge within our people to a higher level than it is," he said.

What's critical, said Ray Marcy, Chairman, President and CEO of Interim Services Inc., is "how we educate, not just what we educate."

Sharon Feldman, vice president of employee relations at Warner Bros., said the skills that her company and other businesses need are simple: workers must have basic reading, writing and math skills; must be computer literate; must be able to assimilate into the corporate culture; and be a team player.

The second part of the discussion focused on what government and businesses can do to help educators.

George McCrary, workforce development manager at Wal-Mart Stores, said his company has a policy that every store must adopt a school and work as partners with educators. He urged the educators in the room to go back home and contact their local Wal-Mart store manager to set up a program with their schools.

Karl Chapman, founder and chief executive of Spring Group PLC, said in England the government made improving schools and workers' skills a priority. Teacher training, the ability to close poor schools and the creation of "learning accounts" that allow people to take out loans during their lifetimes to retrain are just a few of the things that country is doing.
Venue:
Milken Family Foundation National Education Conference
Century Plaza Hotel
Los Angeles, California

Name: Financing our Global Environmental Future
Description:
The world spends billions of dollars each year to protect the environment. But despite these efforts, ecosystems continue to be lost in record numbers.

In an effort to stem these losses, the Milken Institute, United Nations Foundation and The Nature Conservancy have embarked on a unique partnership to work on finding solutions to environmental problems using financial innovations.

On March 22, 2001, the three organizations co-sponsored a one-day conference in Beverly Hills, CA, "Financing Our Global Environmental Future," which focused on how to use financial markets to save the world′s rain forests, coral reefs and other ecosystems.

The conference brought together more than 75 business, financial and environmental leaders in a series of panel discussions, speeches and breakout sessions that explored everything from carbon credits markets to equity funds for environmentally sensitive companies.

The attendees offered an optimistic, albeit tempered, view of the possibilities of using finance to benefit nature.

"We have no choice but to protect the planet," said Institute Chairman Michael Milken. The question is, "How do we pay for it? Those who find the solution will reap the financial rewards."

Timothy E. Wirth, President of the UN Foundation and a former U.S. senator from Colorado, said a lot of progress has been made in saving the world′s ecosystems. But that progress has not kept up with the ongoing destruction of the world′s bio assets.

"We′re never going to get there unless we figure out how to bring financial technologies to bear on these problems," he said.

The Milken Institute is an expert in using financial innovations to help solve public policy problems. Coupled with the UN Foundation′s global reach and The Nature Conservancy′s strong environmental credentials, the three organizations offer a strong partnership in finding new ways to save environmentally sensitive areas through financial incentives.

Throughout the day, attendees pointed to many of the successes they′ve had, such as eco-tourism, environmentally friendly equity funds and "green" products that don′t hurt nature.

But the biggest problem, they said, is figuring out how to pay for the effort. Although some have pegged the worth of the earth′s biosphere at $33 trillion, only a tiny fraction of that is spent trying to save it.

Figuring out a price for the world′s ecosystems — and then coming up with ways to make money that can be used to save them — is "the holy grail" of this effort, said Ricardo Bayon, a fellow at the New America Foundation.

"We′re still early in our understanding of what these forests provide," said Michael Jenkins, executive director of Forest Trends, "so it′s hard to create markets for them."

Added Stanford University biologist Gretchen Daily: "What′s the value to society to invest in a piece of the coast?"

In addition, some of the world′s most valuable ecosystems are government property, or in such countries as Cambodia or Myanmar, where investors won′t go.

On the more optimistic side, Michael Walsh, senior vice president of Environmental Financial Products, said initiatives such as carbon credits markets — where a "clean" company can sell its emission allotment to others, while overall pollution limits are lowered — show that the idea of using financial markets to save the environment can work.

"We are really turning some corners here," he said.

The three organizations plan further meetings to continue the dialogue and create concrete proposals to help solve environmental problems using financial tools.

• View the keynote speech by California State Treasurer Philip Angelides.
• View an edited transcript of the concluding panel discussion moderated by Michael Milken, with concluding remarks from Timothy Wirth.
• To view a presentation given by Dan Janzen, Professor of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, about ways to use wildland biodiversity without damaging it, visit his web site.

Two papers were written for this conference:

• Financial Global Environmental Futures, by Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Studies, the Milken Institute
• Innovating Environmental Finance, by Richardo Bayon.

Name: Privatization and Capital Market Reforms
Description:
Privatization and Capital Market Reforms

Milken Institute and Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs

On September 19, 2000, the Jerusalem Center and the Milken Institute sponsored a closed forum for experts on capital market reform.

As a prerequisite for privatization, it is necessary to reform the capital market to enable the raising of funds from the public or investment companies to privatize government-owned companies or services.

Moderated by Prof. Ben-Zion Zilberfarb and Dr. Glenn Yago, the forum included the following presentations:

Dr. Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Market Studies, Milken Institute, "Capital Access and Economic Growth"

Prof. Yaakov Ne'eman, Former Finance Minister, "Factors Impinging Upon Privatization Policy"

Yaron Jacobs, Director General, Government Corporations Authority, "Privatization of State-Owned Enterprises"

Dr. Asher Blass, Chief Economist, Bank of Israel, "Cost of Existing Pension Fund Arrangements"

Dr. Eyal Sulgenik, Chief Examiner, Israel Securities Authority, "Capital Market Reform: Survey, Analysis, and Implications"

Adi Rivlin, Deputy Minister for Capital Markets, Finance Ministry, "Improving Demand and Supply in the Capital Markets"

Prof. Ben-Zion Zilberfarb, Former Director General, Finance Ministry, "Capital Market Regulation"

Privatization and Capital Market Reforms is available through the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs. Order.

Name: Privatization in Local Government: Ashkelon and other Municipalitites
Description:
On June 13-14, 2001, a conference was held in Ashkelon on Privatization in Local Government: Models and Lessons, cosponsored by the Koret Foundation, the City of Ashkelon, the Economic Corporation of Ashkelon, and the Milken Institute, to discuss successful privatization efforts in that city and the growing experience with privatization in other Israeli municipalities.

This conference presented an opportunity to present working examples of privatization and allowed those in attendance to learn from the practical models which were presented, and from the experience of other local authorities represented at the conference as well. Some 90 participants came together over two days to discuss the current experience of Israeli local authorities with outsourcing and joint ventures with private companies, in a venue which afforded them a unique opportunity to exchange information.

Conference participants included:

  • Shmuel Bar Lev, Head of Katzrin Local Council, Golan Heights
  • Noa Ben Arye, Esq., Chief Counsel, Union of Local Authorities
  • Avraham Ben David, Director General, City of Ashkelon
  • Amihai Ben Dror, Director, Municipal Policy Unit, Union of Local Authorities

  • Yaakov Efrati, Director General, Ministry of Infrastructure
  • Hillel Granot, Director General, Petach Tikva Economic Development Corporation

  • Yehoshua Hazenpertz, Accountant, Schiff, Hazenpertz and Associates

  • Hagai Shefer, Director General, Milgam Urban Services
  • Haim Turgeman, Director General, Ashkelon Economic Corporation
  • Benny Vaknin, Mayor of Ashkelon
  • Prof. Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Studies, Milken Institute, Los Angeles
  • Prof. Ben Zion Zilberfarb, former Director General, Ministry of Finance

Name: Privatization: Alternative Financing for Urban Infrastructure
Description:
The Jerusalem Center cosponsored a conference in Tel Aviv on September 13, 2000, on "Alternative Financing of Urban Infrastructure: The Habimah Parking Structure Project," together with the Milken Institute, Tel Aviv University, and the City of Tel Aviv-Yafo. A few months later the Habimah Theater parking structure was chosen as the first-ever "pilot" project in Israel for the issuance of municipal bonds. If successful, this practice may be adopted by other municipalities and could herald a real revolution in the expansion of financial resources for local authorities.

The presentations included:

  • Robert P. Feyer, Bond Counsel at Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe LLP, "Outline of Legal Considerations for Parking Revenue Financing"
  • Michael A. Freed, American Capital Access Financial Guaranty Corporation, "Improved Access to Capital through Bond Insurance"
  • Stanley Gold, President of Shamrock Holdings, Chairman of Tadiran Communications, and former Chairman of Koor Industries, "Alternative Urban Economic Development: Lessons from the U.S."
  • Ariel Kappon, Director General of the City of Tel-Aviv-Yafo, "Tel Aviv-Yafo Development Projects"
  • Miri Katz, Chairperson of the Israel Securities Authority, "Issuing Municipal Bonds in Local Authorities"
  • Anat Keinan, Chief Financial Officer of the City of Tel-Aviv-Yafo, "Sources of Finance for Urban Development"
  • Ron Lubash, Managing Director of the Israel Group of the Investment Banking Division of Lehman Brothers international bank, "Municipal Revenue Bonds for Parking Facilities"
  • Dror Nagel, General Manager of Gmulot Ltd., "Municipal Bonds as an Investment Option"
  • Fruma Narov, Senior Vice President of Urbitran Associates civil engineering, "Parking Facility Feasibility: The American Experience"
  • Dorit Salinger, General Manager of Maalot, The Israel Securities Rating Company Ltd., "Examining the Possibility of Grading the Habimah Parking Facility"
  • Prof. Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Studies at the Milken Institute, "Alternative Financial Structures"
  • Ronen Zelnir, Managing Director of IBI Underwriting & Investments Ltd., "How Do You Market Them?"

Name: Privatization and Increasing Competition in the Israeli Economy
Description:
On October 10-12, 1999, the Jerusalem Center and the Milken Institute sponsored a closed forum for experts on "Privatization and Increasing Competition in the Israeli Economy." The widely lauded forum looked at such topics as capital market reforms, municipal and local reforms, and decentralizing the peace process.

The proceedings of the conference were published in Hebrew for an Israeli audience in the volume Privatization and Increasing Competition in the Israeli Economy. ([JCPA and the Milken Institute, 2000] 157 pp. in Hebrew and 82 pp. in English; Softcover $12 - NIS 40)

Participants included:

  • Dr. Asher Blass of the Research Department of the Bank of Israel
  • Yaakov Efrati, Director General, Ministry of Infrastructure and former Director General, Ministry of Interior
  • JCPA Fellow Manfred Gerstenfeld
  • Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, a leading innovator in the privatization of municipal services in America
  • Eran Goren, CEO of Nessuah Zannex Ltd.
  • Mayor Gabi Kadosh of Eilat
  • MK Nachum Langenthal, former Director General, Ministry of Transportation
  • Sassi Shilo, Acting Director General, Economics Company, Israel Union of Local Authorities
  • Arnon Tiberg, Director General, Delta Galil Industries Ltd.
  • Stef Wertheimer, Chairman, Iscar Ltd.
  • Dr. Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Market Studies at the Milken Institute

The forum was under the academic direction of Professor Ben-Zion Zilberfarb, former Director General of the Ministry of Finance.

Name: Practical Privatization: Lessons from Cities and Markets
Description:
On June 18, 1998, the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs and the Milken Institute held a conference in Jerusalem on Practical Privatization in Local Government, bringing together a distinguished group of Israeli officials and American experts including the Prime Minister and Finance Minister of Israel, and the Mayor of Indianapolis. The proceedings of the conference were published in Hebrew for an Israeli audience in the volume Practical Privatization: Lessons from Cities and Markets, which outlines how outsourcing and privatization can be used by Israel's local authorities to improve their ability to deliver quality services to their residents at lower cost. The conference examined the U.S. experience with privatization in various cities in light of the ongoing effort in Israel to decrease public-sector involvement in its cities.

Among the speakers were Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israeli Finance Minister Ya'akov Ne'eman, Indianapolis Mayor Stephen Goldsmith, and representatives of the finance and investment sectors. More than 200 people attended, including representatives from most of Israel's major cities, as well as scholars, government economic officials and business leaders.

The morning session focused on privatization experience and theory. The afternoon portion featured specialized sessions on water and water treatment, infrastructure finance and projects, and municipal services.

The conference was a follow-up to a November symposium on Israel's economic future held at the Milken Institute. The Jerusalem conference was organized in conjunction with the Office of the Mayor, City of Indianapolis; the Israeli Economic Commission; and the Consulate of Israel on behalf of the Israeli Ministry of Finance and the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs.

For related information on Israel's economy, see the Milken Institute's Israel Briefing Book.

Name: Shimon Peres, Nobel Laureate, former Prime Minister of Israel
Description:
The war against terrorists is unlike any war in history, and defeating them requires a much different strategy than ever before — one that involves technology, economics and law as well as military might, said Shimon Peres, Nobel Laureate and former Prime Minister of Israel.

Speaking to a group of 70 Los Angeles business leaders in a special forum held for members of the Milken Institute Associates, Peres outlined four major events that must be addressed in the coming decade to avert global disaster: confrontation with terrorists, resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, environmental decline and the development of nanotechnology.

Today's primary danger is confrontation with terrorists, said Peres. Terrorism requires cooperation, and without exception, the countries that harbor terrorists are dictatorships that lack transparency, courts of law and equal rights for women. What is the best weapon for fighting terrorism? Peres' answer: technology. As proof that technology forces nations to change, Peres pointed to China. Nothing, he said, could have changed the communist nature of China but technology. Terrorist-friendly countries lack technology because that type of investment requires an environment of values, transparency and openness. The war against terror is a "nonclassical war," Peres said, without frontiers. No one, he asserted — Chinese, Russian, Israeli or American — can live in a world in which it is a danger to fly in a plane, drink the water or breathe the air.

Another element of the dangers that face the world today is the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. "There is a new theater of war — the Middle East," Peres said. To diffuse this requires a resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The good news, he pointed out, is that the solution is clear, and there is sufficient support among the Palestinian people, the United States and most of Europe to make it happen: replace Arafat — a dictator — with a legitimate government of legitimate ministers, a real government structure and a transparent economy. Why hasn't there been a single suicide bomber from Jordan, whose population is more than 80 percent Palestinian, Peres asked. Because Jordan has a legitimately elected government, its citizens do not feel oppressed. Peres said this change must occur as early as 2005 to avoid a greater regional war.

The third major event the world must address in the next decade is the environmental problem, one that Peres described as a social and political one. As long as poor countries are forced to strip their lands of natural resources to put food in their stomachs, severe and irreparable climate alterations will continue. By destroying the balance of nature, he said, we are inviting disaster. Rich countries must come to terms with poor countries to stabilize the environment.

The final major event that Peres considers so significant that he views it as "a new dimension" is the development of nanotechnology — the art of manipulating materials on an atomic or molecular scale. All other technology pales in comparison, he stated. Peres urged governments to use this technology, and atomic energy, constructively.

The confrontation against terror, Peres concluded, is not a Jewish-Moslem problem. It is a conflict of freedom versus oppression. Countries that lack freedom sow terror. The democratization of these nations is terrorism's greatest threat. Technology and the media are instrumental in making this change come about because they bring the free world into these same countries.

"I am accused in my country of being an optimist," he said. "But I have never met a pessimist who discovered a star…. Or built a factory."

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.
blurb: Shimon Peres describes the war on terrorism, the Israel-Palestinian conflict, environmental degradation and advancements in nanotechnology as the four major events facing the world over the next 10 years.

Name: "Off the Record" with LAPD Chief William Bratton
Description:
Los Angeles Police Chief William Bratton, speaking at a private meeting with members of the Milken Institute Associates, said he is trying to change the culture and size of the department so that he can deal with three major issues:

  • implement the consent decree to reform the police department;
  • reduce violent crime, particularly gang crime; and
  • address terrorism and employ preventive measures.
To be successful, he said, the city needs a bigger police department — now at about 9,200 sworn officers, the smallest of the country's major cities — and a greater sense of urgency in getting things done.

"Too few for too long had been asked to do too much with too little," Bratton said. "The ultimate challenge is to change a culture than has been resistant to change."

Bratton, the former police commissioner of Boston and New York City who was appointed LAPD chief in October 2002 by Mayor James Hahn, conceded that changing such a large bureaucracy is not easy, especially in a city as diverse and complex as Los Angeles. But he is "cautiously optimistic" about succeeding.

The meeting is one of a series that allows members of the Associates to meet privately with local, national and international leaders.

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: The Challenges of the Quartet Road Map and the Role of Saudi Arabia
Description:
Ambassador Dore Gold addressed a Milken Institute Forum in which he discussed the Quartet Road Map to Peace, so-called for the four governing bodies guiding the current negotiations — the U.S., the U.N. Secretariat, the former Soviet Union and the E.U.

Gold began by outlining three elements that formed the basis for the current effort:

  • Unequivocal evidence of the link between the Palestinian Authority and terrorism, calling for new leadership.
  • An immediate, unarmed cease fire ending terror against Israeli civilians before the start of negotiations.
  • The ultimate establishment of a Palestinian state.

    • Commenting on the PA's "new" leadership, he pointed out that of the 25 members of the Palestinian Parliament, only four are loyal to Abu Mazzen, the Palestinian Authority's recently appointed Prime Minister while 21 remain loyal to Arafat. Abu Mazzen controls one security service, while Arafat remains in command of eight security services.

    Gold also noted that while there is a clear consensus among Palestinians about the meaning of "peace," that being a Palestinian state, Israelis have been less articulate about their understanding beyond a "safe" peace. Gold stressed the importance of articulating clear concrete goals in Israel's negotiations and suggested three: one undivided Jerusalem with Israel as sovereign, secure, defensible borders, no "right of return" for Palestinians with immediate disbandment of refugee camps and absorption of those Palestinians into the countries in which they reside.

    Another important issue that Gold focused on in his discussion was that Israel had, in fact, complied with U.N. Resolution 242 in 2000 when it ended its military occupation and withdrew its forces, placing the Palestinian Authority in charge of 98% of West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

    Other topics discussed by Gold:

  • A halt to support of terrorist groups by Arab states, specifically noting Saudi Arabia's assistance to Hamas and its importance to improving the security of the U.S.;
  • Investment in Palestinian infrastructure by Egypt and Jordan;
  • An end to incitement, which he described as "motivation for terror," calling it the first step in moving toward peace and "an essential issue to resolve."

    • Ambassador Dore Gold is President of the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs. He was the eleventh Permanent Representative of Israel to the United Nations and served as Foreign Policy Advisor to former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He was also a member of the Israeli negotiating team at Wye River. Ambassador Gold is the author of Hatred's Kingdom: How Saudi Arabia Supports the New Global Terrorism.
Venue: Milken Institute, 1250 Fourth St., Santa Monica, CA
Speakers: Ambassador Dore Gold, President, Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs
blurb: Dore Gold, former Israeli ambassador to the United Nations, discussed recent developments in the prospects for peace in the Middle East.

Name: To The Promised Land: Immigrants in California and Israel
Description:
Despite the strains and responsibilities that immigration imposes on a country, the overall economic and social benefits are positive, participants in the second annual "To The Promised Land: Immigrants in California and Israel" conference concluded.

But to ease immigrants' absorption into their new country, and maximize the benefits earlier on, government must change its policies to reflect regional needs, as well as clarify immigrants' rights and responsibilities, participants agreed.

In a unique gathering of more than 100 scholars and businesspeople from the Latino and Israeli communities, the conference — hosted by the Milken Institute, in conjunction with the Consulate General of Israel, The Tomás Rivera Policy Institute and the Jewish Federation Community Relations Committee — examined the economic, political, cultural and demographic effects of immigration on California and Israel, and the common challenges they pose.

Following opening remarks by Los Angeles Councilman Joel Weiss and Los Angeles City Attorney Rocky Delgadillo, attendees attended four panel sessions:

The Politics of Absorption: Immigration and our Political Sphere compared the influence of politics and voting rights on immigrants' acclimation to their new homes. In the early American and Israeli experiences, political parties organized immigrant groups, providing them with basic services such as health care, housing, jobs and education. As a result, immigrants often joined the political party that shepherded them in their early days. In the U.S., however, the right to vote that comes with naturalization takes a minimum of five years, enough time for loyalties to subside or for indifference to set in, diluting their influence. In Israel, the right to vote is immediate, but that carries its own risks, such as whether the Israeli political scene is unduly influenced by people from other countries not yet socialized to Israel's way of life.

The Mechanism of Absorption: The Role of Government focused on the benefits that come with integration — economic stimulation, civic participation, public safety - and policies that can help accelerate newcomers' entry into the community. Panelists noted that government policies and societal needs were often in conflict (e.g. exclusion from job training vs. the labor needs of the region), and that they needed to be brought in alignment. The state can help promote democracy by helping immigrants fulfill their responsibilities - to work, speak the language, pay taxes and participate in civic responsibilities. Panelists added, however, that jobs, not policy, draw people to a particular region.

Melting Pot or Mosaic? Identity and Immigration addressed the impact of global immigration on society over generations. Panelists agreed that the same model did not apply to European and Latino immigrants. These groups had very different immigration and absorption experiences, ultimately creating a "salad bowl" of people combining their American and ancestral identities. While "the most successful immigrants disappeared into the landscape," noted Moctesuma Esparza, many second- and third-generation Americans turn around to reclaim their history and create an entirely new identity.

The Bottom Line: Economic Benefits and Costs of Immigration Immigration has a positive net effect on the economy as immigrants buy homes and businesses, panelists said. In the U.S. and in Israel, homeownership is seen as perhaps the most significant aspect in integrating immigrants into their communities and society. Access to capital gives immigrants a stake in the community. Homeownership, always widespread among immigrants in Israeli, where special mortgages are available to newcomers, is expanding among Latinos in the United States as well. New immigrants also bring with them new knowledge and skills. When there is a common vision, these elements converge to create a strong society, panelists said.

Closing Plenary Speakers compared and contrasted the Israeli and Latino experiences. They offered lessons from the past and ideas for improving those experiences, both for immigrants and the community at large. Education and inclusion in the political process were cited as focal points for making the immigration process a successful one for all parties. Zvi Vapni of the Consulate General of Israel concluded, "The big picture is unquestionably positive, despite great challenges and adversity."
blurb: Despite the strains and responsibilities that immigration imposes on a country, the overall economic and social benefits are positive, participants concluded.

Name: Saving Capitalism from the Capitalists
Description:
While cautioning that good government is an essential part of a successful capitalistic system, Raghuram Rajan defended globalization, open trade and free markets as the best way to eliminate poverty.

Addressing some 200 people at a Milken Institute Forum, Rajan summed up the concepts laid out in his book, Saving Capitalism from the Capitalists: Unleashing the Power of Financial Markets to Create Wealth and Spread Opportunity. He began with the three key points that he and his co-author, Luigi Zingales, make in their book:

(1) Markets give the poor the promise of mobility. Truly free markets, Rajan said, "are the single most important tools to eliminate poverty and spread opportunity."
(2) Markets need good government. When there is too little of the right kind of government, he asserted, markets work poorly, adding that the force of globalization is making governments more market-friendly.
(3) Markets are fragile and even free-market societies should not be complacent. The best protection for fragile markets, Rajan said, is awareness of what can go wrong. Raising that awareness was the goal that he and his co-author hoped to accomplish in writing their book.

Citing an example of what could go wrong in capitalism, Rajan claimed that what many decry as capitalism's exploitation of the poor is in fact a failure of capitalism because the poor do not have access to cheap financing. Access to financing, he stated, enables the realization of dreams.

Why are countries poor? Because they lack the underlying infrastructure — good accounting, corporate governance, etc. — that make financial systems work. Why, then, don't they have functioning systems? Rajan said the perception of those in power is that improving the system will not serve them, thus they do not have the incentives to push for better infrastructure. Having risen to power under a particular system, incumbent capitalists block improvements because freer access to finance and competition would unseat many of them while fostering the widespread prosperity they espouse.

Well-functioning capitalism requires a "Goldilocks government," that is, something in the middle, Rajan said. The capitalist system needs both a well-developed government infrastructure and a business environment that promotes competition. How do you get governments to work for the common good and expand capital markets? By making those in power see that it's in their interest to become more pro-market rather than to block their development.

Rajan believes that this is happening "quietly" through globalization. He gave the example of India's post-revolution government, which at the time controlled all production in the country. Shielded from competition, there was no incentive to change, or improve. The quality of goods produced by India's manufacturing sector was abysmal. In the 1990s, following the example of China, India allowed foreign manufacturers into the country and the quality of production among Indian companies markedly improved. This, he said, has led to the elite pushing reform in favor of the common good. Awake now to the high quality of goods available in the marketplace, a consumer revolution is taking place in India, being financed by what Rajan described as a "creaky" financial system that must be improved.

On the issue of outsourcing, Rajan explained that in the long run, foreign outsourcing benefits both countries. Citing the example of U.S. efforts to block the outsourcing of steel production, he observed that it protected a few jobs short term but raised the price of American automobiles, hurting that industry and sending consumers to foreign-made cars. Ultimately, he said, there is no partial protection. Stopping outsourcing decreases the level of entrepreneurship, closes a country's doors and closes its economy. This happened here in the 1930s, and he warned that it could happen again.

"Multinationals do improve lives in other countries," he said. While today there may be inequality in pay scales and employee protection, eventually there will be a convergence of standards. Through globalization, competition will hit areas previously untouched. More free trade will lead to greater growth and increased well-being.

Raghuram Rajan was named chief economist of the International Monetary Fund in June 2003. He is the first Joseph L. Gidwitz Professor of Finance at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. He has been a visiting professor at the Kellogg School and held the Fischer Black visiting chair at MIT, where he earned his Ph.D. in 1991. In January 2003, Rajan received the inaugural Fischer Black Prize of the American Finance Association award to be given every two years to the financial economist under age 40 who has made the most significant contribution to the theory and practice of finance.

For more information about Milken Institute Forums, please e-mail conferences@milkeninstitute.org or call Lisa Noshi at 310-570-4605.
Venue: Milken Institute, 1250 Fourth Street, Santa Monica
Speakers: Dr. Raghuram Rajan, Professor of Finance, University of Chicago, Graduate School of Business
blurb: Raghuram Rajan will discuss the forces that are compromising capitalism and offer a unique solution.

Name: 2003 California State of the State Conference
blurb: The Milken Institute’s 5th Annual California State of the State conference took place October 30, 2003 at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. Summaries and audio recordings of the conference sessions are available.

Name: Making Schools Work
Description:
There is a lot of talk about school reform these days. Some focus on pay. Others look at classroom size. Still others want to increase teacher and principal accountability.

William Ouchi, a professor of management at UCLA's Anderson School, takes a more business-like approach to the problem. In a landmark study outlined in his new book, Making Schools Work, Ouchi found that the biggest obstacles to improving education are large, centralized school bureaucracies.

In an examination of 223 schools in six cities — from the massive Los Angeles Unified School District to much smaller Catholic archdiocesan schools — Ouchi found that the schools whose students performed best had the most decentralized management systems. In these schools, the principals — not central office administrators — controlled school budgets and personnel.

Does it work?

Ouchi pointed to three innovative school systems he examined in Edmonton (Canada), Seattle and Houston. These systems were once plagued by the same problems that trouble Los Angeles, New York and other big-city school districts: poor test scores, flight to private schools and high dropout rates.

But leaders in each city changed their systems, moving control from a centralized office to individual schools. Principals were allowed to put money where they thought it would do the most good. In essence, they were allowed to act as entrepreneurs and make decisions based on their school's unique circumstances.

The changes have produced significant, lasting improvements in these districts, Ouchi said. In Edmonton, for example, where school principals now control 91 percent of their budgets (compared to 6.7 percent for Los Angeles school principals), test scores are up and parents, teachers and students are all much happier with their schools.

"They have put private schools out of business," Ouchi said. "That, to me, is the acid test."

In Seattle, 43 percent of children were in private schools in 1970. Today, that is down to 35 percent. In Houston, whose students consistently outscore those of Los Angeles by nearly 10 points in both reading and math, test scores are way up.

The key, Ouchi said, is what he calls the Weighted Student Formula, whereby every student is evaluated and assessed a certain dollar value in educational services. If a school has more nonEnglish-speaking students, for example, the principal can put more money into classes that help them learn English. Or it could go to hire tutors to teach at-risk students. The bottom line, he added, is money is put to its best use for each school.

"Every group of children is different," Ouchi said.

He said he has worked to help reform the Los Angeles Unified School District, whose students typically score near the bottom of national tests, but without success. He called LAUSD "the most centralized education system in the country, other than Hawaii." (Los Angeles spends only 35.4 percent of its budget on teacher pay, while Houston spends 48.5 percent and Edmonton spends 55.8 percent on teachers.)

But, he argues, if reform can work in places like Houston and Seattle, it can work in Los Angeles.

"It makes me angry, because I know other schools can be as good, but aren't," Ouchi said.
Speakers:
William Ouchi, Sanford and Betty Sigoloff Chair in Corporate Renewal, Professor of Management, 
UCLA Anderson School of Management
blurb: William Ouchi, Sanford and Betty Sigoloff Chair in Corporate Renewal at the UCLA Anderson School of Management discussed his new book describing a revolutionary approach to creating successful public schools.

Name: "Off the Record" with California State Controller Steve Westly
Description:
State Controller Steve Westly, speaking at a private meeting with members of the Milken Institute Associates, called the current political and economic upheaval in California "an extraordinary time" that requires common sense leadership and bipartisan solutions.

He warned that failure to solve the state's budget problems could lead to serious consequences in the near future, and he urged compromise on both sides.

"This state has become too divisive, too partisan," Westly said.

Among his main issues are:

  • changing the process of redistricting, which in the hands of politicians has led to fewer and fewer competitive races, causing an increase in political extremism;
  • extending term limits, whose current constraints have caused a loss of some of the Legislature's most knowledgeable leaders; and
  • open primaries, which will lead to more moderate candidates.

Despite our current woes, he remains extremely optimistic about California's future, added Westly, the former eBay executive.

"The economy is coming back," he said. "I'm confident the state will come back as strong as ever."

The meeting was one of a series that allows members of the Associates to meet privately with local, national and international leaders.

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: The 2% Solution: Fixing America's Problems in Ways Liberals and Conservatives Can Love
Description:
America's most serious problems — such as the 40 million people without health insurance or the poor state of education in our urban schools — remain unsolved thanks to a lack of imagination, will and ability by both sides to compromise. Only some new thinking, new approaches and a willingness by leaders from both political parties to listen to each other's views can change things, said Matt Miller.

Miller, a syndicated columnist and radio commentator, thinks he has just the answer to end the stalemate — the "2% Solution."

As described in his new book by the same name, Miller's thesis is that for just two cents on the dollar, all Americans could have health insurance, full-time workers could earn a decent living wage, and children in the inner-city can have the best teachers. We can do all of this, he said, using conservative means — like tax subsidies and vouchers — to achieve liberal goals. And in the end, government would still be smaller than it was when Ronald Reagan was president.

Sound too good to be true? Miller doesn't think so.

"With the baby boomers retiring, we no longer have the luxury of not being serious about these issues," he told a Milken Institute Forum audience. "At the end of the day, what I'm talking about is tiny compared to other things we've done in our history."

What he proposes, Miller said, is spending no more money as a percentage of the country's GDP than what the government spent during Reagan's term — about 22 percent. In 2004, that's about $220 billion, or "2 percent" of our $11 trillion national income.

Tired of seeing little progress on a host of important policy issues, Miller spent the past couple of years talking with thought leaders from both sides of the aisle — from political strategist James Carville to Nobel laureate Milton Friedman — before coming up with solutions that he feels both sides could agree on.

Each side, however, must be willing to compromise — the "grand bargain," as he calls it. The left has to be more open to market-based solutions, and the right has to be more open to spending money commensurate with the size of the problem.

"We cannot solve these problems without money," Miller said. "And we have the money."

Miller said he hopes his book will change national politics by showing Americans how we can reframe the debate and fix some of the nation's biggest domestic problems through solutions that are pragmatic, broadly acceptable and just.

If we don't do it soon, he warned, our ability to fix these problems will become almost impossible. Less than 10 years remain before the baby boomer's retirement will start to drain away all the cash and political energy to do anything but cope with their colossal health and pension costs.

Matthew Miller is a syndicated columnist, a commentator for NPR's "Morning Edition," and the host of the radio program "Left, Right & Center." His articles have appeared in The Atlantic Monthly, The New Republic, and The New York Times Magazine. He was previously a senior adviser to the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget and a management consultant with McKinsey & Company.
Speakers: Matthew Miller, syndicated columnist and radio commentator
blurb: Syndicated columnist Matthew Miller offers a revolutionary program for fixing America 's most serious domestic problems for just two cents on the national dollar - while we still can.

Name: California-Israel Eco-Technology Partnership Forum
Description:
The 2nd annual California-Israel Eco-Technology Partnership Forum included an impressive list of business people who are working to solve the world's energy and water needs in an environmentally responsible way.

But it was a politician — albeit a Nobel laureate and one of the world's most honored — who put the day's discussion in perspective.

Former Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said the planet's two most important resources — fresh air and clean water — receive the least attention of the world's leaders. With the global population explosion, land has become a limited resource, Peres said, and we must subsidize efforts in science and technology that will help solve the problems that this growth has created.

It is science and technology that enrich us, he said, and we must help those making advances in using new energy sources — the sun, wind, and nuclear energy — to provide clean, low-cost ways of generating power.

Peres lauded efforts by technology companies to combat pollution, desalinate water and develop clean energy sources in nondestructive ways. In Africa, for example, a project is underway that combines the heat of the desert with the power of its waterfalls to supply energy to Europe. Investing in knowledge, especially in nanotechnology, Peres said, is the future.

The day-long event, spearheaded by the Government of Israel Economic Mission and hosted by the Milken Institute, featured panel discussions with leaders in water and energy technology from California and Israel. Each panel discussion was followed by technology company presentations highlighting specific developments in the areas of water and energy. Emphasis was placed on efforts to substantially expand the use of alternative energy sources and create more efficient methods of water usage.

Several new products were introduced this year by presenters, including a device that purifies salt and non-potable water using solar energy, one that utilizes magnetic technology to clean industrial wastewater, and several others that offer environmentally friendly, efficient and cost-effective methods for removing pollution. Luncheon keynote speaker David Freeman, Chairman of the California Consumer Power and Conservation Financing Authority, advocated a transition to renewable hydrogen in place of fuel to power trucks, buses, cars and even airplanes.

We do not need to wait for the fuel cell, Freeman said. The technology is here, but the will is lacking. It takes enlightened citizens and leadership to reduce our dependence on Middle East oil, he stressed, which he characterized as dangerous to America and among the largest problems we face.

"We are pregnant with opportunities here," he said, and we need to elevate our vision of what is possible to a larger scale.

View transcript of Prime Minister Peres' remarks.
Venue: Milken Institute Conference Center, Santa Monica, CA
blurb: Representatives of Israeli and American environmental technology companies held their second annual California-Israel Eco-Technology Partnership Forum along with California and Israel government agencies to discuss efforts to expand the use of alternative energy sources and create more efficient methods of water usage.

Name: Asian Bond Market Forum
Description:
The Milken Institute and Asian Institute of International Financial Law of The University of Hong Kong host the first annual Asian Bond Market Forum November 11-14, 2003 in Hong Kong.

The Forum's collaborative approach is aimed at bringing together policy makers and market professionals to bring ideas to the table that will help establish fully active domestic bond markets and regional investment in East Asia.

Leading financial professionals and decision makers from China, ASEAN, Korea and Hong Kong will join leading investors from Asia, Japan, the United States and Europe in this endeavor.

The conference's distinguished lineup includes James Barth, Milken Institute Senior Research Fellow; Lilia Bautista, Chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Philippines; Zhou Xiaochuan (invited), Chairman of the People's Bank of China in Beijing; and Cecile Saavedra, Managing Director, Standard & Poor's.

For program and registration details, visit www.abm-forum.org. (This link takes you outside the Milken Institute web site. To return, click on the back button).
blurb: The Milken Institute and the Asian Institute of International Financial Law of The University of Hong Kong hosted the first annual Asian Bond Market Forum November 11-14, 2003 in Hong Kong.

Name: The Current Economy and Financial Trends
Description:
The aging of today's developed nations will lead to a global shift in economic power over the next 50 years to younger, developing countries — a change that has enormous implications for investors and companies worldwide, Wharton School Professor Jeremy Siegel told a Milken Institute Forum audience.

Because the United States, Europe and Japan have aging populations, the ratio of workers per retiree is dwindling, he said. By 2050, that ratio is expected to be 2.6:1 in the U.S., and as low as 1:1 in Italy. Those are unsustainable ratios.

"Who will produce the goods?" Siegel asked. "Who will buy the assets?"

Either today's workers will have to delay retirement into their 70s — something not many Americans would relish — or other nations will have to take up the slack. Productivity gains and immigration won't be enough.

The only other answer, Siegel said, is that developing countries — which today have 80 percent of the world's population, but produce only 20 percent of its GDP — will have to make up the difference. If these younger nations can grow their GDP 6 percent annually, they will produce the world's goods and buy its assets.

"The economic power will shift to them," Siegel said. "By 2050, they'll own more than 80 percent of the world's capital."

This has huge implications for investors and companies, he added, among them the explosion of growth and demand in emerging domestic markets.

During his talk, co-hosted by the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, Siegel, author of Stocks for the Long Run, also discussed his belief that stocks will continue to outperform other asset classes, as they have over history.

He included historical charts showing that the average returns for stocks, minus inflation, has been 6.7 percent for more than 100 years, while bonds' average return has been 3.5 percent. In addition, while stocks are riskier over the short-term, his research shows that over any 30-year period, stocks are actually safer than bonds.

He also discussed his "core investing" principles, such as that companies should focus on their core competencies. To show that these principles work, he produced a list of the best-performing stocks since 1950. At the top was National Dairy Products Corp. (now Kraft Foods), which has brought investors 15 percent annual returns, followed by R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, Standard Oil of New Jersey (now ExxonMobil) and Coca Cola — all companies that focus on what they do best.

One of the reasons investors have done well by these firms, he said, is they give out dividends — an important and sometimes overlooked strategy for building wealth. The recent trend by companies to give out stock options to their executives has led CEOs to focus on driving up stock prices. That, in turn, has led to reduced dividends from about 5 percent for most of the 20th century to about 1 percent during the bull market of the 1990s and only slightly more than that today. Siegel said dividends are not only a good investment tool, but they increase investor confidence in the market.

For more information about Prof. Siegel or the Wharton School, click here.
(Note: This link takes you to a web site outside of milkeninstitute.org. To return, hit the back button on your web browser.)
Speakers: Jeremy Siegel, Russell E. Palmer Professor of Finance, Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
blurb: Jeremy Siegel, Russell E. Palmer Professor of Finance, Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, shared his insight and analyses on current financial trends - what worked, what’s still working and what’s not.

Name: "Off the Record" with Douglas Holtz-Eakin
Description:
Douglas Holtz-Eakin, Director of the Congressional Budget Office, told members of the Milken Institute Associates that his office spends a lot of time studying the impact of proposed legislation on the federal budget. They must also deal with numerous requests from members of Congress to analyze specific issues, such as the cost of the war in Iraq. And there are the ongoing analyses of pending policy issues such as trade and financial market regulation.

But while all of these tasks are vital, the elephant in the room these days is the federal budget deficit, he said.

"All of these discussions take place within the context of the budget outlook for the U.S.," Holtz-Eakin said.

For the current fiscal year, the deficit is expected to reach $480 billion. Next year, it is projected to be $350 billion. Deficits will continue to decline until about 2012, when a balanced budget is finally reached. In 2013, we should finally see a surplus again, he said.

But, he emphasized, these projections are based on current laws — some of which undoubtedly will change. Policy, he said, is the big uncertainty in trying to figure out where the federal budget is headed.

Holtz-Eakin, whose nonpartisan agency is responsible for providing Congress with budget and economic analyses, discussed a broad range of issues that could change these projections, from tax cuts to entitlement programs such as Social Security and Medicare. How Congress deals with these issues will greatly impact these projections.

Holtz-Eakin began his four-year term in February 2003. Before that, he was chief economist for the President's Council of Economic Advisers, where he was also senior staff economist for two years.

The meeting was one of a series that allows members of the Associates to meet privately with local, national and international leaders.

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: To Protect and To Serve: Safety and Order in Los Angeles
Description:
LAPD Chief William Bratton and a panel of four renowned experts on crime prevention discussed the unique challenges the police face as they try to make Los Angeles "one of the safest large cities in America."

A proponent of the "broken windows" philosophy of policing, Bratton cited L.A.'s small police force as the greatest impediment to solving some of its toughest crime problems — especially gang violence. Because of the relatively small number of police officers, the force must make incremental, rather than a dynamic changes in addressing the city's crime problems, he said.

The "broken windows" philosophy calls for improving quality-of-life issues to rid an area of petty crime and destructive behavior that lead to greater, more serious offenses. Combined with other important crime-fighting techniques such as community policing, this method has been highly successful in dramatically reducing crime in cities such as Boston and New York. While progress has been made in attacking problems specifically identified by L.A.'s citizens, such as graffiti, its gang problem will only be resolved, the chief stated, with more police, more after-school programs and more jobs.

Bratton's talk was followed by a panel discussion with four leading proponents of his crime-fighting philosophy.

Criminologist and economist James Wilson characterized the police force as only one component of successful crime fighting. "Police make a difference," he said, "but they need help from other government agencies," whose behavior affects the ability to sustain the outcome of policing efforts. City government, he maintained, ought to focus on the problems neighborhoods identify — empty buildings used for dealing drugs, abandoned cars, litter and other conditions that cause neighborhoods to deteriorate — and remove those conditions. These efforts improve public order, public confidence and reduce crime.

George Kelling, a professor in Rutgers University's School of Criminal Justice, emphasized that the solutions present themselves when the problem is correctly identified. Blighted areas, such as L.A.'s Skid Row, are characterized by a culture of lawlessness, he said. When the local culture condones an atmosphere where "anything goes," its residents suffer. They live in fear and are terrorized by local gangs and petty criminals. By paying attention to quality-of-life issues — that is, stopping people who create havoc — the police can help restore order and safety in crime-ridden neighborhoods, he said.

The Rev. Eugene Rivers, co-chair of the National Ten Point Leadership Foundation, emphasized the importance of building strategic partnerships with other government agencies, local communities, faith-based organizations and even private companies. To resolve L.A.'s culture of violence and gang problem, the city must engage the community to face the problem and create disincentives to crime. The work of society, he concluded, must complement the efforts of the police department.

Peter Cove, founder of America Works, said putting parolees to work as soon as they leave prison would reduce recidivism. Of the 600,000 people who leave state penitentiaries each year alone, he said, 70 percent are back in three years. Having found that quickly moving people into work from welfare made a difference in the welfare roles, he decided to apply that model to ex-convicts. Cove observed that those individuals who were moved into work almost immediately after leaving prison didn't go back. Though the program is too new to measure results, the indications are that prison-to-work programs would have a major impact on lowering crime.

This forum was co-hosted by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research.
(Please Note: This link takes you to a web site outside the Milken Institute web site. To return, hit the back button on your web browser.)
Speakers: Los Angeles Police Chief William J. Bratton, keynote address, and panel discussion with four crime experts
blurb: Los Angeles Police Chief William Bratton outlined his crime-fighting philosophy, widely known as "broken windows," followed by a panel discussion with four leading crime experts.

Name: Global Conference 2004
blurb: A record 2,000 people attended the 7th annual Global Conference, which highlighted the vast changes and challenges facing business leaders and policy makers today, as well as the improved global economy.

Name: Financing the Future
Description:
Allowing entrepreneurs access to the capital they need to create, grow and sustain their businesses — and in the process generate jobs and wealth for workers and nations — is crucial to future prosperity, Institute economists Glenn Yago and Susanne Trimbath said.

Laying out themes from their book, Beyond Junk Bonds, Yago and Trimbath told the Forum audience that innovations in finance have greatly improved the sources and availability of capital in the U.S. in recent decades, which has helped fuel America's tremendous economic growth. As similar innovations become more widely available, they can also help other countries — something that is starting to happen, they said.

"The story of financing the future is the story of financing change," said Yago.

Access to capital makes it possible for companies to improve productivity — for example, by allowing them to restructure in times of competitive change or difficulty, or to merge with other firms to save costs.

New financial technologies and tools give capital markets the flexibility they need to respond to competitive circumstances, they said. These include such ideas as securitized mortgages and credit cards, collateralized loan obligations, and derivatives.

Yago and Trimbath also gave a history of the high-yield bond market, including its performance versus equities and other investments over the past decade. High-yield securities have become well-established financial tools used by today's biggest global companies.

At the heart of their talk, however, was the idea that such innovations, and the free flow of capital, is crucial to solving some of our most important public policy issues, from paying for the retirement of millions of baby boomers to saving global ecosystems. Also, with the debate over globalization and how developing countries are going to raise their standards of living, these financial innovations can play an important role, they said.

Glenn Yago is Director of Capital Studies at the Milken Institute. He specializes in financial innovations, financial institutions and capital markets, and has extensively analyzed public policy and its relation to high-yield markets, initial public offerings, industrial and transportation concerns, and public and private sector employment. Previously, he was a professor at the State University of New York—Stony Brook, City University of New York Graduate Center, and Baruch College.

Susanne Trimbath is Senior Research Economist in Capital Studies at the Milken Institute, and an experienced business professional with nearly 20 years in financial services, including operations management. She also taught economics and finance courses at New York University's Department of Economics, Stern School of Business and the New York Institute of Finance. Her research focuses on mergers and buyouts, real estate investments, and emerging capital markets. Previously, she was a director in operations at Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation in New York.
Speakers:
Glenn Yago, Director of Capital Studies, Milken Institute
Susanne Trimbath, Senior Research Economist, Milken Institute
blurb: Milken Institute economists Glenn Yago and Susanne Trimbath talked about the crucial importance of financial innovations, and the free flow of capital, to solving some of our most important public policy issues.

Name: Invest Australia
Description:
In conjunction with Invest Australia and the Australian Consul General, the Milken Institute hosted a private breakfast on Jan. 20, 2004, that offered a view of Australia's business and investment scene.

The meeting, being held as part of Australia Week 2004, featured Alexander Downer, Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs; David Hill, Chairman and CEO of Fox Sports Television Group; and Thomas Lynch, Managing Director of Wilshire Private Markets Group.

Downer talked about the Australian economy, trade, FTA progress with China, Singapore, Thailand, and the U.S., security and international relations.

Hill addressed the cultural, social and business synergies that exist between Americans and Australians.

Lynch provided investment insight on doing business in Australia as an investor and funds manager.

The event was part of the Institute's ongoing series of meetings with leaders of distinction and members of the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: California State Forum
Description:
If Los Angeles is to prosper, its leaders must give top priority to improving the region's infrastructure, from expanding regional airports to building affordable housing. But most important, they must focus on the area's most important asset — its people — and that means improving education and helping create well-paying jobs.

That was the message from four of Los Angeles' leading public officials at a California State Forum hosted by the Milken Institute: "California's Economic Recovery: Financing Our Infrastructure."

The panelists were Roy Romer, Superintendent of the L.A. Unified School District; Michael D. Antonovich, Los Angeles County Supervisor; Laura Chick, Los Angeles City Controller; and Eric Garcetti, Los Angeles City Councilman.

Garcetti focused on what he called "a crisis of finance" within state and local governments, as well as the critical need for housing, while Chick decried a "crisis of confidence" that people have because of the appearance of an un-level playing field in the bidding for some of the city's contracts.

Antonovich cited a litany of issues that need addressing, from traffic to education, but left his most pointed criticisms for Sacramento, where the state Legislature has been on what he called a spending "binge" for several years.

Romer emphasized the good things that are happening at the school district, such as rising scores in elementary grades and the recent voter approval of bond Measure R, which allows the district to continue with much-needed school construction.

The meeting included follow-up questions from a panel of experts: Ross DeVol, Director of Regional Economics at the Milken Institute; Howard Fine, a reporter for the Los Angeles Business Journal; and George Kieffer, Chairman of the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce. Frank Mottek of KNX Newsradio was the master of ceremonies.

John E. Anderson, Chairman, President and CEO of Topa Equities, received the Forum Award in honor of his service to the community.

The event was sponsored by Barrington Associates, as well as Bingham McCutchen, LLC, Northern Trust, CDR Financial Products and the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce.

The California State Forum is a nonpartisan event that was created to provide the public greater access to civic leaders and to encourage discourse about issues affecting the community. It is televised and played on local stations throughout California following the event.
Speakers:
Roy Romer, Superintendent, Los Angeles Unified School District
Michael D. Antonovich, Los Angeles County Supervisor
Laura Chick, Los Angeles City Controller
Eric Garcetti, Los Angeles City Councilman
blurb: The Milken Institute hosted the California State Forum, a televised program that brought together four of L.A.'s leading public officials to discuss how to accelerate the region's economic recovery.

Name: Off the Record With Andras Simonyi
Description:
Andras Simonyi, the Hungarian ambassador to the United States, reiterated his country's support for America in its war against Iraq, saying it is important to stand behind its ally.

"The relationship between the United States and Hungary has never been closer, never been better," said the ambassador during a private meeting with members of the Milken Institute Associates.

The ambassador added, however, that he is sorry to see the rift between the U.S. and its longtime allies France and Germany over the war, since it's important that the Trans-Atlantic relationship remain strong.

While Hungary has supported the U.S. decision on Iraq, it has also worked hard to maintain its good relationship with Germany, its key partner in Europe.

The ambassador also talked about Hungary's joining the European Union later this year. He said his country will be a vocal and active member of the EU.

"We'll be there to help and make a difference," he said.

Ambassador Simonyi touched on a variety of other issues, including immigration, demographics, investments in Hungary and the economy.

He joined the Foreign Ministry in 1989. Prior to becoming ambassador, he headed the NATO Liaison Office in Brussels. He was a key player in preparing Hungary for accession to NATO and in 1999, he became the first Hungarian permanent representative on the NATO Council. He is vice president of the Hungarian Atlantic Council, co-founder of the Center for Euro-Atlantic Integration and Democracy, and was Hungary's representative to the Western European Union Council for five years.

The meeting was one of a series that allows members of the Associates to meet privately with local, national and international leaders.

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: Financing Hydrogen: A Look at the Year Ahead
Description:
The California Hydrogen Business Council presents a special event Thursday, March 4, 4-8 p.m. at the Milken Institute.

This event, Financing Hydrogen: A Look at the Year Ahead will explore near-term opportunities for investors, entrepreneurs and industrial concerns in the emerging Hydrogen Economy.

Consider that:

  • Our newly elected governor has appointed Terry Tamminen, Secretary of Cal EPA, as the architect of a plan to build a hydrogen fueling station every 20 miles along California's Interstate Highway system.
  • The California State Treasurer has asked that 0.5 percent of the assets of the state's largest pension funds be invested in environmental technologies.
  • President Bush's recently proposed FY 2005 budget calls for $228 million to support hydrogen-related programs, a 43 percent increase over 2004 spending.

    • Come and join us along with leading investors and organizations involved in hydrogen related technologies and infrastructure to learn about opportunities in this emerging sector.

    The event will begin with "2003: The Year in Review," an assessment of recent investment activity, provided by Reed Global Advisors.

    Two panel sessions will follow:
    Investments In Hydrogen Infrastructure and
    Investments In Hydrogen Technologies.

    A buffet and beverages networking session will follow the presentations.

    Participants include NextGen Partners, the Rustic Canyon Group, Garage Technology Ventures, Chrysalix, ChevronTexaco, Praxair, The Hydrogen Car Company, PriceWaterhouseCoopers, South Coast Air Quality Management District, California Treasurer's Office, and many more.

    View agenda.

    PREREGISTRATION IS REQUIRED and attendance is limited.
    Advance registration (payment received before Feb. 26) is $65 for CHBC members and $100 for nonmembers. Late registration is $100 for members and $150 for nonmembers. Registration deadline is March 2.

    Download the meeting registration form at http://www.hydrogen.la/chbc/registration03-04-04.doc or at http://www.hydrogen.la/chbc/registration03-04-04.pdf
    or, you may contact:
    California Hydrogen Business Council
    Attn: Melissa Stock
    melissastock@socal.rr.com
    3532 Katella Avenue, Suite 108
    Los Alamitos, CA 90720
    Phone 562-493-4014

    Public parking for this event is available in Public Parking Lot #1 on 4th street, immediately adjacent to the Milken Institute.
blurb: This event, hosted by the Milken Institute and presented by the California Hydrogen Business Council, will explore near-term opportunities for investors, entrepreneurs and industrial concerns in the emerging Hydrogen Economy.

Name: Market-Based Solutions through Environmental Finance: the Case of the Chicago Climate Exchange
Description:
Back when he came up with the idea of creating a public exchange that would trade the rights to carbon dioxide, many on both sides of the equation — the financial community and environmentalists — thought his chances of success were, well, small.

After all, the markets were down and the U.S. had pulled out of the Kyoto Protocol, which could have helped jumpstart the initiative.

But Richard Sandor, who created the idea of trading financial futures in the 1970s, knew it could work. And in December 2003, through perseverance and perhaps a little luck, he saw his dream come true in the form of the Chicago Climate Exchange, a self-regulatory exchange that administers a voluntary greenhouse gas reduction and trading program for North America.

At a Milken Institute roundtable meeting with government officials, environmental organizations and members of the financial community, Sandor said the Exchange has been wildly successful in its first two months.
