Already on board as members are such firms as Ford, DuPont, IBM, Motorola and American Electric Power, as well as the city of Chicago and the University of Oklahoma. And the trading of carbon dioxide has nearly tripled since the Exchange opened on Dec. 12.

"This is going to dominate the environmental forefront," Sandor said of the idea of cap-and-trade programs. It could even expand into the areas of trading the rights to air and water.

"They are our most important commodities, and they have to be rationed," he said. He added that markets are the best way to do that — much better than armies fighting over it.

The meeting was part of the Milken Institute's ongoing series of presentations of financial innovations addressing long-standing public policy problems bringing together financial practitioners, policy makers and change agents in the public and private sector.

Dr. Sandor, Chairman and CEO of the Chicago Climate Exchange, was the recipient of the Milken Institute's 2003 Award for Financial Innovation and the subject of recent in-depth reports in Time and Forbes magazines. He is a director on numerous boards, including the Intercontinental Exchange, an electronic marketplace for commodity and derivative products, and is a member of the design committee of the Dow Jones Sustainability Index.

For more information about the Exchange, visit www.chicagoclimateexchange.com. (Note: This link takes you to a web site outside of milkeninstitute.org. To return, hit the back button on your web browser.)
blurb: Richard Sandor, who created idea of trading financial futures in the 1970s, talks about the success of his new venture, the Chicago Climate Exchange, a self-regulatory exchange that administers a voluntary greenhouse gas reduction and trading program for North America.

Name: Workforce Housing for Cities and Counties
Description:
Co-hosted by Fannie Mae

In Santa Barbara County, the average price of a home is $930,000, yet teachers in the area only make between $30,000 and $40,000 year — not nearly enough to afford a place of their own. So where do these teachers, as well as the firefighters, police officers and other workers crucial to a community, live?

It's a problem facing workers not only in Santa Barbara, but nationwide — especially in California where home prices continue to climb as demand outstrips supply.

It's also a problem that the speakers at this Forum are tackling head-on as they implement creative and workable solutions to the lack of affordable housing for workers.

Mike Curzan of UniDev LLC, whose principals have developed and are developing over $400 million of affordable workforce housing in markets around the U.S., says his goal is simple: "We want to create as low a price as possible — within reason of construction costs — to make it affordable to people."

His firm's most recent project is at California State University at Channel Islands, which already consists of over 250 for-sale homes and rental apartments designed to serve a mixed-income population. Residents with incomes as low as $40,000 can purchase units being developed with prices as low as $165,000. Eventually, it will have 900 units of affordable faculty and staff housing, a small amount of commercial and R&D space — and over $800 million in revenue for the campus.

The key to UniDev's success is land. The sponsor — in this case, CSU — commits land to the project and UniDev takes care of the rest. Through the use of a ground lease, the sponsor is able to control the project, giving priority for housing to certain employees (professors, for example, or nurses) and receive revenue in the process.

The idea is to create quality housing for workers who couldn't ordinarily afford it, allowing them to live in the community where they work. This reduces commute time and allows hospitals, cities or universities to attract employees without having to raise salaries to beyond what they can afford.

Marc Wright of Martinez & Wright Homeownership Partners discussed his group's housing benefit program that enables essential workers in expensive California markets to buy homes near their workplace. They contract with employers to provide a housing subsidy, while receiving a share of equity proportional to Partners' contribution toward the property's purchase price.

"The employee only pays what they can afford," he said. "We fill in the gap."

Ted Chandler of Fannie Mae discussed his organization's support for these innovative solutions. He also cited Fannie Mae's commitment to affordable housing. One example is the American Dream Commitment program, which was created to provide $2 trillion in private capital for 18 million minority and underserved Americans to own or rent a home by the end of the decade.

Suzanne Reade, President of Urban Insurance Partners Institute, which provides insurers with the resources, contacts and data needed to write business effectively in urban areas, discussed the challenges and opportunities insurers see in the urban marketplace.

"They have to rethink the way they do business," she said of insurance companies.

The Forum was part of a day of meetings and presentations at the Milken Institute co-hosted by Fannie Mae that brought together city and county officials, real estate and mortgage insurance executives, and other housing and financing lenders to provide them with information on resources that are available about the housing crisis, the status of housing affordability and its effects in communities.
Speakers:
Ted Chandler, Vice President of Housing and Community Development, Fannie Mae
Mike Curzan, Chief Executive Officer, UniDev LLC
Suzanne Reade, President, SReade, Inc., and Urban Insurance Partners Institute
Marc Wright, Founder and Principal, Martinez & Wright Homeownership Partners, LLC
blurb: In this Forum, co-hosted by Fannie Mae, a group of experts discussed real solutions to California's lack of affordable housing and its impact on employee recruitment, retention and performance.

Name: Reinventing Israeli Government
Description:
The IDC Decade of Leadership Event Series presented by The Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy & Strategy at the Interdisciplinary Center of Herzliya will hold its annual conference, "Reinventing Israeli Government," in Herzliya, Israel on March 30.

The maintenance of a viable democracy depends on accountability, transparency, effectiveness, efficiency, responsiveness, integrity and public trust. Problems, tensions and conflicts in these areas in Israel result in policy deadlocks and an incapacity to govern.

In order to enhance economic progress, social cohesion and effective democratic governance, this conference will address the steps towards major conceptual and structural changes that can be taken to improve government functioning.

The Institute's Director of Capital Studies, Glenn Yago, will participate in a panel titled "The Public Sector: Decentralization and Executive Agencies."

View agenda.

For more information, contact the Symposium Coordinator, Prof. David Nachmias, Lauder School of Government, IDC Herzliya, 011-972-9-9527-272.
blurb: The IDC Decade of Leadership Event Series presented by The Lauder School of Government, Diplomacy & Strategy at the Interdisciplinary Center of Herzliya will hold its annual conference, "Reinventing Israeli Government."

Name: "Off the Record" with Pat Cox
Description:
In a wide-ranging discussion of issues from trade to terrorism, Pat Cox, President of the European Parliament, offered a positive assessment of the future of the European Union during a private meeting with members of the Milken Institute Council.

He said the addition of 10 new member countries in May will strengthen the EU because they will bring new voices, new ideas and strong ideals to the organization.

"They aren't going to be shoved around by anybody," Cox said. "Europe will be richer with them."

With his visit coming just days after voters ousted Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar's Popular Party from power on the heels of terrorist bombings in Madrid, Cox focused many of his comments on that issue.

He reassured his audience that the change in Spain's government will not cause a shift in the global effort to fight terrorism.

"I don't believe any Spanish administration is going to go soft on terrorism," he said. "I expect them to have a very, very strong anti-terrorism policy."

During his talk and a question-and-answer session that followed, Cox touched on a host of issues facing Europe, including its relations with the U.S., intellectual property concerns, the Microsoft anti-trust dispute, trade, job creation and immigration.

A member of the European Parliament since 1989, Cox represents the constituency of Munster in the Republic of Ireland. Before entering politics, he worked both as an economics lecturer and as a journalist and television presenter on Irish television. Having been elected to the European Parliament as a Progressive Democrat MEP in 1989, he was successfully re-elected, this time as an Independent Member, in 1994. He was elected president of the European Parliament in 2002.

The meeting is one of a series that allows members of the Milken Institute Council - part of the Milken Institute Associates program - to meet privately with local, national and international leaders.

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: The Right Nation: Conservative Power in America
Description:
The Right Nation: Conservative Power in America is a portrait of the genesis and rise of America's conservative movement, said co-author John Micklethwait. The portrait captures the groups, initiatives, think tanks and ideologies that epitomize the America's conservative right, a movement unparalleled in any other part of the world. Conservatives, he pointed out, are members of rifle clubs, love NASCAR, hate government, live in the South and suburbs of the heartland, and are fiercely moralistic. With 41 percent of Americans identifying themselves as conservatives, the country's center of gravity is much more to the right than other developed nations. This, Micklethwait said, explains the gulf between America and its allies, as well as their hatred of President George W. Bush.

While the American left has equivalent movements overseas, there is no equivalent of the American right in Europe. Its ideology seems "un-American." While liberals oppose racial inequality, support restrictions on guns, oppose the death penalty and are anti-abortion, the South, West and American heartland are bound by strident nationalism, profound differences in values, fervent opposition to government say on almost every issue, and overwhelming support for high defense spending.

"America," Micklethwait stated, "is clearly divided along ideological lines." The left-right political division is based more on culture and values and less on class. Rich or poor, conservatives go to church at least once a week, believe the role of government is to provide freedom to pursue personal goals, support a strong military and are very patriotic. This too, he noted, has no counterpart in other developed countries, where government is expected to guarantee that no one is left in need, church attendance is sporadic and support for taxation for public services is high.

The six features of American conservatism, according to the Micklethwait, who wrote the book with Adrian Wooldridge, the Economist's Washington-based correspondent, are religion, government, capitalism, the complete absence of socialism, tradition and geography. Conservatives are more religious, skeptical of government, advocate decentralization, focus on progress—capitalism's main product—and have no legacy of social welfare. Unlike overcrowded Europe, the vast American continent has enough space to provide each person with an acre of land, not including Alaska, and still only occupy 1/20th of the country. This fact, the authors maintain, has nurtured the frontier spirit and aversion to government intrusion.

Thanks to immigration and a higher birth rate, America's population is aging much more slowly than Europe's, and its conservative movement is growing. America, the authors predict, will have increasing economic strength (notwithstanding the baby-boomer liabilities being handed down to future generations) and will become the world's police, given the conservative penchant for increasing military strength.

Micklethwait noted that while America's left has "vast intellectual power, more money and more brains" than the conservatives, they "lack the organization" that has been the underpinning of the conservative movement's success. Conservatives remain united and are able to proceed even when not in office whereas the left simply does not have the right's lasting power.
Venue:
Milken Institute
1250 Fourth Street
Santa Monica, CA
blurb: Renowned America watcher, John Micklethwait of the Economist, explained why the American conservative movement will remain the most compelling political force of our age.

Name: "Off the Record" with Mark Rosenthal
Description:
Mark Rosenthal, a prominent sports lawyer who won the Eric Gagne arbitration case for the Dodgers earlier this year, said the key to winning was comparing the relief pitcher to others with his years of experience and not trying to denigrate Gagne's outstanding achievements.

"I wasn't going to argue that Eric Gange didn't have a great season," Rosenthal said. "That was going nowhere."

Instead, he said, he compared his salary demands to other pitchers with his same three years of experience, like Mariano Rivera of the Yankees, who was awarded $4.25 million in 1999.

The Dodgers offered Gagne $5 million, while the pitcher asked for $8 million. Agreeing to Gagne's demand would result in a record salary for a pitcher with only three years' experience, Rosenthal said.

"Our case was not so much about Eric Gagne as it was about baseball's salary system," said Rosenthal in a breakfast meeting with members of the Milken Institute Associates.

To the surprise of much of the baseball world, the arbitrators selected the Dodgers' $5 million offer.

Rosenthal chairs the Sports Industry Group at Jeffer, Mangels, Butler & Marmaro. His practice emphasizes sports law, entertainment litigation and intellectual property litigation. He has represented professional sports teams for 15 years and currently represents more baseball teams in salary arbitrations than any other attorney in the country.

To join the Associates, please contact Jared Carney, Director of Marketing, at (310) 570-4676, or by e-mail at jcarney@milkeninstitute.org.

Name: 2004 California State of the State Conference
blurb: The 6th annual State of the State Conference offered a mixed outlook for California – good in the long-term thanks to our many technology and research assets, but difficult in the short term with challenges in education, state financing and business costs.

Name: Agile Energy Systems: Global Lessons from the California Energy Crisis
Description:
As oil prices rise and more and more cities experience electricity blackouts around the globe, there is a subtle but important shift going on that could help ease future energy crunches — an "agile" energy system that is less dependent on traditional fossil fuels and more reliant on renewable, clean energy technologies, said authors Woodrow W. Clark II and Ted Bradshaw.

Thanks not only to public-private partnerships pushing the move toward "green" energy supplies, but also to some forward-looking multinational corporations like General Electric, this shift is taking place across the globe, they said.

"We're in the middle of a paradigm change," said Clark, a senior fellow at the Milken Institute.

Clark and Bradshaw discussed their new book, Agile Energy Systems, Global Lessons from the California Energy Crisis, which offers a new approach to energy reliability and efficiency.

Rather than the deregulation model, which has cost California some $40 billion, or a fully regulated energy system, the authors argue for one that is market-driven, but with a strong dose of government help and regulation.

This system, they say, involves a much higher reliance on clean energies, like wind, sun and hydrogen, as well as hybrids of these and carbon-based fuels.

"The deregulation model did not work and will not work," said Bradshaw, a professor at the University of California, Davis. "Deregulation was a bad idea."

The key points of an "agile" energy system are:

  • Diversified technologies
  • Distributed production
  • Renewable and clean natural energy sources
  • Interdependent (hybrid) and interchangeable
  • Quickly developable and promotes small businesses
  • Enhance the public good
  • Reliable and cost controlled

To avoid electricity blackouts in the future, governments and companies must work together to build on a diversified sources of clean energy supplies.

"Clean, renewable energies are the future," said Clark.

Read more about Agile Energy Systems, Global Lessons from the California Energy Crisis.
Speakers: Woodrow W. Clark, II, Senior Fellow, Milken Institute, and Ted K. Bradshaw, Professor, Human and Community Development Department, University of California, Davis
blurb: Woodrow Clark II and Ted Bradshaw, authors of Agile Energy Systems: Global Lessons from the California Energy Crisis, talked about how to use the lessons of the past to reshape the future of energy systems for any region or country.

Name: "Off the Record" with Donald Tang
Description:
China's new leaders face tremendous challenges as they try to find the right balance between economic growth, job creation and building a modern economy for a population of 1.2 billion people.

But everyone has a stake is seeing them succeed, said Donald Tang, vice chairman of Bear, Stearns & Co. and a leading expert on China. If they fail, it will have serious repercussions on the global economy.

"If China prospers, it will benefit all of us," said Tang, who was this season's first guest in the Milken Institute Associates' series of private meetings with individuals of distinction.

Fortunately, Tang said, China's new leadership is extremely smart and they understand the issues. He believes they will make the right decisions on the economy.

Tang offered his views on a variety of topics, ranging from the growth of China's middle class and its current construction boom to rising oil prices and the growing tension between China and Taiwan — an issue that he said must be managed very carefully by all sides, the U.S. included, to prevent a serious confrontation.

To join the Associates, please contact Jared Carney, Director of Marketing, at (310) 570-4676.

Name: Financing Israel's Future: The Economic Reform Agenda — A Progress Report
Description:
Joseph Bachar, Director General of the Ministry of Finance for the State of Israel, said substantial progress has been made on Israel's economic front as it moves away from a government-run economy to one more dependent on open markets.

Eighteen months ago, Bachar said, the government of Israel was in a near-crisis situation, exacerbated by the fact that, under those circumstances, it was unable to borrow in the foreign markets. Government expenditures were high, the deficit was growing and the market was shrinking, increasing the country's debt substantially.

The good news on the political front was the tacit agreement between newly appointed Finance Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon allowing Netanyahu to act without Sharon's interference. Israel, Bachar claims, benefited from that.

As a result, the Ministry of Finance created a strict economic policy adopted by the government to reverse the crisis and sustain economic expansion. The four pillars of the government's new economic policy were to shrink the government, create incentives for people to go to work, reduce private sector taxes and privatize government businesses. There is a clear government commitment, Bachar said, to reducing government involvement in the economy.

To "shrink" the government, it implemented a budget discipline that reduced government expenditures substantially — for example, approving the first public-sector wage cuts in Israel's history. Guarantees received from the U.S. government also provided Israel with the opportunity to go to the foreign markets and borrow. Israel's commitment to sticking to its budget discipline was passed into law, sending a strong positive signal to the market.

The government has also reduced welfare payments and reduced or eliminated personal tax rates for people earning low wages to provide them with incentives to go to work. Previously, Bachar said, too many people were better off staying at home than going to work. Government allowances for people who could go to work amounted to 6.4 percent of GDP (about $6.5 billion). All transfer payments in 2002 came to 13 percent of GDP.

In conjunction with shrinking the public sector, Israel needed to give the private sector more fuel. It did this by creating private-sector incentives, among them, a reduction in the corporate tax rate to 30 percent from 36 percent by 2007 and of the VAT by 1 percent.

Bachar also said the government is privatizing entities such as El Al, which would have been unheard of 20 years ago given security concerns. Its goal is to get out of the markets and become "irrelevant" over time.

As Israel moves from a socialist to a capitalist economy, it has only just begun to develop its capital markets. Credit, Bachar pointed out, is virtually nonexistent through any intermediary other than its banks, which do 95 percent of the lending in the country. Credit card companies in Israel are also held by the banks. Capital is not only expensive, but Israel's two largest banks are government run. Very few people have access to capital, with 70 percent of lending going to 1 percent of the borrowers. Its goal is to increase competition by reducing concentration and conflicts of interest, opening the way for other financial intermediaries such as money market funds, mortgage-backed securities, deposit insurance, derivatives, etc.

Bachar spoke to guests of the Milken Institute and the Government of Israel Economic Mission in Los Angeles, which co-hosted the event. His visit is one of the Institute's ongoing series of programs and initiatives focusing on the Israel and Middle East economies. Learn more.
blurb: Joseph Bachar, Director General of the Ministry of Finance for the State of Israel, talked about the substantial progress has been made on Israel’s economic front as it moves away from a government-run economy to one more dependent on open markets.

Name: An Ocean Blueprint for the 21st Century
Description:
More than $15 billion annually is being spent on space research by NASA. How much is spent on another great expanse about which we have much to learn — earth's oceans? Only $630 million a year, said Jerry Schubel, President and CEO the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, who led this roundtable discussion.

As a coastal state with four of the 13 national marine sanctuaries, California needs to take a leadership position not only in vision, but in implementation of ocean conservation, he said. California is already a highly urbanized state. At its current rate of growth, 75 percent of the population will live within 50 miles of the coastline.

California has paved 95 percent of its wetlands, creating impermeable land cover, transformed the watershed and created harbors where they did not exist. Marina del Rey is the largest small-craft harbor in the world and the port of Los Angeles/Long Beach is the third largest in the world.

Melting snow caps due to global warming are contributing to our water shortage problem and the sea level is expected to rise at least six inches as a result, he said.

These issues must be addressed now to prevent catastrophe in the not-too-distant future, Schubel said.

We must create an environment that would have occurred naturally, he said. We have the knowledge; now we need the appropriate application by policy makers, scientists and the public. Furthermore, the model for protecting our coasts must be a regional one, he added. In the past, we've addressed individual problems along the coastline, but the impact extends well inland.

A report on these issues, An Ocean Blueprint for the 21st Century, which was discussed by participants, cites five key areas for attention:

1. Improved governance
2. Sound science for wise decisions
3. Education of the public
4. Specific management challenges
5. Implementation and funding

Action taken in California includes passage of the Marine Life Protection Act, The Marine Life Management Act, the Water Quality Bill and the California Beach Preservation Act, establishment of an ocean council, a $21-million coastal ocean currents monitoring system and engaging the philanthropic community in funding much of the work that needs to be done under these laws.

Ultimately, heightened public awareness is critical to the success of ocean conservation, so a series of public service announcements is also being planned.

Brian Baird, assistant secretary for ocean and coastal policy for the California Resource Agency, said that non-source pollution is the number one source of ocean pollution, and that people need to become aware of how their everyday actions impact the ocean before they will change their behavior. Local measures, he said, are often the most effective.

Success will be the outcome of a shared vision of where we are headed, a partnership between local government and the public, and an annual accounting that demonstrates the economic benefits of action taken.

This seminar is part of the Institute's ongoing environmental finance research, which focuses on using capital markets to help fund conservation efforts. Lean more.
blurb: Jerry Schubel, President and CEO the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, was  joined by environmental experts from the Milken Institute and business, state and local officials to formulate strategies aimed at promoting the long-term welfare of the California coast.

Name: Global Conference 2005
blurb: The Global Conference is an intensive learning and networking opportunity for the world's leading decision makers. Over the course of three days, more than 2,000 leaders in business (including hundreds of CEOs and other top corporate executives), government, philanthropy, journalism and academics gather to examine current public policy issues and debate strategic solutions.

Name: The Savings and Loan Crisis: Lessons from a Regulatory Failure
Description:
Between 1980 and early 1995, more than 5,000 savings and loans, commercial banks and credit unions failed in the U.S. The cost of resolving this crisis exceeded $190 billion.

In this talk, based on their book, The Savings and Loan Crisis: Lessons from a Regulatory Failure, editors Glenn Yago and James Barth explained what led to these failures and, more importantly, what we learned from them.

"The savings and loan crisis is a textbook case of financial institutions breaking down through a unique combination of macroeconomic conditions, interest rate and tax policy shifts, structural changes in capital markets and financial institutions, and, ultimately, regulatory chokeholds and policy missteps that created a perfect financial policy storm," said Yago, Director of Capital Studies at the Milken Institute.

Among the missteps he cited were:

  • Federal restrictions that kept S&Ls from participating in many financial activities, forcing them to rely on interest-rate-dependent home mortgages.
  • Poor incentives, which kept involvent S&Ls open far too long, thus adding to the final cleanup cost.
  • Misleading accounting procedures used by S&Ls.
  • Federal regulations that only exacerbated the problem.

Yago said lawmakers, regulators, the Executive Branch and S&L executives all responded to the growing crisis too late, too slowly and too unevenly.

"Most S&Ls didn't fall, but were pushed by government regulations," Yago said.

Among the current concerns for U.S. regulators are the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC), the quasi-government agency that insures private pension plans and is $23 billion in the red, and Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two other government-sponsored institutions whose failure would inevitably be picked up by taxpayers.

Barth also talked about China's financial system, where more than half of its bank assets are in state-owned banks, raising concerns for a potential crisis.

Barth and Yago said the savings and loan crisis taught the important lesson that one must design banking regulations in such a manner as to allow institutions to adapt to changing competitive market forces. This message applies not just to the U.S., but also to every other country around the world — almost all of which have suffered some kind of banking crisis in recent decades.

To lessen the likelihood of similar financial industry collapses in the future, countries must have flexible banking laws and regulations, better accounting methods, and improve incentives for regulators and owners.

"The bottom line for us is the importance of democratizing capital markets to increase the level of economic participation in a way that allows for the diversification of risk and the maximization of rewards among a broader pool of people so they can finance the future — of their homes, their businesses and their countries," Yago said.

Yago is Director of Capital Studies at the Milken Institute. He specializes in financial innovations, financial institutions and capital markets, and has extensively analyzed public policy and its relation to high-yield markets, initial public offerings, restructuring, and job creation and retention strategies.

Barth, a Milken Institute Senior Fellow, is the Lowder Eminent Scholar in Finance at Auburn University. His research has focused on financial institutions and capital markets, both domestic and global, with special emphasis on regulatory issues, most recently having served as leader of an international team advising the People's Bank of China on banking reform. Barth was an appointee of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush as chief economist of the Office of Thrift Supervision until November 1989 and previously served as the chief economist of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, federal agencies overseeing the savings and loan industry.

View the slide presentation
Speakers: Glenn Yago, Ph.D.,Director, Capital Studies, Milken Institute and James Barth, Ph.D., Senior Fellow, Milken Institute
blurb: Glenn Yago and James Barth demonstrate how this $190-billion failure could have been avoided and what the U.S. and other countries can do to lessen the likelihood of similar financial industry collapses in the future.

Name: Pharmaceutical R&D: The Changing Economic Environment
Description:
Despite an increase in pharmaceutical research and development spending, fewer and fewer drugs are being developed because companies today focus on the more profitable "blockbuster" drugs, said Senior Fellow Tomas Philipson. Because of this, there is less innovation taking place in the industry.

The tradeoff, he added, is that often these blockbuster drugs have the ability to help a lot of people.

"The industry is getting better at targeting big markets," Philipson said.

Finding the right balance between profits, drug prices and innovation is tricky, he said. There are many forces battering the pharmaceutical industry's research and development abilities, both political and economic.

One of the stickiest issues facing consumers, drug companies and government officials is how to lower prices for drugs, especially for seniors, while giving drug companies enough incentives to continue spending money on R&D innovation.

By lowering prices on American drugs, you will inevitably reduce drug company profits, and thus, reduce the amount of money going into R&D. Doing this, Philipson said, would reduce the amount of new drugs coming to market — or result in drugs that otherwise would have been created from not being produced at all.

"We can make drugs cheap for seniors today, but the research and development investment would be substantially reduced," he said. The consequence of that, he added, is "the next generation will be less healthy." Thus, today's debate over re-importation is not, as it is often described, a "free-trade issue," but one involving "intergenerational welfare," he said.

On the related issue of whether the U.S. government should allow drug re-importation from Canada, Philipson said such a move would not significantly affect the cost of drugs to Americans, but could be very costly to Canadians.

Because Canada represents such a small segment of the pharmaceutical market — about 6 percent — drug companies would not allow prices to their biggest market, the U.S., to come down to match Canada's. Rather, Canada's would come up to match those in the U.S., he said.

Another tradeoff we make is the patents we give to new drugs, giving drug companies exclusive sales rights. This monopoly provides them with the profits they need to pour money back into developing new drugs, but the tradeoff is higher drug prices.

In the debate over drug prices, the question often comes down to, which would you rather have — new drugs or cheap drugs?

"We haven't figured out an alternative for innovation, other than patents," Philipson said. Looking at current trends, he is "cautiously pessimistic" that this dynamic will change anytime soon.

Philipson is a professor in the Irving B. Harris Graduate School of Public Policy Studies and a faculty member of the University of Chicago Department of Economics and law school. An expert in the field of health economics, Philipson recently served in the U.S. government as Senior Economic Advisor to the Administrator of The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). Philipson earned his undergraduate degree in mathematics at Uppsala University in his native Sweden and his Ph.D. in economics at the University of Pennsylvania.
Speakers: Tomas J. Philipson, Ph.D., Milken Institute Senior Fellow; Professor, Irving B. Harris Graduate School of Public Policy Studies, the University of Chicago Department of Economics
blurb: Tomas Philipson, Milken Institute Senior Fellow and professor of economics at the University of Chicago discussed the fallout from the rising costs of drug discovery and the changing environment for investing in pharmaceutical R&D.

Name: Hydrogen Highway Financial Innovations Laboratory
Description:
It is the stuff of novels, television drama and scientific conferences, but is the Hydrogen Highway a reality or mere wishful thinking?

In January 2004, California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger introduced the California Hydrogen Highway Network to accelerate the introduction of a hydrogen-powered transportation system in California. Its purpose is to create a network of hydrogen stations throughout the state by 2010, reaching 2,000 stations and 2 million vehicles by 2030.

Is it viable? Many in the field seem to think so.

The Hydrogen Highway Financial Innovations Laboratory held Nov. 18 at the Institute brought together 30 experts in public and private finance, technology, industry and policy to discuss viable pathways to creating a "hydrogen economy." At the end of the day, the participants, who broke into focus groups addressing financing mechanisms, technological development, societal issues and cross-cutting solutions, came up with recommendations to be submitted to Schwarzenegger.

The essential ingredients of a viable hydrogen economy, the group agreed, were political will and cash. Despite formidable barriers to implementation, motivation is also a driving force toward achieving that end. Early-stage key players identified by the group were hydrogen producers and equipment manufacturers. These include government, project financiers, big auto OEMs, energy utilities, hydrogen retailers (stations) and renewable-energy players. Initial end users identified were fleets and government, and only in the long-term, public consumers.

A clearly identified downside was the lack of private capital available for infrastructure. Venture capitalists are not interested in government-subsidized markets, nor will private investors fund projects that have no revenue stream for at least five years. Private investors need clearly defined, focused opportunities, they said, as well as a broader market than one limited to California. On the upside, while infrastructure will have to be funded by public means, models exist for converting government-built infrastructure to private projects, among them, the solar industry and the defense industry.

In the technology and public policy arenas, members determined that the central issue is how to direct current technology toward the policy of hydrogen economy. They also looked at existing infrastructure that could be utilized in this regard, including railroad and cell-phone infrastructure, military bases and Cal Trans stations, and agreed to study natural gas to determine the existence of a parallel track.

Among the societal drivers cited were energy scarcity, energy diversity, carbon dioxide emissions and global warming, yielding benefits such as better air quality, job creation and export opportunities.

The general consensus emerged that hydrogen is the energy future, leaving the question of how California becomes a leader in that future. Public awareness and buy-in were considered critical by the group and they raised the possibility of an initiative similar to the voter-approved stem cell initiative as a starting point.

The technology team felt that, realistically, hydrogen would gain a major foothold among the population closer to the year 2030, citing the cost of the car as one factor and hydrogen's adoption as a commodity by major oil companies as another.

Name: They Made America - From the Steam Engine to the Search Engine
Description:
They Made America is the title of his book, and in his 90-minute appearance at the Milken Institute, author Sir Harold Evans made it clear why the innovators he writes about indeed helped make America what it is today.

These are not just people who discovered or invented things. These are entrepreneurs who took discoveries and ideas and turned them into products that millions of people could use and enjoy.

"Edison learned to only make things that people wanted," Evans said. "That's what Americans are good at."

Among the innovators in his pantheon that Evans cited during his talk were:

  • Sam Colt, inventor of the repeating revolver, which changed warfare.
  • Isaac Singer, inventor of the Singer sewing machine, which vastly improved productivity and employment in the clothing industry.
  • Lewis Tappan, who in the 1800s, created the world's first credit rating system.
  • Theodore Judah, who gave us the transcontinental railway, linking California with the rest of America.
  • Leo Baekeland, who created plastic.
  • Amadeo Giannini, who created "the people's bank" — today's Bank of America — by liberalizing lending policies to help the middle class and working people.
  • Martha Harper, a servant girl who started America's first retail franchise network.
  • Juan Trippe, whose company, Pan American Airways, pioneered commercial jet airline travel.
  • Ida Rosenthal, who produced the Maidenform bra.
  • Samuel Insull, who helped bring cheap electricity to the masses.
  • Jean Nidetch, who started Weight Watchers.
  • Estee Lauder, who founded the international cosmetics company.
  • Malcom McLean, who came up with the idea of placing trucking containers directly on ships — an innovation that created today's global marketplace.
  • Gary Kildall, the founder of the personal computer revolution.
  • Herbert Boyer, who helped usher in the biotechnology era.
  • Raymond Damadian, who developed the MRI, allowing doctors to see the inside of the human body.

A common element among these innovators, Evans said, is they created things that allowed many more people to enjoy what previously only the rich or elite could take advantage of, from airline travel and cars to cameras and electricity.

They also tended to be common people with extraordinary ideas.

"So many innovations came from ordinary people, from unexpected sources," Evans said. "That's the nature of innovation."

Evans is an historian, author and journalist with a distinguished career leading some of the world's most well-known newspapers and magazines. He was the editor of the Sunday Times of London for 14 years and then the Times of London before coming to the U.S. in 1984. Evans was founding editor of Conde Nast Traveler, president and publisher of Random House, editorial director and vice chairman of U.S. News & World Report, Atlantic magazine, Fast Company and the New York Daily News and is currently editor-at-large of The Week magazine. In 2002, Britain's journalists voted Evans the greatest all-time British newspaper editor. He received a knighthood in 2004 for his services to journalism.
Speakers: Sir Harold Evans, historian, author and journalist; editor-at-large of The Week magazine.
blurb: Sir Harold Evans, one of the most celebrated journalists of our time and author of They Made America, describes the innovators who changed our lives.

Name: "Off the Record" with Tomas Philipson
Description:
America's pharmaceutical industry has become one of the most profitable and important in the world thanks to the tremendous advances that have been made in medicine in recent years and an aging population. But it has also become a lightning rod for some of the most contentious public policy issues of our time — from the re-importation of drugs from Canada to the drug approval process.

Finding common ground on these issues is important to not only patients, but the drug companies themselves, whose ability to develop news drugs depends on their ability to get a return on their research and development dollars, said Senior Fellow Tomas Philipson, a professor in the Irving B. Harris Graduate School of Public Policy Studies at the University of Chicago.

Philipson, an expert on the economics of health care, discussed the many forces that are affecting these returns, including the recently approved Medicare Modernization Act. The drug benefit plan portion of this legislation, which becomes effective on Jan. 1, 2006, is government's effort to address the increasing demand from our growing elderly population and is evidence of a general downward pressure on drug prices, he said.

Also threatening the return on the industry's R&D investment is the increase in the popularity of cheaper generic drugs.

"Half the prescriptions written today are generic, up from 18 percent in 1984," said Philipson.

Although R&D spending has increased, the number of new pharmaceutical products introduced to the market has actually decreased, he said. The challenge is finding the appropriate balance or "trade-off between speed-to-market and drug safety issues."

In addition to the School of Public Policy Studies, Philipson is a faculty member of the University of Chicago Department of Economics and law school. Philipson recently served as Senior Economic Advisor to the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration and the administrator of The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

The "Off the Record With ..." series of private meetings with individuals of distinction is open to members of the Milken Institute Associates. To join, please contact Jared Carney, Director of Marketing, at (310) 570-4676, or by e-mail at jcarney@milkeninstitute.org.

Name: After the Palestinian elections: Is there a real window of opportunity in the Middle East?
Description:
Dore Gold, former Israeli Ambassador to the U.N. and a central figure in the Middle East peace process, said the recent election of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas offers a "small window of opportunity" for a major breakthrough in that troubled part of the world.

But he is not overly optimistic.

"Abbas fully believes that violence has completely backfired," said Gold during a private meeting at the Milken Institute. "From a tactical perspective, he believes it doesn't work."

However, strategically Abbas does not appear willing to actually dismantle the terrorists' infrastructure of Hamas or his Fatah organization, Gold added. For that reason, getting Abbas to convince those who support violence to stop their attacks against Israel remains a tall order, he said.

"Can he stop the attacks?" Gold asked. "The jury is still out."

According to Gold, the near-term future will bring three developments:

  • Abbas will have continuing trouble from the fundamentalist groups like Hamas, as well has his own Fatah faction.
  • Increased military action by Israel is likely.
  • It will be difficult to get a full-time cease-fire in place.

In addition to his remarks about the peace process, Gold also touched on a number of other subjects, including Iraq, Israel's internal politics and the proposed withdraw of Israel from Gaza.

Gold is President of the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs. He was the 11th Permanent Representative of Israel to the United Nations (1997-1999) and foreign policy advisor to former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He also served as an advisor to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, with whom he traveled to Washington and attended the 2003 Aqaba Summit with President George W. Bush.

He is the author of numerous books and articles on the Middle East, among them U.S. Military Strategy in the Middle East, Hatred's Kingdom: How Saudi Arabia Supports the New Global Terrorism and Tower of Babble: How the United Nations Has Fueled Global Chaos.

His appearance is part of an ongoing dialogue about the Middle East sponsored by the Milken Institute, whose Capital Studies group has numerous economic development initiatives in Israel and surrounding nations. (Read more.)
blurb: Dore Gold, former Israeli Ambassador to the U.N., says the recent election of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas offers a “small window of opportunity” for a major breakthrough in that troubled part of the world.

Name: Trading and Exchanges – Why People Trade
Description:
So you think you know it all when it comes to trading stocks, eh? Well, think again, says USC Professor Larry Harris, author of Trading and Exchanges: Market Microstructure for Practitioners, a book about why people trade.

If you're like many people, your main purpose in trading is retirement — either saving for it or selling stocks to pay for it. But there are a whole lot of other people out there trading for many other reasons. And since the equities markets need winners as well as losers to operate efficiently, you can't make money unless you take advantage of others' blunders, said Harris.

"Trading is, ultimately, a zero-sum game," he said. "Understanding why people trade — and with whom they're trading — is very important. If you're going to beat the market, you have to find out who's making mistakes."

Among the most common mistakes that traders make, he said, are:

• I gambled when I intended to speculate.
• I tried to speculate when I intended to invest.
• I held on because I wanted to be right.
• I traded on stale information.
• I traded on the wrong model.
• I traded when liquidity was scarce.
• I traded too much.

Harris offered the audience a taxonomy of various types of traders, from speculators to dealers, hedgers to tax avoiders. Some trade based on news about a certain industry or company. Others trade because they think they know something others don't and can "beat" the market.

Ultimately, Harris said, trading is not just about being smart or having good ideas. Just like in a sport, you have to know the other players and their weaknesses.

"Winning requires good ideas," he said, "but you also have to understand why the other side will lose."

Larry Harris is the immediate past chief economist of the Securities and Exchange Commission, where he contributed extensively to the development of regulations implementing Sarbanes-Oxley and to the resolution of the mutual fund timing crisis.

He left the commission in July 2004 to resume his appointment as the Fred V. Keenan Chair in Finance at the USC Marshall School of Business. Professor Harris is an expert in market microstructure and investment management. His introduction to trading, Trading and Exchanges: Market Microstructure for Practitioners, is widely regarded as the definitive treatment of the subject. Harris earned his Ph.D. in economics at the University of Chicago.
Speakers: Larry Harris, Former Chief Economist, Securities and Exchange Commission; Professor, USC Marshall School of Business
blurb: Larry Harris, former chief economist of the Securities and Exchange Commission, offers insight into the world of financial traders - who they are and why they trade.

Name: "Off the Record" with Thomas J. Wilson
Description:
Thomas J. Wilson, president of The Allstate Corporation's home and auto businesses, addressed members of the Milken Institute Associates on January 26. He talked about covering risk, especially the so-called mega-risks like terrorism and hurricanes.

Wilson is president of Allstate Protection, the $23-billion property and casualty unit of The Allstate Corporation. He also served as the president of Allstate Financial, the company's financial services unit, and as chief financial officer. During his tenure as CFO, he received the Alexander Hamilton Award from CFO Magazine for strength in financial management. Wilson's career has included tenure at Sears, Roebuck & Co., Dean Witter and Amoco.

The "Off the Record With ..." series of private meetings with individuals of distinction is open to members of the Milken Institute Associates. To join, please contact Jared Carney, Director of Marketing and Project Development, at (310) 570-4676, or by e-mail at jcarney@milkeninstitute.org.

Name: "Off the Record" with Michael Speier
Description:
Michael Speier, Managing Editor of Variety, addressed members of the Milken Institute Associates on the impact of movies in Los Angeles, the U.S. and around the world. Coming just days before the Academy Awards, his talk focused on the importance of the Oscars — and the considerable economic and professional cachet that comes from winning.

Speier has spent the past seven years as managing editor of Special Reports, editor of the Gotham edition of Variety and co-TV critic. Speier, who joined Variety in 1997, is a 1991 graduate of Syracuse University and has a master's degree from the University of North Texas.

The "Off the Record With ..." series of private meetings with individuals of distinction is open to members of the Milken Institute Associates. To join, please contact Jared Carney, Director of Marketing and Project Development, at (310) 570-4676, or by e-mail at jcarney@milkeninstitute.org.

Name: Israel Economic Summit - Economic Strategies for Israeli Diplomatic Missions and Consuls of Economic Affairs
Description:
Milken Institute scholars participated in a three-day economic summit for Israeli diplomatic missions and economic consuls, a first-of-its-kind event. The diplomats gathered at the Beverly Hilton Hotel here in Los Angeles to hammer out economic strategies for a range of issues that included investing in biotech, Israel-U.S. activities, the relationship between diplomacy and the economy, and development strategies.

High-profile faces among the presenters were Michael Milken, Chairman of the Milken Institute, Yair Landau, Vice Chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, and Stanley Gold, Chairman of Shamrock Capital. Several Los Angeles-area businesspeople and members of the investment community participated as well.

Ranking Israeli presenters included Yoram Ben-Ze'ev, Deputy Director General for North America and Yossi Gal, Deputy Director for Economic Affairs, both of the Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The economic conference, held June 5-7, was organized by the Consulate General of Israel in Los Angeles in conjunction with the Milken Institute.
Venue:
Beverly Hilton Hotel
Beverly Hills, CA
blurb: Israeli diplomats and economic consuls to North America gathered for a 3-day economic summit - the first of its kind - in Los Angeles.

Name: Trial Lawyers Inc.: California
Description:
While California has made progress in reforming its litigation industry, much more is needed to hold down costs from awards and settlements that hurt the state's economy, according to several speakers at a panel discussion put on by the Manhattan Institute.

Citing three sectors in particular that have become profitable niches for trial lawyers in California — construction defects, employment and securities class-action — James Copland, Director of the Manhattan Institute's Center for Legal Policy, said litigators have a tight grip on the state. Los Angeles in particular, he said, has become known as a plaintiff-friendly place.

"Los Angeles is particularly bad as a jurisdiction for litigation," said Copland, whose center wrote a report, "Trial Lawyers, Inc.: California," on which the seminar was based.

Thomas Girardi, a highly successful trial lawyer with Girardi & Keese, defended litigators as protectors of good business against unethical firms that cut corners to save money.

"If you're running a good company, then you need me," he said. "I'm the equalizer."

Also on the panel were John Sullivan, President of the Civil Justice Association of California, and moderator Stephen Bainbridge, a law professor at UCLA.

Businessman William Simon, Jr., who is running for state treasurer in next year's election, gave the keynote speech. He supported the need for tort reform in California, arguing that the state's civil justice system "has been hijacked by a small group of lawyers."

"It's time to return balance and common sense to the civil justice system," he said.

Simon urged other lawyers to fight for changes, such as tightening the standards for filing class-action lawsuits, enacting a "loser pays" system and creating sanctions for lawyers who file frivolous suits.

The event was hosted by the Milken Institute. For more information about "Trial Lawyers Inc.," visit the Manhattan Institute's web site at www.manhattan-institute.org. (Note: This link takes you to a web site outside of milkeninstitute.org. To return, hit the back button on your web browser.)
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA
blurb: Does the trial lawyer industry in California hurt the state's businesses and economy? That was a key question in this seminar put on by the Manhattan Institute and hosted by the Milken Institute.

Name: 2005 California State of the State Conference
blurb: More than 500 business leaders and public policy makers gathered for the 7th annual State of the State Conference to discuss California's economy and future.

Name: Freakonomics: A Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything
Description:
When they first agreed to collaborate on a story, University of Chicago economist Steven Levitt and New York Times writer Stephen Dubner didn't think too much would come of it. Levitt didn't understand why a reporter would be interested in his sometimes arcane, often counter-intuitive economic theories, and Dubner didn't think that many people would read a story about an economist.

They were both wrong.

Many book tours and a best-seller later, both men say they are surprised at the popularity of Levitt's theories and of their book, Freakonomics.

Speaking in front of a full house at the Milken Institute, Levitt and Dubner described some of the research findings, which are also outlined in their book, including:

  • The misguided solution — a $3 fine — that a day-care center came up with to cut down on the number of parents who showed up late to pick up their children. In essence, the fine told parents it was OK to be late as long as you were willing to pay, and thus, late pickups actually increased.
  • The discovery, through a detailed examination of test scores, that teachers in the Chicago Public School system were cheating to raise the test scores of their students. The incentive? Teachers whose students tested poorly could be passed over for a raise or promotion.
  • The economics of the crack cocaine business and why, as their book put it, "drug dealers still live with their moms." The bottom line: the hierarchy of drug dealers is not much different than the average fast-food chain. Those at the top make a lot of money, but those at the bottom make very little.
  • The bagel man — the businessman who learned the fine points of honesty and dishonesty in office workers when he left collection boxes for payment. (Examples: Workers in smaller offices are more honest than those in big ones; and unseasonably good weather results in more payments than unseasonably bad weather.)

The key to his findings, Levitt said, is knowing what to measure and how to measure it — and having the data to study.

"At its root, economics is the study of incentives," Levitt said.

About the speakers:

Steven D. Levitt is a Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago and an editor of The Journal of Political Economy. In January 2004, he was awarded the John Bates Clark medal for the economist under 40 who has made the greatest contribution to the discipline by the American Economic Association. Stephen J. Dubner writes for the New York Times and The New Yorker, and is the bestselling author of Turbulent Souls and Confessions of a Hero Worshiper.
Speakers:
Steven D. Levitt, Professor of Economics, University of Chicago
Stephen J. Dubner, Journalist and Author
blurb: Economist Steven D. Levitt, described by The Wall Street Journal as "a maverick treasure hunter who relies for success on his wit, pluck and disregard for conventional wisdom," and writer Stephen J. Dubner talk about their bestseller, Freakonomics.

Name: Global Conference 2006
blurb: More than 2,500 leaders in business, government, philanthropy, journalism and academics gathered in Los Angeles April 24-26, 2006, for the 9th annual Global Conference.

Name: The Economic Impact of Hurricane Katrina
Description:
The devastation left by Hurricane Katrina could cost the U.S. economy an initial loss of 400,000 jobs in September and reduce monthly average job creation by 30,000 jobs for the rest of 2005. It could also increase oil by $10 a barrel and lead to a nearly 1 percent decline in GDP growth in the fourth quarter of this year.

But next year, when the reconstruction efforts get into full swing, the recovery will turn things around — adding those 30,000 jobs back per month, easing the price of oil and increasing the GDP by more than a percentage point during the second and third quarters.

These are the preliminary findings of two of the Milken Institute's regional economists who've studied the potential impact of Katrina on the U.S. and Gulf economies.

Ross DeVol, Director of Regional Economics, and Perry Wong, Senior Research Economist, told members of the Milken Institute Associates that based on what has happened after previous natural disasters, the short-term job losses will be made up by increases in such areas as construction once rebuilding is fully under way.

And given the perception by many in the public that the federal government did not respond fast enough to the Katrina disaster, DeVol expects a massive outlay of federal dollars in the rebuilding effort.

"There will be no expense spared," DeVol said.

Insurance payouts for Katrina are expected to be the most for any hurricane cleanup in U.S. history — anywhere from $20 billion to $45 billion. The federal government could end up spending as much as $150 billion.

One of the key questions is how to rebuild New Orleans, which is dependent on tourism and lacks the knowledge-based workforce that is crucial for economic growth.

"It's not just the rebuilding that's important, but what kind of rebuilding we do," said Wong. "The danger is if we try to put it back just as it was."

Update: After Hurricane Rita hit the Gulf Coast in September, DeVol and Wong updated their findings about the impact of the two hurricanes on the local and national economies. Their findings can be found in the slides (above), but here is a summary:

Delayed economic activity caused by the massive evacuations in the Houston region, combined with the economic dislocations in the affected area, will reduce real GDP growth by an additional 0.2 percentage point in the third and fourth quarters of 2005 beyond the 0.5 and 1.0 percent reductions already anticipated due to Hurricane Katrina. Reported job growth will be reduced by an additional 5,000 per month, on top of the 30,000 attributable to Katrina, for the remainder of 2005. The price of natural gas should increase by nearly $1 per million British thermal unit from what would have been expected before Rita hit.

Rita may also delay the reconstruction efforts in New Orleans somewhat because of renewed flooding, but rebuilding will still turn things around in 2006 — adding back 30,000 jobs per month from Katrina, plus another 4,000 per month in southeast Texas and southwest Louisiana. The easing of oil and refined-petroleum-products prices, along with reconstruction, will increase GDP growth by more than a percentage point during the second and third quarters of 2006.

Learn more about the Milken Institute Associates.

Name: Structural Reform in the Israeli Capital Market
Description:
Israel has made great economic strides in the last two decades thanks to a series of economic reforms packages begun in 1985 and tight economic policies designed to control inflation.

But as Amir Barnea stated in his visit to the Milken Institute, there is still a ways to go as Israel moves away from a government-controlled economy to one more driven by market forces.

Capital-market development has been identified as a fundamental strategy for Israel. The biggest obstacle in this task is reforming the banking sector to allow for a viable secondary market. Israel's banking sector is largely dominated by two banks that account for 63 percent of both total assets and deposits in the sector. Furthermore, loans account for 81 percent of corporate-debt financing in Israel, of which 74 percent are bank loans. And of these bank loans, 66 percent are from the two largest banks. This large concentration in banking exposes the banks to financial risks, forcing them to absorb much of the economic loss during recessions, as seen in 2001.

Barnea, a professor of Finance at the Arison School of Business at the Interdisciplinary Center, Herziliya, who has been helping lead the country's reform efforts, said that diversification of risk is crucial to protecting Israel's economy against future financial shocks, as well as promoting efficient and open markets. A series of reforms being considered includes implementing regulatory standards for banks by encouraging them to divest their interest in provident fund management, insurance and mutual funds to other entities.

The proposed reforms will allow the capital markets to introduce new financial instruments such as asset-backed securities and securitization for Israel. This will ultimately benefit entrepreneurial activity, attract foreign investment and provide capital access for investors by enhancing the efficiency and sophistication of Israel's capital markets.

Barnea, in partnership with the Milken Institute, hopes to monitor — on a monthly basis — the effects of the reforms to determine changes in the cost of intermediation, consumer choice, and the cost of credit and their impact on the economy.

His visit is part of the ongoing work of the Milken Institute and its partners in Israel to create a more vibrant, market-based economy in that country.
blurb: Amir Barnea, a professor of Finance at the Arison School of Business at the Interdisciplinary Center, Herziliya, describes the tremendous strides made in recent years, and the challenges ahead, as Israel moves from a government-controlled economy to a market-based economy.

Name: The Economics of Terrorism
Description:
For most people, the "war on terrorism" is fought in traditional ways — upgrading security in our airports, military attacks on known terrorist targets, and so on. But as discussed in this special Forum, there are other ways to fight this global battle.

"The Economics of Terrorism" brought together a group of leading experts to describe how economic analysis and theory can help in the war on terrorism. They offered an economic analysis of factors that lead to terrorism, such as the supply of and demand for weapons — especially weapons of mass destruction — suicide bombers and other recruits, and financing.

They also provided an analysis of major risk-reduction decisions and the impact of risk perceptions on economic decisions to prevent terrorism. And they discussed the potential impact of a terrorist attack on our ports and other targets, as well as the costs of preventing and responding to such a disaster.

Panelists:

Michael D. Intriligator is a Senior Fellow at the Milken Institute and Professor of Economics, Political Science, and Policy Studies at UCLA. From 1982 to 1992, he directed the UCLA Center for International and Strategic Affairs, the predecessor of the current Burkle Center for International Relations. His most recent work has concerned globalization, terrorism, global security and the future of the Russian economy.

James E. Moore II is Professor of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Public Policy and Management, and Civil Engineering at the University of Southern California. He specializes in transportation engineering, transportation systems and other infrastructure systems. Moore's research interests include risk management of infrastructure networks subject to natural hazards and terrorist threats.

Christopher Thornberg is a Senior Economist with the UCLA Anderson Forecast. He has been involved in a number of studies measuring the impact of important events on the economy, including the September 11 terrorist attacks.

Alvin Toffler, Author and Futurist, is principal of Toffler & Associates, a consulting company, and author of more than one dozen books, including the bestsellers Future Shock and Third Wave. He wrote about the proliferation of computers, the advent of cable television, niche markets, the shift to work-at-home, corporate restructuring, the break-up of the Soviet Union, the shift to a global economy and dozens of other scenarios long before they appeared in our nomenclature.

Peter Katona (moderator) is Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine at the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA in Infectious Diseases. He has worked at the Center for Disease Control and Prevention as an EIS Officer, and for Apria Healthcare as the corporate medical director. Katona has been a consultant to the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services, on the development of an information management system geared toward biological terrorism preparedness (known as the Health Alert Network) and as medical consultant to the county Emergency Medical Services Agency. He is co-founder of Biological Threat Mitigation, a bio-terror consulting firm.
Speakers:
Michael Intriligator, Senior Fellow, Milken Institute
Peter Katona, Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine, UCLA Medical School
James E. Moore II, Professor and Chair, Daniel J. Epstein Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, USC
Christopher Thornberg, Senior Economist, UCLA Anderson Forecast
Alvin Toffler, Author and Futurist
blurb: "The Economics of Terrorism" brought together a group of leading experts to describe how economic analysis and theory can help in the war on terrorism.

Name: The Pro-Growth Progressive: An Economic Strategy for Shared Prosperity
Description:
The debate over how to promote prosperity in the U.S. has become bitter and hostile, says Gene Sperling, President Clinton's chief economic advisor.

On the right are those who have total faith in pro-growth policies. On the left are those who want to slow down globalization and offer more protections for workers. Both views are recipes for trouble, said Sperling.

The pro-growth approach helps mainly the wealthy and has created a "winner-take-all" economy. The protectionism course slows down the pace of inevitable change and innovation in a global economy, which can hurt job creation.

Fortunately, Sperling said, there's a third way, which he describes as the "pro-growth progressive" approach.

"Our goal is not GDP growth per se," Sperling said. "Our vision is an America that grows together. We either grow together or we grow apart."

Sperling said changes in technology and the global marketplace have roiled markets and businesses worldwide, as low-wage countries like India and China take a bigger and bigger share of the economy.

That has led to some disruptions in the U.S. labor market, which has jeopardized middle-class jobs, he said. We need policies that will help workers affected by globalization get themselves back on their feet.

"We have to make falling less severe," he said.

While criticizing Republicans for not doing enough to help the middle and lower classes, Sperling added that Democrats can't just be the party "when things go bad." They must have positive ideas. They need to talk about wealth creation. They need an optimistic message.

***

Sperling is a Senior Fellow at the Center for American Progress. He was President Clinton's National Economic Advisor and head of the National Economic Council from 1997 to 2001, and deputy national economic advisor from 1993-1996. He also served as a top economic advisor for the Kerry-Edwards presidential campaign. A columnist and commentator for Bloomberg News, he has been a contributing writer and consultant to the television series "The West Wing," serves as director of the Center for Universal Education at the Council on Foreign Relations and is chair of the U.S. Global Campaign for Education. He is the author of The Pro-Growth Progressive: An Economic Strategy for Shared Prosperity. He attended the University of Minnesota, Wharton Business School and Yale Law School.
Speakers: Gene Sperling, Senior Fellow, Center for American Progress; former National Economic Advisor
blurb: Gene Sperling, President Clinton's National Economic Advisor, discusses his new proposals for national economic success that respect both the power of free markets and the need for vigorous public policies based on progressive values.

Name: Rethinking Bank Regulation: Till Angels Govern
Description:
After six years of research that involved two in-depth surveys, hundreds of questions, painstaking cross-checking of data and exhaustive follow-up, James Barth and Gerard Caprio realized there is tremendous diversity in banking supervisory and regulatory practices around the world.

This made answering the question, "Which banking system works best?" all the more important.

How much diversity did they find? Examples:

Does the size of a country's banking system matter? In Germany, bank assets represent 361 percent of GDP, while in the U.S. it's 64 percent and in Sudan only 14 percent.

Does government ownership of banks matter? In China, 98 percent of the banking assets are government owned, while in India, the government owns 75 percent. In the U.S., the government owns no banks.

Does the amount of assets in foreign banks matter? In Italy, only 6 percent of banking assets are foreign-owned, while that number is 19 percent in the U.S. and 99 percent in New Zealand.

In addition, Barth and Caprio said, each country's regulatory system is different. For instance, half of the 152 countries they and colleague Ross Levine surveyed have explicit deposit insurance policies, while the other half none. Restrictions on the activities in which banks may engage differ country by country. So do the supervisory powers in each country.

So given all of these differences, what system works best? What rules and regulations should countries adopt to ensure the most efficient banking system?

Barth, Caprio and Levine — authors of a new book, Rethinking Bank Regulation: Till Angels Govern, which is based on their research — found that:

  • Open, competitive, democratic political institutions foster private monitoring and transparency. These countries are less likely to limit bank entry and activities and are less likely to have state banks.
  • Closed, uncompetitive, autocratic political systems do not favor transparency. These countries limit bank entry and activities and tend to have state banks.

Based on their research, Barth and Caprio said, they reached the following conclusions:

  • Countries should avoid relying on bank-activity restrictions, stringent official powers and state ownership.
  • They should emphasize private monitoring and avoid generous deposit-insurance schemes.
  • They should foster/force information disclosure.

Most important, they said, supervisors have a crucial role in governing the financial system, but governments should support market discipline, not supplant it with intrusive regulation and supervision.

"It's the private sector's ability to monitor that matters more to the health of the banking system (than supervision)," Caprio said.

Finally, they said, no one size fits all. Given the complexities of each country's economic, legal and political systems, and their individual conditions and needs, there is no simple set of "best practices" to banking regulation in countries around the world.

Does this all matter? Of course, Barth said. "A stable and well-functioning banking system is critical for economic growth and development."

James R. Barth is a Senior Fellow at the Milken Institute and the Lowder Eminent Scholar in Finance at Auburn University. He also has been professor of economics at George Washington University, associate director of the economics program at the National Science Foundation, and Shaw Foundation Professor of Banking and Finance at Nanyang Technological University. Barth was an appointee of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush as chief economist of the Office of Thrift Supervision, and previously as chief economist of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Most recently, he served as leader of an international team advising the People's Bank of China on banking reform.

Gerard Caprio, Jr. is director for policy in the Financial Sector Vice Presidency at the World Bank, and is Professor of Economics at Williams College. Previously he was manager, Financial Sector Research, in the bank's Development Research Group. He is the World Bank's senior spokesperson on financial markets and financial sector regulation, development and reform. Before joining the bank in 1988, Caprio was vice president and head of global economics at JPMorgan, and previously held economist positions at the Federal Reserve Board and the IMF, and taught at George Washington University.
Venue:
Milken Institute Conference Center
Santa Monica, CA
Speakers:
James R. Barth, Senior Fellow, Milken Institute
Gerard Caprio, Jr., Director for Policy, World Bank
blurb: In this talk, Barth, a Senior Fellow at the Institute, and Caprio, a director at the World Bank, discuss the importance of picking the right banking system – and the right bank regulations – to increase economic growth.

Name: Off the Record With Gerard Caprio
Description:
Gerard Caprio talks about changes at the World Bank during an address to Milken Institute Associates.

Soon, Gerard Caprio, Jr. will be back in academia, leaving behind 17 years fighting global poverty as a director at the World Bank.

But before he goes, he had a few thoughts for Milken Institute Associates who gathered for an "Off the Record With Gerard Caprio" breakfast meeting.

Among some of his points:

  • Many governments around the world are more interested in economic growth than poverty — mostly the so-called "middle-income" nations.
  • How well countries allocate their people's savings has a major impact on economic development.
  • Banks in general are safer today, but their lending is down.

Caprio, an expert on international banking systems and regulation, said the keys to economic growth in developing countries remain improving their financial, information and legal systems.

He also talked about the World Bank's direction under new president Paul Wolfowitz, and what changes can be expected in the future; the anti-globalization movement; and different approaches to lending around the world.

Gerard Caprio, Jr. is director for policy in the Financial Sector Vice Presidency at the World Bank. Starting in January 2006, he joins Williams College as a Professor of Economics. Previously he was manager, Financial Sector Research, in the World Bank's Development Research Group. He is the World Bank's senior spokesperson on financial markets and financial sector regulation, development and reform. Before joining the bank in 1988, Caprio was vice president and head of global economics at JPMorgan, and previously held economist positions at the Federal Reserve Board and the IMF, and taught at George Washington University.

The "Off the Record with ..." series of private meetings with individuals of distinction is open to members of the Milken Institute Associates. To join, please contact Mindy Silverstein, Director of Milken Institute Associates, at (310) 570-4634, or by e-mail at msilverstein @milkeninstitute.org.

Name: Off the Record With Sandra Lee
Description:
With the increasingly intense nature of global markets and trade, Hong Kong is one of the most globally oriented business and economic centers in the world.

And Sandra Lee, Permanent Secretary for Economic Development of the Government of Hong Kong, is at the center of this dynamic, with responsibilities that include logistics, aviation, ports, energy, postal services, meteorological services, competition policy, consumer protection and tourism.

In a breakfast meeting with members of the Milken Institute Associates and invited guests, Lee painted a positive picture of Hong Kong's future. After suffering through the financial crises of the late 1990s, the SARS scare and other blows to the economy, the city has recovered nicely, she said.

"Last year was very good for Hong Kong," she said, pointing out that Hong Kong's GDP was up 7 percent in 2005.

Lee and others in her delegation, including Alan Lee, Chairman of Hong Kong Container Terminal Operators Association, and Willy Lin, Chairman of Hong Kong Shippers' Council, described the growing competition in China, but they said they are working well with mainland China's leaders.

She discussed the Hong Kong government's policies on economic and trade development, the impact that proposed new shipyards in Shanghai will have on their competitive relationship with the mainland and environmental pollution.

Ms. Lee was appointed to the Administrative Service of the Hong Kong Government in 1979. Over the years, she has worked in a number of policy and resource bureaus at the Government Secretariat and overseas offices in Washington, D.C. and London. More recently Ms. Lee served as Director-General of the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office in London and Secretary for Economic Services. She has been in her present post as Permanent Secretary for Economic Development since July 2002.
